Rigidity of warped cones and coarse geometry of expanders

David Fisher ,Â  Thang Nguyen Â andÂ  Wouter van Limbeek
(Date: March 12, 2024)
Abstract.

We study the geometry of warped cones over free, minimal isometric group actions and related constructions of expander graphs. We prove a rigidity theorem for the coarse geometry of such warped cones: Namely, if a group has no abelian factors, then two such warped cones are quasi-isometric if and only if the actions are finite covers of conjugate actions. As a consequence, we produce continuous families of non-quasi-isometric expanders and superexpanders. The proof relies on the use of coarse topology for warped cones, such as a computation of their coarse fundamental groups.

Contents
  1. 1 Introduction
  2. 2 Preliminary remarks
  3. 3 Coarse fundamental group of level sets of warped cones
  4. 4 Coarse homotopy invariance of group contributions
  5. 5 Stabilization of maps on coarse fundamental groups
  6. 6 Identification of growth rate by quasi-isometry
  7. 7 Construction of a semiconjugacy
  8. 8 Promotion of the semiconjugacy
  9. 9 Construction of families of expanders

1. Introduction

1.1. Brief overview:

This paper can be viewed from two distinct points of view. From one point of view, our primary contribution is proving the existence of wide classes of expanders and superexpanders which are geometrically different. These results are discussed in Subsection 1.3 of this introduction. From another point of view, we prove a dramatic rigidity result for group actions. Namely, we show that a certain geometric space associated to a group action, the warped cone of John Roe, is a complete conjugacy invariant for a large class of group actions. Our results on rigidity of group actions can be viewed as a dynamical analogue of quasi-isometric rigidity in geometric group theory and have other applications in the context of the coarse Baum-Connes conjecture. These results are discussed in Section 1.2. All the results on expanders and superexpanders are deduced from the rigidity results for group actions. The reader can read the next two subsections of this paper in either order, depending on their interests.

1.2. Warped Cones

Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a finitely generated group acting isometrically on a compact metric space Mğ‘€M. For t>0ğ‘¡0t>0, define the metric space Mt:=(tâ€‹MÃ—Î“)/Î“assignsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘€Î“Î“M_{t}:=(tM\times\Gamma)/\Gamma, where tâ€‹Mğ‘¡ğ‘€tM is a copy of Mğ‘€M scaled by a factor tğ‘¡t and Î“Î“\Gamma is equipped with a fixed word metric. Define the geometric cone ğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ’¢â†·Î“M\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} to be a metric space that assembles all Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t} as ğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)=(MÃ—(0,âˆ)Ã—Î“)/Î“ğ’¢â†·Î“Mğ‘€0Î“Î“\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}=(M\times(0,\infty)\times\Gamma)/\Gamma where the metric on MÃ—(0,âˆ)ğ‘€0M\times(0,\infty) is given by tâ€‹g+dâ€‹t2ğ‘¡ğ‘”ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¡2tg+dt^{2} for some fixed Riemannian metric gğ‘”g on Mğ‘€M. For isometric Î“Î“\Gamma actions this definition coincides with Roeâ€™s warped cone over a group action [Roe], see Remark 2.2. At times it is better for applications to consider instead the metric space ğ’â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ’â†·Î“M\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} that is simply the disjoint union of the Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t}. We will study warped cones up to quasi-isometry.

Definition 1.1.

Let Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY be metric spaces. A map f:Xâ†’Y:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘‹ğ‘Œf:X\rightarrow Y is an (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-quasi-isometry if there exist L>1ğ¿1L>1 and C>0ğ¶0C>0 such that:

  1. (1)

    for every a,bâˆˆXğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‹a,b\in X we have 1Lâ€‹dXâ€‹(a,b)âˆ’Câ‰¤dYâ€‹(fâ€‹(a),fâ€‹(b))â‰¤Lâ€‹dXâ€‹(a,b)+C1ğ¿subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘ğ¶subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘ğ¶\frac{1}{L}d_{X}(a,b)-C\leq d_{Y}(f(a),f(b))\leq Ld_{X}(a,b)+C

  2. (2)

    for every yâˆˆYğ‘¦ğ‘Œy\in Y, there is xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X such that dYâ€‹(fâ€‹(x),y)â‰¤Csubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ¶d_{Y}(f(x),y)\leq C.

To study quasi-isometries of disjoint unions of level sets, we need to extend this notion slightly. Given a collection of spaces {Xt}tâˆˆTsubscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\{X_{t}\}_{t\in T} and {Ys}sâˆˆSsubscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘†\{Y_{s}\}_{s\in S} we call them (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-quasi-isometric if there is a bijection Ï•:Tâ†’S:italic-Ï•â†’ğ‘‡ğ‘†\phi:T\rightarrow S and (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-quasi-isometries ft:Xtâ†’YÏ•â€‹(t):subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡â†’subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œitalic-Ï•ğ‘¡f_{t}:X_{t}\rightarrow Y_{\phi(t)}. As usual spaces or collections of spaces are quasi-isometric if there exist some L>1ğ¿1L>1 and C>0ğ¶0C>0 for which they are (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-quasi-isometric.

To state a version of our results we need to define what it means for group actions to be commensurable. While this is similar to, and motivated by, the definition of commensurability for finitely generated groups, we warn the reader that actions of commensurable groups are not commensurable in this sense and in fact need not give rise to quasi-isometric warped cones! The notion in this context is slightly more complicated than in the world of finitely generated groups.

Definition 1.2.

Two group actions Î“0â†·M0â†·subscriptÎ“0subscriptğ‘€0\Gamma_{0}\curvearrowright M_{0} and Î“1â†·M1â†·subscriptÎ“1subscriptğ‘€1\Gamma_{1}\curvearrowright M_{1} are commensurable if

  • â€¢

    Misubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–M_{i} is a finite cover of Miâˆ’1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–1M_{i-1} for one of i=0,1ğ‘–01i=0,1 and

  • â€¢

    for the same index iğ‘–i we have that Î“isubscriptÎ“ğ‘–\Gamma_{i} is the group of lifts of Î“iâˆ’1subscriptÎ“ğ‘–1\Gamma_{i-1} to Misubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–M_{i}.

In the definition the indices should be interpreted modulo 222. This is slightly awkward but in the actual theorems it will be finite quotients of the original actions that are related, not finite covers. This last notion corresponds most closely to the idea of two subgroups of a larger group having intersection which has finite index in both, i.e. the extrinsic definition of commensurability. For the intrinisic definition of commensurablity, i.e. the analogue of having isomorphic finite index subgroups, it is useful to make explicit the notion of when two actions are isomorphic up to commensuration. In particular, the regularity of the commensurating map plays a role in applications.

Definition 1.3.

A commensuration of the actions Î“â†·Mâ†·Î“ğ‘€\Gamma\curvearrowright M and Î›â†·Nâ†·Î›ğ‘\Lambda\curvearrowright N consists of the following data:

  • â€¢

    an action Î“â€²â†·Mâ€²â†·superscriptÎ“â€²superscriptğ‘€â€²\Gamma^{\prime}\curvearrowright M^{\prime} commensurable to Î“â†·Mâ†·Î“ğ‘€\Gamma\curvearrowright M and an action Î›â€²â†·Nâ€²â†·superscriptÎ›â€²superscriptğ‘â€²\Lambda^{\prime}\curvearrowright N^{\prime} commensurable to Î›â†·Nâ†·Î›ğ‘\Lambda\curvearrowright N,

  • â€¢

    a bi-Lipschitz map f:Mâ€²â†’Nâ€²:ğ‘“â†’superscriptğ‘€â€²superscriptğ‘â€²f:M^{\prime}\to N^{\prime},

  • â€¢

    an isomorphism Ï†:Î“â€²â†’Î›â€²:ğœ‘â†’superscriptÎ“â€²superscriptÎ›â€²\varphi:\Gamma^{\prime}\to\Lambda^{\prime},

such that fğ‘“f is Ï†ğœ‘\varphi-equivariant. If Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} and Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime} are homogeneous spaces and fğ‘“f is affine, then we call this data an affine commensuration.

Here a map between homogeneous spaces is affine if it is compatible with the homogeneous structures, i.e. if it is the composition of a translation and a group automorphism (see Definition 8.1).

We state our main result first for geometric warped cones. Under an additional technical condition, we will obtain a similar result for non-geometric warped cones below.

Theorem 1.4.

Let Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda be finitely presented groups acting isometrically, freely and minimally on compact manifolds Mğ‘€M and Nğ‘N (respectively). Assume that neither of Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda is commensurable to a group with a nontrivial free abelian factor. Suppose that ğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ’¢â†·Î“M\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} is quasi-isometric to ğ’¢â€‹(Î›â†·N)ğ’¢â†·Î›N\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)}. Then there is an affine commensuration of the two actions.

For a minimal isometric Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“action on Mğ‘€M, the closure GğºG of Î“Î“\Gamma in Isomâ¡(M)Isomğ‘€\operatorname{Isom}(M) acts transitively on the compact manifold Mğ‘€M and minimality is preserved by commensurability. So our hypotheses imply that Mğ‘€M and Nğ‘N, as well as Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} and Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime}, are homogeneous and so the claim that the commensuration is affine is sensible.

We can also prove a result forcing an affine commensuration of actions even given only sequences (tn)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›(t_{n}) and (sn)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›(s_{n}) and quasi-isometries between the tnsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t_{n}â€“level set of ğ’â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ’â†·Î“M\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} and the snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›s_{n}â€“level set ğ’â€‹(Î›â†·N)ğ’â†·Î›N\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)}, but this requires some additional technical assumptions on acting groups. The main advantage from our perspective of the geometric warped cone is that the maps on different level sets are in a natural sense coarsely homotopic. The more general context is interesting because it is the avenue to our results about expanders and superexpanders. For this more general result, we require an additional assumption on one of the acting groups, which we call Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} and define in Subsection 5.1 below. Groups with property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} have only finitely many automorphisms satisfying any fixed constraint on distortion with respect to the stable length of group elements. Lattices in semisimple Lie groups have property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Theorem 1.5.

Let Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda be finitely presented groups acting isometrically, freely and minimally on compact manifolds Mğ‘€M and Nğ‘N (respectively). Assume that

  • â€¢

    Neither of Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda is commensurable to a group with a nontrivial free abelian factor, and Î“Î“\Gamma has Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}, and

  • â€¢

    There exist uniform quasi-isometries fn:Mtnâ†’Nsn:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›â†’subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›f_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}}, where tn,snâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›t_{n},s_{n}\to\infty.

Then there is an affine commensuration of the action of Î“Î“\Gamma on Mğ‘€M and the action of Î›Î›\Lambda on Nğ‘N.

We next state, somewhat informally, a corollary of Theorem 1.5, our results for building many non-quasi-isometric expanders/group actions in Section 9, and the main results of Sawickiâ€™s recent paper on the coarse Baum-Connes conjecture for warped cones over group actions with spectral gap [Saw3]. Sawickiâ€™s proof is based on ghost projections constructed in an earlier paper of Drutu and Nowak [DN]. We note that we use Theorem 1.5, not Theorem 1.4, since Sawicki is forced to pass to discrete versions of the cone for his proofs.

Corollary 1.6.

There are continua of non-quasi-isometric spaces where the coarse Baum-Connes assembly map is not surjective.

In the next subsection we discuss applications of our results to producing families of expanders that are not quasi-isometric. In the few subsections following that one, we discuss the necessity of the hypotheses of these two theorems, some history of the work motivating our interest in this problem, and finally an outline of both our proofs and the paper.

1.3. Expanders

Expander graphs play an important role in fields ranging from computer science to geometric topology to operator algebras. An expander graph is a sequence of finite graphs of increasing size and bounded degree with strong spectral properties that, for example, force embeddings of the graphs into Hilbert spaces to be highly distorted (see Section 9.2 for precise definitions). Recently, attention has also been drawn to superexpanders where the spectral properties prevent good embeddings into broader classes of metric spaces. The first constructions of expanders were probabilistic, but so far there is no probabilistic construction of superexpanders. More recently, attention has focused on constructions of (super)expanders with a wide range of geometric behavior. This began in [MN1, Theorem 9.1] and [Ost, Theorem 5.76] and has led to a rush of recent results by Khukhroâ€“Valette, Hume, Delabieâ€“Khukro, De Laatâ€“Vigolo and Sawicki [KV, Hum, DK, dLV, Saw1]. Most of these papers study the problem from the point of view of its intrinsic interest, but there are also intriguing connections to the theory of computation in [MN2].

Explicit examples of expanders were first constructed by Margulis using congruence quotients of groups with property (T) [Mar1]. Using a strengthening of Property (T), Lafforgue showed that the same graphs are superexpanders [Laf]. Group actions on homogeneous spaces are a geometric source of expanders: Indeed, Margulis also constructed expanders from the action of SLâ¡(n,â„¤)SLğ‘›â„¤\operatorname{SL}(n,\mathbb{Z}) on ğ•‹nsuperscriptğ•‹ğ‘›\mathbb{T}^{n} for any nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2 [Mar1]. Margulisâ€™ construction is mostly carried out in the dual setting of SLâ¡(n,â„¤)SLğ‘›â„¤\operatorname{SL}(n,\mathbb{Z}) actions on â„¤nsuperscriptâ„¤ğ‘›\mathbb{Z}^{n}, while the explicit translation to actions on homogeneous spaces was first made by Gabber and Galil [GG].

To see that group actions yield a robust source of expanders and superexpanders, we recall a discretiziation procedure that converts a group action into a sequence of graphs. Given a group action on a metric space (M,d)ğ‘€ğ‘‘(M,d), we can consider rescalings Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t} defined as (M,tâ€‹d)ğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘‘(M,td). For a sequence tnâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t_{n}\to\infty, Vigolo discretizes the rescalings Mtnsubscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›M_{t_{n}} to get a sequence of approximating graphs Xnsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X_{n}, and gives a criterion for {Xn}nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğ‘›\{X_{n}\}_{n} to be an expander sequence [Vig1]. The approximating graph is obtained by partitioning each Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t} into sets of roughly equal diameter which correspond to vertices of the graph and then adding an edge between two elements in the partition if the translate of one by a generator intersects the other. Vigolo shows his discretizations are expanders if and only if the action of Î“Î“\Gamma on Mğ‘€M has a spectral gap, a result extended to superexpanders by Sawicki [Saw1]. In fact, for the proofs of our theorem, we will need to pass from this sequence of graphs to one more closely tied to the geometry of Mğ‘€M as describe in [Vig1, Section 6].

When the underlying space is a manifold, we will refer to these as geometric expanders or geometric superexpanders.

There is a large literature producing actions with spectral gaps, so this construction provides a wealth of methods to produce expanders. Since we will focus on minimal isometric group actions, we will need a compact group Kğ¾K and a dense subgroup Î”<KÎ”ğ¾\Delta<K with a spectral gap on L2â€‹(K)superscriptğ¿2ğ¾L^{2}(K). For particular choices of Kğ¾K, many of these are constructed as lattices in a Lie group GğºG which have dense embeddings in a compact form Kğ¾K of GğºG, namely by Margulis and Sullivan using groups with property (T)ğ‘‡(T) and by Drinâ€™feld using more elaborate representation theory [Mar2, Sul, Dri]. In the late â€™90s, examples were found by more elementary methods by Gamburdâ€“Jakobsonâ€“Sarnak in [GJS] where the authors conjecture that a generic dense free subgroup of a compact simple group Kğ¾K will have a spectral gap. In recent work towards that conjecture, Bourgainâ€“Gamburd and Benoistâ€“De Saxce show that any dense free subgroup of Kğ¾K with algebraic entries has a spectral gap [BG2, BG1, BdS].

Our contribution to the geometry of expanders will be in providing many examples of expanders that are not quasi-isometric. While much of the work mentioned above is of this kind, so far applications to computer science require stronger results, namely that these expanders are, in an appropriate sense, an expander for random graphs [MN2]. It is possible that the geometric expanders considered here also satisfy this property, but a proof of this will require new ideas.

We say two sequences of graphs {Xn}subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›\{X_{n}\} and {Yn}subscriptğ‘Œğ‘›\{Y_{n}\} are (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“quasi-isometric if there are maps fn:Xnâ†’Yn:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›â†’subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Œğ‘›f_{n}:X_{n}\rightarrow Y_{n} that are (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“quasi-isometries. (See Definition 1.1.) Interested in the possible geometry of expanders, we define two sequence of graphs to be {Xn}subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›\{X_{n}\} and {Yn}subscriptğ‘Œğ‘›\{Y_{n}\} to (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-quasi-isometrically disjoint if there are no (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-quasi-isometric subsequences. (When discussing quasi-isometry of subsequences, we assume the obvious re-indexing.) When the sequences are (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-quasi-isometrically disjoint for all Lğ¿L and Cğ¶C, we call them simply quasi-isometrically disjoint. We call a collection Î©Î©\Omega of sequences of graphs quasi-isometrically disjoint if any pair of sequences in Î©Î©\Omega is quasi-isometrically disjoint. From our results on group actions, we can produce many explicit families of quasi-isometrically disjoint expanders:

Theorem 1.7.

Let Kğ¾K be a compact Lie group and fix râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2. Then free, rank rğ‘Ÿr subgroups of Kğ¾K with spectral gap yield quasi-isometrically disjoint expanders unless they are commensurable. In particular, there exist explicit quasi-isometrically disjoint continuous families of expanders.

To obtain families as in the theorem, we just note that from the existing literature we can produce many free groups with spectral gap: For example, set K=SUâ¡(n)ğ¾SUğ‘›K=\operatorname{SU}(n) with nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2 and fix a free dense rank subgroup Î›âŠ†SUâ¡(n)Î›SUğ‘›\Lambda\subseteq\operatorname{SU}(n) of rank râˆ’1ğ‘Ÿ1r-1 and with spectral gap. Then consider the family {âŸ¨Î›,kâŸ©}kâˆˆKsubscriptÎ›ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ¾\{\langle\Lambda,k\rangle\}_{k\in K}. For generic kğ‘˜k, we have Î“:=âŸ¨Î›,kâŸ©â‰…FrassignÎ“Î›ğ‘˜subscriptğ¹ğ‘Ÿ\Gamma:=\langle\Lambda,k\rangle\cong F_{r}, and the spectral gap for Î›Î›\Lambda implies that Î“Î“\Gamma has spectral gap. For more details and other constructions, see Section 9.

We remark here that before the above result, the only known construction of uncountably many quasi-isometrically disjoint expanders is obtained by a fixing a single expander X:={Xn}nassignğ‘‹subscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğ‘›X:=\{X_{n}\}_{n} with some geometric invariant, such as diameter, growing very rapidly, and considering the set of all subsequences of Xğ‘‹X. To show this produces uncountably many quasi-isometrically disjoint expanders, one uses that there are uncountably many sequences of natural numbers that pairwise have finite intersection, a fact that was pointed out to us by D. Sawicki. As already pointed out by Vigolo, constructions from warped cones can lead to large families which cannot easily be distinguished by a condition on rapidly growing geometric invariants [Vig1]. For example, in Theorem 1.7 and Theorem 1.8 below we can always produce examples where either number of vertices or the diameter of the nğ‘›nth graph is nğ‘›n.

From the point of view of coarse geometry a key property of expanders is that they do not embed uniformly in any Hilbert space. By analogy, one defines superexpanders to be graphs that satisfy a certain PoincarÃ© inequality that obstructs uniform embedding in some class ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} of Banach spaces. Here we will always consider the class ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} of Banach spaces with nontrivial Rademacher type, which includes the class of uniformly convex Banach spaces. Superexpanders were first shown to exist by Lafforgue using strong property (T) in [Laf]. More examples were constructed by Mendel and Naor in [MN1] and by Liao in [Lia]. It is already clear from Lafforgueâ€™s first paper that his results, combined with Margulisâ€™ construction in [Mar2], produce geometric expanders. While there are in some sense many fewer examples of group actions with the stronger spectral properties required to produce geometric superexpanders, we are still able to construct families of these. For the following theorem we let GğºG be a higher rank pğ‘p-adic Lie group, Î›<GÎ›ğº\Lambda<G a cocompact lattice with a dense image homomorphism Ï:Î›â†’K:ğœŒâ†’Î›ğ¾\rho:\Lambda\to K where Kğ¾K is a compact connected Lie group. Given a free group Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} with k>2ğ‘˜2k>2, we let Î“=Î›Ã—FkÎ“Î›subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜\Gamma=\Lambda\times F_{k} which acts on Kğ¾K by letting Ïâ€‹(Î›)ğœŒÎ›\rho(\Lambda) act on the left, picking any inclusion i:Fkâ†’K:ğ‘–â†’subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ¾i:F_{k}\rightarrow K and letting iâ€‹(Fk)ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜i(F_{k}) act on the right.

Theorem 1.8.

Varying the inclusion iğ‘–i above, the actions of Î“Î“\Gamma on Kğ¾K produce explicit quasi-isometrically disjoint families of superexpanders.

In the proof of this theorem the Î›Î›\Lambdaâ€“action provides the spectral gap required to make the graphs superexpanders, while the free group provides us with the ability to vary the actions and geometry of the graphs. Both Theorem 1.7 and 1.8 are consequences of Theorem 1.5 and some results on character varieties used to guarantee that the actions are free and minimal.

1.4. History and motivations

Given a group Î“Î“\Gamma and a sequence Î“nsubscriptÎ“ğ‘›\Gamma_{n} of finite index subgroups, the box space is the disjoint union of metric graphs Xn=Î“/Î“nsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›Î“subscriptÎ“ğ‘›X_{n}=\Gamma/\Gamma_{n}. The key observation that begins the paper of Khukhroâ€“Valette is that the Gromovâ€“Hausdorff limit of {Xn}nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğ‘›\{X_{n}\}_{n} is in fact Î“Î“\Gamma, so that if there is a quasi-isometry between box spaces of Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda, then Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda are quasi-isometric and one has access to the broad literature on quasi-isometries of groups. The proof of De Laatâ€“Vigolo follows a similar line but replaces box spaces by warped cones. They study warped cones over actions on manifolds and show that any sequence of level sets for ğ’â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ’â†·Î“M\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} has Gromovâ€“Hausdorff limit Î“Ã—â„dim(M)Î“superscriptâ„dimensionğ‘€\Gamma\times\mathbb{R}^{\dim(M)}, a result also proven by Sawicki in [Saw2]. In both cases these results allow one to distinguish large classes of expanders by referring to the literature on quasi-isometric rigidity of groups.

More recently, Delabieâ€“Khukhro have shown that quasi-isometries of box spaces are in fact much more restricted than just quasi-isometries of the ambient group [DK]. Essentially Delabieâ€“Khukhro use that the quasi-isometry makes the box spaces coarsely homotopic and show that this forces the ambient groups to be commensurable and the sequences of subgroups to be isomorphic using the notion of a coarse fundamental group. These results are the natural analogue of ours in the setting of box spaces, but do not require any assumptions on the groups. The fact that there is some obstruction to a result like ours in terms of the acting group is already noticed explicitly by Sawicki, who proves a conditional result about quasi-isometries of warped cones induced by a single good map f:Mâ†’N:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘€ğ‘f:M\rightarrow N [Saw2]. While we do not use this result of Sawickiâ€™s here, from this perspective, a key technical difficulty in our work is producing any such map.

We are also motivated by the natural analogy between classifying finitely generated groups up to quasi-isometry and classifying the warped cones of group actions up to quasi-isometry. The new classification questions that arise seems to connect to numerous other fields of mathematics including computer science, dynamics, geometric group theory and operator algebras. We remark here that much as it is for finitely generated groups, quasi-isometry is the right notion of equivalence in the category of warped cones. First, changing the generating set of the acting group changes the warped cone metric but the metrics remain quasi-isometric. Second, choosing a different but bi-Lipschitz metric on Mğ‘€M also changes the warped cone metric, but again only up to quasi-isometry. This second observation implies that all Riemannian metrics on a fixed manifold will give rise to quasi-isometric warped cones. In the context of actions on totally disconnected spaces, Sawicki shows that non-bi-Lipschitz metrics can give rise to non-quasi-isometric warped cones for the same group action. One can probably also produce examples of this in the setting of actions on manifolds simply by taking a Riemannian metric and snowflaking it.

1.5. Hypothesis on group actions

In both Theorems 1.4 and 1.5, the assumption on absence of abelian factors of Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda is necessary: In [Kim], Kim shows that circle rotations that are related by integral fractional linear transformations give rise to quasi-isometric geometric warped cones. Since rotation number is a conjugacy invariant of rotations, this provides many non-conjugate â„¤â„¤\mathbb{Z}â€“actions on S1superscriptğ‘†1S^{1} that have quasi-isometric geometric warped cones and the rotation numbers can be sufficiently different that the problem is not resolved by commensuration of the actions. In an appendix to a recent paper by Sawicki, Kielakâ€“Sawicki give an even more remarkable construction showing that there are rotations on S1superscriptğ‘†1S^{1} whose warped cone is quasi-isometric to the warped cone of the trivial action on ğ•‹2superscriptğ•‹2\mathbb{T}^{2} [Saw2] and also produce a variety of other examples of this flavor, including ones between minimal isometric actions. The key insight there is to see that one can shift geometry of the acting group to geometry of the ambient space, provided one takes sequences of level sets that grow at different rates and the geometry of the space and group factors are sufficiently similar. These more exotic examples do not give rise to quasi-isometries of geometric warped cones.

We do not currently know if Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} is necessary in Theorem 1.5 or if all finitely generated subgroups of compact Lie groups have Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}. We have also not explored the degree to which variants of the theorems might be true for actions that are not isometric, which is an intriguing direction for future research.

1.6. Basic intuition and outline of the proofs and the paper

The basic intuition behind our theorem is roughly that if the quasi-isometries between the cones respected a distinction between directions related to paths in the manifold and directions related to paths in the group, then the quasi-isometry would appear to need to recognize the orbit structure of the action. This is because points x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y in Mğ‘€M are in the same Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“orbit if and only if the distance between xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y in level sets of ğ’â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ’â†·Î“M\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} remains bounded. In addition if the quasi-isometry respects the distinction between directions related to paths in the manifold and directions related to paths in the group, one should be able to rescale the quasi-isometries along the manifold direction to have them converge to a bi-Lipschitz map. Together these two intuitions would produce an orbit equivalence between actions, which can be seen to be a conjugacy by results of the first author and Whyte [FW]. The actual proof does not follow exactly this line and as mentioned above, the examples of Kim and Kielakâ€“Sawicki show that the basic intuition is wrong for at least some examples. Their intriguing examples show that one cannot, in general, hope that quasi-isometries of warped cones respect the distinction between directions related to paths in the manifold and paths in the group. Our theorems and proofs do give strong evidence that in the case of minimal isometric actions, their examples capture more or less all the ways in which this mixing of space and orbit can occur for quasi-isometries of warped cones.

Before beginning our proof, Section 2 recalls definitions of warped cones and coarse fundamental groups. The first step of our proof is to show that the coarse fundamental group of a warped cone ğ’â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ’â†·Î“M\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} is the group Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} of lifts of the Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“action to the universal cover M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M} of Mğ‘€M. A similar computation was obtained independently and simultaneously by Vigolo [Vig2] (see Remark 3.2 for further discussion). As quasi-isometries necessarily induce isomorphisms of coarse fundamental groups, we get an isomorphism between Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} and Î›~~Î›\widetilde{\Lambda} induced by the quasi-isometry of warped cones. In Section 4, we use this to define an obstruction map that captures when a quasi-isometry of warped cones mixes group directions with manifold directions. The obstruction map is a composition

Ï€1â€‹(M)â†’Î“~â€‹âŸ¶â‰…â€‹Î›~â†’Î›â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€~Î“âŸ¶~Î›â†’Î›\pi_{1}(M)\rightarrow\widetilde{\Gamma}\overset{\cong}{\longrightarrow}\widetilde{\Lambda}\rightarrow\Lambda

where the first and last arrow come from the structure of groups of lifts and the isomorphism in the middle arises from our quasi-isometry. We show that after passing to commensurable actions, our hypothesis that Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda have no abelian direct factors forces the obstruction map to vanish. At this point we have isomorphisms Ï€1â€‹(M)â‰…Ï€1â€‹(N)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘\pi_{1}(M)\cong\pi_{1}(N) and Ï†^:Î“â†’Î›:^ğœ‘â†’Î“Î›\widehat{\varphi}:\Gamma\rightarrow\Lambda. The existence of Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi} is already a major development, since we now have an identification of acting groups and so it is sensible to ask if the actions are conjugate.

The outline is actually a bit more complicated at this step. If we have a quasi-isometry of geometric warped cones, it is not hard to see purely from coarse topology that Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi} actually exists and is independent of tğ‘¡t (see Section 5.6). In the context of Theorem 1.5, we actually have a sequence Ï†^nsubscript^ğœ‘ğ‘›\widehat{\varphi}_{n} of isomorphisms and a key step is to argue that this sequence of quasi-isometries stabilize along a subsequence. We actually need only that they stabilize up to conjugation, i.e. that Ï†^nsubscript^ğœ‘ğ‘›\widehat{\varphi}_{n} stabilize in Outâ¡(Î“)OutÎ“\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) rather than in Autâ¡(Î“)AutÎ“\operatorname{Aut}(\Gamma). This is trivial if say Outâ¡(Î“)OutÎ“\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) is finite, but in general requires an argument. In Section 5, we show that the group automorphisms that arise in our context are Lipschitz for the stable length, and we introduce Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} which essentially says that given a constant Dğ·D there are only finitely many elements of Outâ¡(Î“)OutÎ“\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) represented by automorphisms that are Dğ·Dâ€“Lipschitz for stable length.

The next step after this is also a matter that only arises in the setting of Theorem 1.5. The reader only interested in Theorem 1.4 can skip all but the first and last subsections of Section 5 and all of Section 6. In Section 6, we show that vanishing of the obstruction map in the context of Theorem 1.5 forces tnsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t_{n} and snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›s_{n} to be linearly related. Once one knows this, it is easy to see that one can assume tn=snsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›t_{n}=s_{n}. We note here that it is easy to compute the obstruction map for the examples of Kim and Kielakâ€“Sawicki and see that it does not vanish.

The main step of our proof, completed in Section 7, is to show that one can now in fact construct a semiconjugacy between the actions. To do so, we modify the map of levels sets given by the quasi-isometry by a monodromy correction, which measures the extent to which the quasi-isometry mixes manifold and orbit directions. We show these modified maps are coarsely Lipschitz maps between the manifolds. The estimate on the constants is such that the resulting maps converge to a Lipschitz map as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\rightarrow\infty. The stabilization up to conjugacy of the isomorphisms Ï†nsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›\varphi_{n}, allows us to further adjust the quasi-isometries of level sets before passing to the limit, so that in the limit we produce a Lipschitz semiconjugacy.

The final issue is to show that the semi-conjugacy we construct is actually an affine conjugacy, which is proved using a variant of a standard argument from homogeneous dynamics in Section 8.

Lastly in Section 9, we prove Theorems 1.7 and 1.8 from Theorem 1.5. The key idea is to produce continua of group actions that are not affinely conjugate but that have the necessary spectral gaps. To produce expanders, it suffices to consider actions of free group Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} where we fix the action on Fkâˆ’1subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜1F_{k-1} to be one with a spectral gap and vary the last generator as described after Theorem 1.7. To produce superexpanders, where we need a spectral gap with more general Banach coefficients, we consider products Î”Ã—FnÎ”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Delta\times F_{n} acting on a compact Lie group Kğ¾K where Î”Î”\Delta acts by left-translations and Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} acts by right-translations. We guarantee spectral gap for this action by choosing the Î”Î”\Deltaâ€“action so that it already has spectral gap, and this will be inherited by the product. We remark that to think of this as an affine action requires thinking of Kğ¾K as (KÃ—K)/diagâ¡(K)ğ¾ğ¾diagğ¾(K\times K)/\operatorname{diag}(K) where diagâ¡(K)diagğ¾\operatorname{diag}(K) is the image of the diagonal embedding of Kğ¾K. The existence of continua of non-conjugate free minimal actions follows from results on character varieties proved using Borelâ€™s theorem that word maps are dominant, see Subsection 9.3.

Acknowledgments

The authors thank Michael Larsen and Nick Miller for useful conversations on representation varieties and word maps. DF thanks Piotr Nowak for introducing him to this circle of ideas and thanks Assaf Naor and Mikeal de la Salle for interesting conversations about superexpanders and strong property (T)ğ‘‡(T). WvL is grateful to Federico Vigolo for explaining the connection between expanders and warped cones over group actions at the Newton Institute in May 2017, which aroused his interest in this topic. We thank Emmanuel Breuillard for his explanation of the proof of Lemma 9.6. We also thank Vigolo and Damian Sawicki for helpful comments on a preliminary version of this paper. DF was partially supported by NSF Grants DMSâ€“1308291 and DMSâ€“1607041. WvL and TN thank the Indiana University Math Department for support during a visit there and TN thanks the Michigan Math Department and NSF Grant DMSâ€“1607260 for support during a visit there.

2. Preliminary remarks

2.1. Generalities for warped cones

Let a finitely generated group Î“Î“\Gamma act isometrically on a closed Riemannian manifold (M,g)ğ‘€ğ‘”(M,g). Let Sğ‘†S be a symmetric generating set for Î“Î“\Gamma, so that Î“Î“\Gamma is equipped with a word metric. The geometric cone of Î“â†·Mâ†·Î“ğ‘€\Gamma\curvearrowright M is the metric space

ğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M):=(MÃ—(0,âˆ)Ã—Î“)/Î“,assignğ’¢â†·Î“Mğ‘€0Î“Î“\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}:=(M\times(0,\infty)\times\Gamma)/\Gamma,

where MÃ—(0,âˆ)ğ‘€0M\times(0,\infty) is equipped with the warped product metric tâ€‹g+dâ€‹t2ğ‘¡ğ‘”ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¡2tg+dt^{2}. We let tâ€‹Mğ‘¡ğ‘€tM denote the manifold Mğ‘€M with the metric tâ€‹gğ‘¡ğ‘”tg, and write Mt:=(tâ€‹MÃ—Î“)/Î“assignsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘€Î“Î“M_{t}:=(tM\times\Gamma)/\Gamma for the level set of the geometric cone at time tğ‘¡t. We write dtÎ“superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡Î“d_{t}^{\Gamma} for the metric on Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t}. It is immediate that Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t} can also be described as the metric space with underlying set Mğ‘€M and dtÎ“superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡Î“d_{t}^{\Gamma} defined as follows:

Lemma 2.1.

Let x,yâˆˆMğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘€x,y\in M. Then

dtÎ“â€‹(x,y)=infÎ³âˆˆÎ“(tâ€‹dMâ€‹(x,Î³â€‹y)+â€–Î³â€–).superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡Î“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptinfimumğ›¾Î“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘¦normğ›¾d_{t}^{\Gamma}(x,y)=\inf_{\gamma\in\Gamma}(t\,d_{M}(x,\gamma y)+\|\gamma\|).
Remark 2.2.

For clarity, we mention that our definition of the metric on the (geometric) warped cone differs from Roeâ€™s. For isometric actions, it is well known that Roeâ€™s definition is equivalent to the one given by the formula in the lemma above and so to ours.

From the above expression, it is clear the large-scale geometry of these level sets is invariant under taking finite quotients or extensions of the action:

Lemma 2.3.

Let FâŠ†Î“ğ¹Î“F\subseteq\Gamma be a finite normal subgroup, and write Î“â€²:=Î“/FassignsuperscriptÎ“â€²Î“ğ¹\Gamma^{\prime}:=\Gamma/F and Mâ€²:=M/Fassignsuperscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘€ğ¹M^{\prime}:=M/F. Write Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t} (resp. Mtâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡â€²M_{t}^{\prime}) for the level set at time tğ‘¡t of the cone over Î“â†·Mâ†·Î“ğ‘€\Gamma\curvearrowright M (resp. Î“â€²â†·Mâ€²â†·superscriptÎ“â€²superscriptğ‘€â€²\Gamma^{\prime}\curvearrowright M^{\prime}). Then Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t} is (1,B)1ğµ(1,B)â€“quasi-isometric to Mtâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡â€²M_{t}^{\prime}, where BğµB is the maximal word length in Î“Î“\Gamma of an element of Fğ¹F.

Proof.

Write Ï€:Mtâ†’Mtâ€²:ğœ‹â†’subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡â€²\pi:M_{t}\to M_{t}^{\prime} for the natural quotient map. It is easy to see that Ï€ğœ‹\pi is distance non-increasing, i.e. 111â€“Lipschitz. For the lower bound, let Cğ¶C be the maximal word length of an element of the finite group Fğ¹F. Further for any Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma, let Î³â€²superscriptğ›¾â€²\gamma^{\prime} denote its image in Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}. Then we have â€–Î³â€–â‰¤â€–Î³â€²â€–+Cnormğ›¾normsuperscriptğ›¾â€²ğ¶\|\gamma\|\leq\|\gamma^{\prime}\|+C, which easily implies the other bound.âˆ

We also define the full warped cone ğ’â€‹(Î“â†·M):=âŠ”tMtassignğ’â†·Î“Msubscriptsquare-unionğ‘¡subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}:=\sqcup_{t}\,M_{t} and more generally, for any sequence tnâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t_{n}\to\infty, the associated warped cone ğ’(tn)â€‹(Î“â†·M):=âŠ”nMtnassignsubscriptğ’subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›â†·Î“ğ‘€subscriptsquare-unionğ‘›subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\mathscr{C}_{(t_{n})}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M):=\sqcup_{n}\,M_{t_{n}}. For most of the paper, and for applications to expander graphs, we need to consider quasi-isometries of warped cones associated to a sequence (tn)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›(t_{n}), i.e. a sequence of uniform quasi-isometries fn:Mtnâ†’Nsn:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›â†’subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›f_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}}. Note that in general it need not be true that tnâ‰snasymptotically-equalssubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›t_{n}\asymp s_{n} â€“ indeed, we already alluded to an example of Kielakâ€“Sawicki that produces a quasi-isometry between the warped cone over a suitable rotation on S1superscriptğ‘†1S^{1} for a quadratically growing sequence, and the warped cone over the trivial action on T2superscriptğ‘‡2T^{2} for a linear sequence. However, see Section 6, where we show that tnâ‰snasymptotically-equalssubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›t_{n}\asymp s_{n} under suitable hypotheses.

A map f:Xâ†’Y:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘‹ğ‘Œf:X\to Y of metric spaces is called (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“coarsely Lipschitz if for any x1,x2âˆˆXsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘‹x_{1},x_{2}\in X, we have

dYâ€‹(fâ€‹(x1),fâ€‹(x2))â‰¤Lâ€‹dXâ€‹(x1,x2)+C.subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘Œğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥2ğ¿subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2ğ¶d_{Y}(f(x_{1}),f(x_{2}))\leq Ld_{X}(x_{1},x_{2})+C.

In general, a quasi-isometry of geometric cones yields uniformly coarsely Lipschitz maps of levels.

Lemma 2.4.

Let f:ğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)â†’ğ’¢â€‹(Î›â†·N):ğ‘“â†’ğ’¢â†·Î“Mğ’¢â†·Î›Nf:\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\to\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)} be a quasi-isometry. For any t>0ğ‘¡0t>0, define ft:Mtâ†’Nt:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡â†’subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡f_{t}:M_{t}\to N_{t} as the composition

ft:Mtâ†ªğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)â¡âŸ¶ğ‘“â€‹ğ’¢â€‹(Î›â†·N)â† Nt:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡â†ªsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ’¢â†·Î“Mğ‘“âŸ¶ğ’¢â†·Î›Nâ† subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡f_{t}:M_{t}\hookrightarrow\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)}\twoheadrightarrow N_{t}

where the first map is the inclusion of a level set and the last map is the projection to a level set. Then there exists t0>0subscriptğ‘¡00t_{0}>0 such that for t>t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t>t_{0}, the maps ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t} are uniformly coarsely Lipschitz.

Proof.

It is clear the inclusion of a level set is 111-Lipschitz and fğ‘“f is (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-coarsely Lipschitz. Therefore to show the composition is uniformly coarsely Lipschitz, we need to bound the distortion coming from the projection to a level set. More precisely, let p2:ğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)â†’(0,+âˆ):subscriptğ‘2â†’ğ’¢â†·Î“M0p_{2}:\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\to(0,+\infty) denote the projection of the warped cone on the second factor, and likewise define q2:ğ’¢â€‹(Î›â†·N)â†’(0,âˆ):subscriptğ‘2â†’ğ’¢â†·Î›N0q_{2}:\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)}\to(0,\infty). We claim that fğ‘“f coarsely preserves the second factor, namely that there exists Kâ‰¥1ğ¾1K\geq 1 and B>0ğµ0B>0 such that for all xâˆˆğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ‘¥ğ’¢â†·Î“Mx\in\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}, we have

Kâˆ’1â€‹p2â€‹(x)âˆ’Bâ‰¤q2â€‹(fâ€‹(x))â‰¤Kâ€‹p2â€‹(x)+B.superscriptğ¾1subscriptğ‘2ğ‘¥ğµsubscriptğ‘2ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ¾subscriptğ‘2ğ‘¥ğµK^{-1}p_{2}(x)-B\leq q_{2}(f(x))\leq Kp_{2}(x)+B. (2.1)

Indeed, consider a basepoint x0âˆˆğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)subscriptğ‘¥0ğ’¢â†·Î“Mx_{0}\in\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} with p2â€‹(x0)=1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘¥01p_{2}(x_{0})=1. It is easy to obtain the estimates of Equation (2.1) from the observation that p2subscriptğ‘2p_{2} and q2subscriptğ‘2q_{2} are distance non-increasing, and further

dâ€‹(x,x0)â‰¤|p2â€‹(x)âˆ’p2â€‹(x0)|+diamâ¡(M),ğ‘‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘2ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘¥0diamğ‘€d(x,x_{0})\leq|p_{2}(x)-p_{2}(x_{0})|+\operatorname{diam}(M),

and likewise for dâ€‹(fâ€‹(x),fâ€‹(x0))ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥0d(f(x),f(x_{0})).

From Equation (2.1), it is easy to see that the projection of fâ€‹(Mt)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡f(M_{t}) to the level set Ntsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡N_{t} increases distances by a factor of at most (Kâˆ’1â€‹tâˆ’B)âˆ’1â€‹tsuperscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘¡ğµ1ğ‘¡(K^{-1}t-B)^{-1}t, which is bounded above by (2â€‹K)âˆ’1superscript2ğ¾1(2K)^{-1} for tâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡1t\gg 1. âˆ

2.2. Coarse homotopy and fundamental group

We briefly recall the definition of and basic facts about coarse fundamental groups. For more information, see e.g. [BCW, DK].

Definition 2.5.

Let Xğ‘‹X be a metric space and r>0ğ‘Ÿ0r>0. An rğ‘Ÿr-path is a sequence of points Î±=(p0,â€¦,pâ„“)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell}) where dâ€‹(pi,pi+1)<rğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿd(p_{i},p_{i+1})<r. An rğ‘Ÿr-loop is an rğ‘Ÿr-path with p0=pâ„“subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘â„“p_{0}=p_{\ell}. The endpoint append of an rğ‘Ÿr-path Î±ğ›¼\alpha is the rğ‘Ÿr-path

appendâ¡(Î±)=(p0,â€¦,pâ„“,pâ„“).appendğ›¼subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘â„“\operatorname{append}(\alpha)=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell},p_{\ell}).

If Î²=appendâ¡(Î±)ğ›½appendğ›¼\beta=\operatorname{append}(\alpha), we say Î±ğ›¼\alpha is the endpoint deletion of Î²ğ›½\beta. Two rğ‘Ÿr-paths Î±=(p0,â€¦,pâ„“)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell}) and Î²=(q0,â€¦,qn)ğ›½subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›\beta=(q_{0},\dots,q_{n}) are rğ‘Ÿr-close if either

  1. (a)

    Î²ğ›½\beta is the endpoint append or deletion of Î±ğ›¼\alpha, or

  2. (b)

    Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta have the same length (i.e. â„“=nâ„“ğ‘›\ell=n) and dâ€‹(pi,qi)<rğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿd(p_{i},q_{i})<r for all iğ‘–i.

An rğ‘Ÿr-homotopy based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} between two rğ‘Ÿr-loops Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} is a sequence of rğ‘Ÿr-loops based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}

Î±=c0,c1,â€¦,ckâˆ’1,ck=Î²formulae-sequenceğ›¼subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ›½\alpha=c_{0},c_{1},\dots,c_{k-1},c_{k}=\beta

where ci,ci+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1c_{i},c_{i+1} are rğ‘Ÿr-close for all iğ‘–i.

We define the coarse fundamental group:

Definition 2.6.

Let Xğ‘‹X be a metric space and r>0ğ‘Ÿ0r>0 and p0âˆˆXsubscriptğ‘0ğ‘‹p_{0}\in X. The coarse fundamental group of Xğ‘‹X based at x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0} and of scale rğ‘Ÿr is the group Ï€1â€‹(X,x0;r)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r) whose elements are rğ‘Ÿr-homotopy classes of rğ‘Ÿr-loops based at x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}, with multiplication given by concatenation.

Let us first discuss dependence on the basepoint x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}. The situation is completely parallel to the one for (continuous) fundamental groups. Namely, we say a metric space is connected on the scale rğ‘Ÿr if there is an rğ‘Ÿr-path between any two of its points. If a space is connected on the scale rğ‘Ÿr, then the isomorphism type of Ï€1â€‹(X,x0;r)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r) is independent of x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}. In this case we refer to this group as Ï€1â€‹(X;r)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(X;r). Any two possible identifications differ by an inner automorphism.

Let us now discuss basic functoriality properties of coarse fundamental group of a metric space Xğ‘‹X. First, we can compare the coarse fundamental group at different scales r1<r2subscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘Ÿ2r_{1}<r_{2}. Namely, since any r1subscriptğ‘Ÿ1r_{1}-path is an r2subscriptğ‘Ÿ2r_{2}-path, we have an obvious change of scaleâ€“map

Ï€1â€‹(X,x0;r1)â†’Ï€1â€‹(X,x0;r2).â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘Ÿ2\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r_{1})\to\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r_{2}).

If cğ‘c is a (continuous) path in Xğ‘‹X, we say an rğ‘Ÿr-path Î±=(p0,â€¦,pâ„“)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell}) is a discretization of cğ‘c on the scale rğ‘Ÿr if there is a partition

0=t0<t1<â‹¯<tâ„“=10subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¡â„“10=t_{0}<t_{1}<\dots<t_{\ell}=1

of [0,1]01[0,1] such that pi=câ€‹(ti)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–p_{i}=c(t_{i}) and câ€‹([ti,ti+1])âŠ†BXâ€‹(pi;r)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–1subscriptğµğ‘‹subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿc([t_{i},t_{i+1}])\subseteq B_{X}(p_{i};r) for every iğ‘–i. The rğ‘Ÿr-homotopy class of a discretization is invariant under refinement under the partition and hence does not depend on the partition chosen. It is not hard to check that (continuous) homotopies of loops based at x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0} give rğ‘Ÿrâ€“homotopic discretizations. Therefore we have a well-defined discretization map

Ï€1â€‹(X)â†’Ï€1â€‹(X;r).â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(X)\to\pi_{1}(X;r).

An (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“coarsely Lipschitz map defines an obvious morphism on coarse fundamental groups

fâˆ—:Ï€1â€‹(X,x0;r)â†’Ï€1â€‹(Y,fâ€‹(x0);Lâ€‹r+C).:subscriptğ‘“âˆ—â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ‹1ğ‘Œğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥0ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶f_{\ast}:\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r)\to\pi_{1}(Y,f(x_{0});Lr+C).

These behave well with respect to composition, namely if f:Xâ†’Y:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘‹ğ‘Œf:X\to Y is (Lf,Cf)subscriptğ¿ğ‘“subscriptğ¶ğ‘“(L_{f},C_{f})â€“coarsely Lipschitz and g:Yâ†’Z:ğ‘”â†’ğ‘Œğ‘g:Y\to Z is (Lg,Cg)subscriptğ¿ğ‘”subscriptğ¶ğ‘”(L_{g},C_{g})â€“coarsely Lipschitz, then gâˆ˜fğ‘”ğ‘“g\circ f is (Lgâ€‹Lf,Lgâ€‹Cf+Cg)subscriptğ¿ğ‘”subscriptğ¿ğ‘“subscriptğ¿ğ‘”subscriptğ¶ğ‘“subscriptğ¶ğ‘”(L_{g}L_{f},L_{g}C_{f}+C_{g})â€“coarsely Lipschitz and (gâˆ˜f)âˆ—=gâˆ—âˆ˜fâˆ—subscriptğ‘”ğ‘“âˆ—subscriptğ‘”âˆ—subscriptğ‘“âˆ—(g\circ f)_{\ast}=g_{\ast}\circ f_{\ast}.

2.3. Technical coarse homotopy lemma

Aside from endpoint appends and deletions, we can perform any coarse homotopy by making only two changes at the time, and these are in consecutive positions:

Lemma 2.7.

Suppose Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta are rğ‘Ÿr-close rğ‘Ÿr-loops based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} of the same length. Then there is an rğ‘Ÿr-homotopy (possibly through curves of longer length) from Î±ğ›¼\alpha to Î²ğ›½\beta such that consecutive paths differ in at most two points, and these are consecutive (we allow endpoint appends and deletions).

Proof.

Write Î±=(p0,â€¦,pâ„“+1)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“1\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell+1}) where p0=pâ„“+1subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘â„“1p_{0}=p_{\ell+1} and likewise write Î²=(p0,q1,â€¦,qâ„“,p0)ğ›½subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘0\beta=(p_{0},q_{1},\dots,q_{\ell},p_{0}). Since Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are rğ‘Ÿr-close, we know dâ€‹(pi,qi)<rğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿd(p_{i},q_{i})<r for all 1â‰¤iâ‰¤l1ğ‘–ğ‘™1\leq i\leq l.

It is easy to see that there is an rğ‘Ÿr-homotopy as desired (i.e. making only local changes) between Î±ğ›¼\alpha and the loop that prepends the point p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to Î±ğ›¼\alpha, i.e. the loop

prependâ€‹(Î±):=(p0,p0,p1,â€¦,pâ„“+1).assignprependğ›¼subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“1\text{prepend}(\alpha):=(p_{0},p_{0},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell+1}).

This is rğ‘Ÿr-close to the loop obtained by replacing the second entry by q1subscriptğ‘1q_{1}, i.e.

Î·1:=(p0,q1,p1,â€¦,pâ„“+1).assignsubscriptğœ‚1subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“1\eta_{1}:=(p_{0},q_{1},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell+1}).

Now we take a homotopy with only local changes to the loop which is exactly the same except repeating the point p2subscriptğ‘2p_{2} twice:

(p0,q1,p1,p2,p2,p3,â€¦,pâ„“+1).subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“1(p_{0},q_{1},p_{1},p_{2},p_{2},p_{3},\dots,p_{\ell+1}).

Now we make a â€˜synchronized jumpâ€™ where we change the third entry from p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1} to q1subscriptğ‘1q_{1} and the fourth entry from p2subscriptğ‘2p_{2} to q2subscriptğ‘2q_{2} and end up with the loop

Î·2:=(p0,q1,q1,q2,p2,p3,â€¦,pâ„“+1).assignsubscriptğœ‚2subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“1\eta_{2}:=(p_{0},q_{1},q_{1},q_{2},p_{2},p_{3},\dots,p_{\ell+1}).

See Figure 1 for the idea.

Now we move the repeated entry of q1subscriptğ‘1q_{1} over so that p3subscriptğ‘3p_{3} is repeated twice, and we do another synchronized jump. We keep doing synchronized jumps until we changed all points pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} to points qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–q_{i}. Finally we move any repeated points so that they are at the end, and after endpoint deletions we obtain Î²ğ›½\beta.âˆ

2.4. Additional notation and terminology

Let Î±=(pi)0â‰¤iâ‰¤nğ›¼subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–0ğ‘–ğ‘›\alpha=(p_{i})_{0\leq i\leq n} be an rğ‘Ÿr-path in a compact metric space Xğ‘‹X. The length â„“â€‹(Î±)â„“ğ›¼\ell(\alpha) of Î±ğ›¼\alpha is defined by

â„“â€‹(Î±):=âˆ‘0â‰¤i<ndâ€‹(pi,pi+1).assignâ„“ğ›¼subscript0ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1\ell(\alpha):=\sum_{0\leq i<n}d(p_{i},p_{i+1}).

We denote by Î±Â¯=(pnâˆ’i)0â‰¤iâ‰¤nÂ¯ğ›¼subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘–0ğ‘–ğ‘›\overline{\alpha}=(p_{n-i})_{0\leq i\leq n} the reverse of Î±ğ›¼\alpha. If Î²=(qi)0â‰¤iâ‰¤mğ›½subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–0ğ‘–ğ‘š\beta=(q_{i})_{0\leq i\leq m} is another rğ‘Ÿr-path in Xğ‘‹X with dâ€‹(pn,q0)â‰¤rğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿd(p_{n},q_{0})\leq r, then

Î±âˆ—Î²:=(p0,â€¦,pn,q0,â€¦,qm)assignâˆ—ğ›¼ğ›½subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘š\alpha\ast\beta:=(p_{0},\dots,p_{n},q_{0},\dots,q_{m})

denotes the concatenation of Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta.

3. Coarse fundamental group of level sets of warped cones

3.1. Statement of result

The goal of this section is to compute the coarse fundamental group of the level set Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t} of ğ’â€‹(Î“â†·M)ğ’â†·Î“M\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} at time tğ‘¡t. A heuristic comes from the analogy between coarse algebraic topology on Mt=(tâ€‹MÃ—Î“)/Î“subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘€Î“Î“M_{t}=(tM\times\Gamma)/\Gamma and (continuous) algebraic topology on E:=(MÃ—X~)/Î“assignğ¸ğ‘€~ğ‘‹Î“E:=(M\times\widetilde{X})/\Gamma, whenever X=X~/Î“ğ‘‹~ğ‘‹Î“X=\widetilde{X}/\Gamma is an aspherical manifold with fundamental group Î“Î“\Gamma. After lifting the Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“action on Mğ‘€M to an action of a group Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} on the universal cover M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M} of Mğ‘€M, we have E=(M~Ã—X~)/Î“~ğ¸~ğ‘€~ğ‘‹~Î“E=(\widetilde{M}\times\widetilde{X})/\widetilde{\Gamma}, so we see that Ï€1â€‹(E)â‰…Î“~subscriptğœ‹1ğ¸~Î“\pi_{1}(E)\cong\widetilde{\Gamma} is the group of lifts of Î“Î“\Gamma to M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M}. We prove the same result holds in the coarse setting:

Proposition 3.1.

Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a finitely presented group acting minimally, isometrically, and freely on a manifold Mğ‘€M. Let Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} be the group of lifts of Î“Î“\Gamma to the universal cover M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M} of Mğ‘€M. Then for every tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1 and p0âˆˆMsubscriptğ‘0ğ‘€p_{0}\in M, we have

Ï€1â€‹(Mt,p0;r)â‰…Î“~.subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ~Î“\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r)\cong\widetilde{\Gamma}.
Remark 3.2.

A computation of coarse fundamental groups of warped cones was independently and simultaneously obtained by Vigolo [Vig2]. Note that the setting there is much more general than the one we consider here, although the final answer is presented in a form that is not adapted to the relationship between Î“,Ï€1â€‹(M)Î“subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\Gamma,\pi_{1}(M) and Ï€1â€‹(M;r)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M;r) that we need at present.

The stabilization of the coarse fundamental group Ï€1â€‹(Mt,p0;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r) as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\infty easily allows for the following computation of the fundamental group of geometric cones. However, the full geometric cone is coarsely contractible (because the manifold has been coned off, at least on the scale rğ‘Ÿr). To counteract this, we introduce a truncated geometric cone: For t0>0subscriptğ‘¡00t_{0}>0, we write ğ’¢t0â€‹(Î“â†·M):=(MÃ—[t0,âˆ)Ã—Î“)/Î“assignsubscriptğ’¢subscriptt0â†·Î“Mğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡0Î“Î“\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}:=(M\times[t_{0},\infty)\times\Gamma)/\Gamma for the geometric cone truncated at level t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0}. It is easy to see the projection ğ’¢t0â€‹(Î“â†·M)â†’Mt0â†’subscriptğ’¢subscriptt0â†·Î“Msubscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡0\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\to M_{t_{0}} is a coarse deformation retract, so we have:

Corollary 3.3.

Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a finitely presented group acting minimally, isometrically, and freely on a manifold Mğ‘€M. Then for t>t0â‰«râ‰«1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0much-greater-thanğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t>t_{0}\gg r\gg 1, the inclusion Mt0â†ªğ’¢t0â€‹(Î“â†·M)â†ªsubscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ’¢subscriptt0â†·Î“MM_{t_{0}}\hookrightarrow\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} induces an isomorphism on coarse fundamental groups at scale rğ‘Ÿr. In particular, we have Ï€1â€‹(ğ’¢t0â€‹(Î“â†·M),[p0,t0];r)â‰…Î“~.subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ’¢subscriptt0â†·Î“Msubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘Ÿ~Î“\pi_{1}(\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)},[p_{0},t_{0}];r)\cong\widetilde{\Gamma}.

We provide a brief outline of the proof of Proposition 3.1: In Section 3.2 we associate to every coarse loop an element of Î³ğ›¾\gamma, based on the observation that given two sufficiently close points x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y in Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t}, there is a unique element of Î“Î“\Gamma that translates xğ‘¥x to a point near yğ‘¦y in Mğ‘€M. In this way we associate to a coarse loop finitely many elements of Î“Î“\Gamma. By taking the product we obtain a map Ï€1â€‹(M,p0;r)â†’Î“â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘ŸÎ“\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r)\to\Gamma. In Section 3.4 we show that discretization of continuous loops gives a map Ï€1â€‹(M,p0)â†’Ï€1â€‹(M,p0;r)â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M,p_{0})\to\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r) that is an embedding for tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1. In Section 3.3, we introduce a technical tool that decomposes an arbitrary coarse path (up to coarse homotopy) into an orbital and spatial segment. Next, in Section 3.5, we use this to study the relationship between the contributions of the action and the manifold to the coarse fundamental group, and show Ï€1â€‹(M,p0;r)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r) is an extension of Î“Î“\Gamma by Ï€1â€‹(M)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\pi_{1}(M). Finally in Section 3.6 we show that this extension is in fact Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma}.

3.2. The contribution of the action

We start by associating an element of Î“Î“\Gamma to every coarse loop in Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t}. For R>0ğ‘…0R>0, set

Î´Î“â€‹(R):=minâ€–Î³â€–â‰¤Râ¡minxâˆˆMâ¡dâ€‹(x,Î³â€‹x).assignsubscriptğ›¿Î“ğ‘…subscriptnormğ›¾ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘€ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘¥\delta_{\Gamma}(R):=\min_{\|\gamma\|\leq R}\,\min_{x\in M}d(x,\gamma x).
Construction 3.4.

Let t>2â€‹rÎ´Î“â€‹(2â€‹r)ğ‘¡2ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ›¿Î“2ğ‘Ÿt>\frac{2r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(2r)}. Let Î±=(p0,p1,â€¦,pâ„“,p0)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘0\alpha=(p_{0},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell},p_{0}) be an rğ‘Ÿr-path based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}. Since

dtÎ“â€‹(pi,pi+1)=infÎ³(â€–Î³â€–+tâ€‹dMâ€‹(Î³â€‹pi,pi+1))<r,superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡Î“subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptinfimumğ›¾normğ›¾ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ›¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿd_{t}^{\Gamma}(p_{i},p_{i+1})=\inf_{\gamma}\left(\|\gamma\|+t\,d_{M}(\gamma p_{i},p_{i+1})\right)<r,

we see there exists some Î³âˆˆBÎ“â€‹(r)ğ›¾subscriptğµÎ“ğ‘Ÿ\gamma\in B_{\Gamma}(r) with dMâ€‹(Î³â€‹pi,pi+1)<rtsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ›¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(\gamma p_{i},p_{i+1})<\frac{r}{t}. Further this element Î³ğ›¾\gamma is unique, because if Î·ğœ‚\eta is another element with this property, then Î³âˆ’1â€‹Î·superscriptğ›¾1ğœ‚\gamma^{-1}\eta is an element of length at most 2â€‹r2ğ‘Ÿ2r that displaces pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} by at most 2â€‹rt2ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\frac{2r}{t}. Since t>2â€‹rÎ´Î“â€‹(2â€‹r)ğ‘¡2ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ›¿Î“2ğ‘Ÿt>\frac{2r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(2r)}, this forces Î³=Î·ğ›¾ğœ‚\gamma=\eta, as desired.

Hence we can associate to the rğ‘Ÿr-path Î±ğ›¼\alpha a sequence of elements Î³iâ€‹(Î±)âˆˆBÎ“â€‹(r)subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ›¼subscriptğµÎ“ğ‘Ÿ\gamma_{i}(\alpha)\in B_{\Gamma}(r) such that dMâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹pi,pi+1)<rtsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i},p_{i+1})<\frac{r}{t} for every iğ‘–i.

Definition 3.5.

Let t>2â€‹rÎ´Î“â€‹(2â€‹r)ğ‘¡2ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ›¿Î“2ğ‘Ÿt>\frac{2r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(2r)}. Write Pâ€‹(M;r)ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘ŸP(M;r) for the space of rğ‘Ÿr-paths. Also write Fâ€‹(BÎ“â€‹(r))ğ¹subscriptğµÎ“ğ‘ŸF(B_{\Gamma}(r)) for the free group on BÎ“â€‹(r)subscriptğµÎ“ğ‘ŸB_{\Gamma}(r). Define

Q~:Pâ€‹(M;r)â†’Fâ€‹(BÎ“â€‹(r)):~ğ‘„â†’ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Ÿğ¹subscriptğµÎ“ğ‘Ÿ\widetilde{Q}:P(M;r)\to F(B_{\Gamma}(r))

by Q~â€‹(Î±):=Î³â„“â€‹(Î±)â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³0â€‹(Î±)assign~ğ‘„ğ›¼subscriptğ›¾â„“ğ›¼â‹¯subscriptğ›¾0ğ›¼\widetilde{Q}(\alpha):=\gamma_{\ell}(\alpha)\cdots\gamma_{0}(\alpha) for Î±=(p0,p1,â€¦,pâ„“)âˆˆPâ€‹(M;r)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Ÿ\alpha=(p_{0},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell})\in P(M;r).

Lemma 3.6.

Let t>4â€‹rÎ´â€‹(4â€‹r)ğ‘¡4ğ‘Ÿğ›¿4ğ‘Ÿt>\frac{4r}{\delta(4r)}. If Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are rğ‘Ÿr-homotopic rğ‘Ÿr-loops based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}, then as elements of Î“Î“\Gamma we have Q~â€‹(Î±)=Q~â€‹(Î²)~ğ‘„ğ›¼~ğ‘„ğ›½\widetilde{Q}(\alpha)=\widetilde{Q}(\beta). Hence Q~~ğ‘„\widetilde{Q} descends to a map

Q:Ï€1â€‹(M,p0;r)â†’Î“.:ğ‘„â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘ŸÎ“Q:\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r)\to\Gamma.

For Î±âˆˆÏ€1â€‹(M,p0;r)ğ›¼subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\alpha\in\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r), we say Qâ€‹(Î±)âˆˆÎ“ğ‘„ğ›¼Î“Q(\alpha)\in\Gamma is the orbital jump along Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

Proof.

Clearly Q~~ğ‘„\widetilde{Q} is invariant under endpoint appends and deletions. Therefore it suffices to show the statement for a pair of rğ‘Ÿr-loops Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} that are rğ‘Ÿr-close and of the same length. By Lemma 2.7, there is an rğ‘Ÿr-homotopy from Î±ğ›¼\alpha to Î²ğ›½\beta of the form

Î±=Î·0,Î·1,â€¦,Î·k=Î²formulae-sequenceğ›¼subscriptğœ‚0subscriptğœ‚1â€¦subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğ›½\alpha=\eta_{0},\,\eta_{1},\,\dots,\,\eta_{k}=\beta

where Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} and Î·i+1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–1\eta_{i+1} differ in at most two positions, and these are consecutive. Therefore it suffices to prove the statement assuming Î²=Î·1ğ›½subscriptğœ‚1\beta=\eta_{1}.

So suppose

Î±=(p0,â€¦,pkâˆ’1,pk,pk+1,pk+2,â€¦,pâ„“)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜2â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{k-1},p_{k},p_{k+1},p_{k+2},\dots,p_{\ell})

and

Î²=(p0,â€¦,pkâˆ’1,qk,qk+1,pk+2,â€¦,pâ„“).ğ›½subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜2â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“\beta=(p_{0},\dots,p_{k-1},q_{k},q_{k+1},p_{k+2},\dots,p_{\ell}).

Let Î³kâˆ’1,Î³k,Î³k+1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1\gamma_{k-1},\gamma_{k},\gamma_{k+1} be defined as before, i.e. these are the unique elements of length at most rğ‘Ÿr such that

dMâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹pi,pi+1)<rt.subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i},p_{i+1})<\frac{r}{t}.

Likewise define Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} associated to the path Î²ğ›½\beta. Since Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta coincide except for the kğ‘˜k and (k+1)ğ‘˜1(k+1)st position, we clearly have Î³i=Î·isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\gamma_{i}=\eta_{i} for |iâˆ’k|>1ğ‘–ğ‘˜1|i-k|>1. Therefore to prove the claim it suffices to show

Î³k+1â€‹Î³kâ€‹Î³kâˆ’1=Î·k+1â€‹Î·kâ€‹Î·kâˆ’1.subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1\gamma_{k+1}\gamma_{k}\gamma_{k-1}=\eta_{k+1}\eta_{k}\eta_{k-1}. (3.1)

Let Î¾ksubscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜\xi_{k} and Î¾k+1subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜1\xi_{k+1} be the unique elements of length at most rğ‘Ÿr such that

dMâ€‹(Î¾iâ€‹qi,pi)<rt.subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(\xi_{i}q_{i},p_{i})<\frac{r}{t}.

See Figure 2 for a schematic depiction of the situation. First observe that

Î³kâˆ’1â€‹Î·kâˆ’1âˆ’1=Î¾kandÎ³k+1âˆ’1â€‹Î·k+1=Î¾k+1.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜11subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜andsuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜11subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜1\gamma_{k-1}\eta_{k-1}^{-1}=\xi_{k}\hskip 28.45274pt\text{and}\hskip 28.45274pt\gamma_{k+1}^{-1}\eta_{k+1}=\xi_{k+1}.

Indeed otherwise one would obtain a nontrivial element of Î“Î“\Gamma of length at most 3r that displaces a point less than 3â€‹rt3ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\frac{3r}{t}, but this is impossible since

t>4â€‹rÎ´Î“â€‹(4â€‹r)>3â€‹rÎ´Î“â€‹(3â€‹r).ğ‘¡4ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ›¿Î“4ğ‘Ÿ3ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ›¿Î“3ğ‘Ÿt>\frac{4r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(4r)}>\frac{3r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(3r)}.

Hence to prove Equation (3.1), it suffices to show Î³kâ€‹Î¾k=Î¾k+1â€‹Î·k.subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\gamma_{k}\xi_{k}=\xi_{k+1}\eta_{k}. Indeed, (Î¾k+1â€‹Î·k)âˆ’1â€‹Î³kâ€‹Î¾ksuperscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜(\xi_{k+1}\eta_{k})^{-1}\gamma_{k}\xi_{k} is an element of length at most 4â€‹r4ğ‘Ÿ4r that displaces qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} by less than 4â€‹rt4ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\frac{4r}{t}. Since t>4â€‹rÎ´Î“â€‹(4â€‹r)ğ‘¡4ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ›¿Î“4ğ‘Ÿt>\frac{4r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(4r)}, we must have (Î¾k+1â€‹Î·k)âˆ’1â€‹Î³kâ€‹Î¾k=esuperscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘’(\xi_{k+1}\eta_{k})^{-1}\gamma_{k}\xi_{k}=e, as desired. âˆ

We make a new definition that will be useful for showing Qğ‘„Q is surjective. For Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma, we define an rğ‘Ÿr-loop based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} that first performs orbital jumps whose product in Î“Î“\Gamma is Î³ğ›¾\gamma, and then follows a discretization of a continuous path in Mğ‘€M from Î³â€‹p0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\gamma p_{0} to p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}.

Definition 3.7.

For each Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma, make a choice of writing Î³=sikâ€‹â‹¯â€‹si1ğ›¾subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜â‹¯subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘–1\gamma=s_{i_{k}}\cdots s_{i_{1}} as a product of generators, and a choice of path cÎ³subscriptğ‘ğ›¾c_{\gamma} from Î³â€‹p0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\gamma p_{0} to p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}. Further choose a discretization (q0,q1,â€¦,qâ„“)subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“(q_{0},q_{1},\dots,q_{\ell}) on the scale rtğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\frac{r}{t} of cÎ³subscriptğ‘ğ›¾c_{\gamma}, and such that q0=Î³â€‹p0subscriptğ‘0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0q_{0}=\gamma p_{0} and qâ„“=p0subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘0q_{\ell}=p_{0}. Define È·~Î“:Î“â†’Î©â€‹(M,p0;r):subscript~italic-È·Î“â†’Î“Î©ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}:\Gamma\to\Omega(M,p_{0};r) by È·~â€‹(Î³)â€‹(0):=p0assign~italic-È·ğ›¾0subscriptğ‘0\widetilde{\jmath}(\gamma)(0):=p_{0} and

È·~â€‹(Î³)â€‹(j):=(âˆ1â‰¤lâ‰¤jsil)â€‹p0assign~italic-È·ğ›¾ğ‘—subscriptproduct1ğ‘™ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘–ğ‘™subscriptğ‘0\widetilde{\jmath}(\gamma)(j):=\left(\prod_{1\leq l\leq j}s_{i_{l}}\right)p_{0}

if 1â‰¤lâ‰¤k1ğ‘™ğ‘˜1\leq l\leq k, and È·~â€‹(Î³)â€‹(k+j)=qj~italic-È·ğ›¾ğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\widetilde{\jmath}(\gamma)(k+j)=q_{j} if k<jâ‰¤k+â„“ğ‘˜ğ‘—ğ‘˜â„“k<j\leq k+\ell. Write È·Î“:Î“â†’Ï€1â€‹(M,p0;r):subscriptitalic-È·Î“â†’Î“subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\jmath_{\Gamma}:\Gamma\to\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r) for the map that assigns the coarse homotopy class.

Warning 3.8.

È·Î“subscriptitalic-È·Î“\jmath_{\Gamma} need not be a homomorphism.

Lemma 3.9.

Qâˆ˜È·Î“=idÎ“ğ‘„subscriptitalic-È·Î“subscriptidÎ“Q\circ\jmath_{\Gamma}=\text{id}_{\Gamma}. Hence È·Î“subscriptitalic-È·Î“\jmath_{\Gamma} is injective and Qğ‘„Q is surjective.

Proof.

This is a straightforward verification.âˆ

3.3. Canonical forms for coarse paths

We briefly interrupt the computation of the coarse fundamental group to discuss a useful tool for the rest of the computation. Namely, we can reorder the jumps in an rğ‘Ÿr-path so that all the orbital jumps occur at the start, and all the spatial ones at the end.

Definition 3.10.

Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be an rğ‘Ÿr-path. Define the orbital component of Î±ğ›¼\alpha

ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±):=(p0,Î³0â€‹p0,Î³1â€‹Î³0â€‹p0,â€¦,Qâ€‹(Î±)â€‹p0)assignğ’ªğ›¼subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ›¾0subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ›¾1subscriptğ›¾0subscriptğ‘0â€¦ğ‘„ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0\mathcal{O}(\alpha):=(p_{0},\gamma_{0}p_{0},\gamma_{1}\gamma_{0}p_{0},\dots,Q(\alpha)p_{0})

and the spatial component

ğ’®â€‹(Î±):=(Qâ€‹(Î±)â€‹p0,Î³â„“â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³1â€‹p1,â€¦,pâ„“)assignğ’®ğ›¼ğ‘„ğ›¼subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ›¾â„“â‹¯subscriptğ›¾1subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“\mathcal{S}(\alpha):=(Q(\alpha)p_{0},\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{1}p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell})

of Î±ğ›¼\alpha. The canonical form of Î±ğ›¼\alpha is ğ’â€‹(Î±):=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±)âˆ—ğ’®â€‹(Î±)assignğ’ğ›¼âˆ—ğ’ªğ›¼ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{C}(\alpha):=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\mathcal{S}(\alpha).

The relevance for the present computation of coarse fundamental groups is that this operation does not change the coarse homotopy class.

Lemma 3.11.

Let tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1. Then any rğ‘Ÿr-path Î±ğ›¼\alpha is rğ‘Ÿr-homotopic rel endpoints to its canonical form ğ’â€‹(Î±)ğ’ğ›¼\mathcal{C}(\alpha).

Proof.

This is straightforward. For the idea to to construct the homotopy from Î±ğ›¼\alpha to ğ’â€‹(Î±)ğ’ğ›¼\mathcal{C}(\alpha), see Figure 3.

âˆ

For later use, we record the following elementary property of canonical forms:

Lemma 3.12.

Let tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1. Then an rğ‘Ÿr-path and its canonical form have the same length.

Proof.

Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be an rğ‘Ÿr-path. We keep the notation of Definition 3.10. Note that for each iğ‘–i, we have

dtÎ“â€‹(pi,pi+1)=â€–Î³iâ€–+tâ€‹dMâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹pi,Î³i+1),superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡Î“subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1normsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–1d_{t}^{\Gamma}(p_{i},p_{i+1})=\|\gamma_{i}\|+t\,d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i}\,,\gamma_{i+1}),

so

â„“â€‹(Î±)=âˆ‘i(â€–Î³iâ€–+tâ€‹dMâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹pi,Î³i+1)).â„“ğ›¼subscriptğ‘–normsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–1\ell(\alpha)=\sum_{i}(\|\gamma_{i}\|+t\,d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i}\,,\gamma_{i+1})).

On the other hand, it is easy to see that â„“â€‹(ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±))=âˆ‘iâ€–Î³iâ€–â„“ğ’ªğ›¼subscriptğ‘–normsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\ell(\mathcal{O}(\alpha))=\sum_{i}\|\gamma_{i}\| and â„“â€‹(ğ’®â€‹(Î±))=âˆ‘itâ€‹dMâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹pi,pi+1).â„“ğ’®ğ›¼subscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1\ell(\mathcal{S}(\alpha))=\sum_{i}t\,d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i}\,,p_{i+1}). âˆ

It is easy to verify the following cocycle-type behavior of canonical forms with respect to concatenation:

Lemma 3.13.

Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta be rğ‘Ÿr-paths such that the endpoint of Î±ğ›¼\alpha is distance at most rğ‘Ÿr from the starting point of Î²ğ›½\beta. Then

ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±âˆ—Î²)=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±)âˆ—ğ’ªâ€‹(Î²)ğ’ªâˆ—ğ›¼ğ›½âˆ—ğ’ªğ›¼ğ’ªğ›½\mathcal{O}(\alpha\ast\beta)=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\mathcal{O}(\beta)

and

ğ’®â€‹(Î±âˆ—Î²)=(Qâ€‹(Î²)â€‹ğ’®â€‹(Î±))âˆ—ğ’®â€‹(Î²).ğ’®âˆ—ğ›¼ğ›½âˆ—ğ‘„ğ›½ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\alpha\ast\beta)=(Q(\beta)\,\mathcal{S}(\alpha))\ast\mathcal{S}(\beta).

3.4. The contribution of the manifold

We will now work to explain the relationship between Ï€1â€‹(M)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\pi_{1}(M) and Ï€1â€‹(M;r)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M;r). Consider the natural discretization map

È·M:Ï€1â€‹(M)â†ªÏ€1â€‹(Mt;r).:subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€â†ªsubscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\jmath_{M}:\pi_{1}(M)\hookrightarrow\pi_{1}(M_{t};r).

See Section 2.2 for the definition. We aim to show this is an embedding whose image is a normal subgroup.

Lemma 3.14.

For tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, the map È·Msubscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€\jmath_{M} is injective.

Proof.

Let câˆˆÏ€1â€‹(M)ğ‘subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€c\in\pi_{1}(M) be a nontrivial (continuous) homotopy class of loops. Let Î¸ğœƒ\theta be a discretization on the scale rtğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\frac{r}{t} of an element of cğ‘c. Suppose Î¸ğœƒ\theta were rğ‘Ÿrâ€“nullhomotopic. By Lemma 2.7, we can choose an rğ‘Ÿrâ€“nullhomotopy of Î¸ğœƒ\theta such that any two consecutive curves in the homotopy differ in at most two positions, and these are consecutive. Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta be any two consecutive curves in the nullhomotopy. We claim that ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) and ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta) are 4â€‹rt4ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\frac{4r}{t}â€“close as coarse paths in Mğ‘€M.

To see this, retain the notation of the proof of Lemma 3.12 (see Figure 2). Note that since Qâ€‹(Î¸)=eğ‘„ğœƒğ‘’Q(\theta)=e, and hence also Qâ€‹(Î±)=Qâ€‹(Î²)=eğ‘„ğ›¼ğ‘„ğ›½ğ‘’Q(\alpha)=Q(\beta)=e, we know that ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) and ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta) start at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}. Now we have

ğ’®â€‹(Î±)=(Î³â„“â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³0â€‹p0,Î³â„“â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³1â€‹p1,Î³â„“â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³2â€‹p2,â€¦,Î³â„“â€‹pâ„“)ğ’®ğ›¼subscriptğ›¾â„“â‹¯subscriptğ›¾0subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ›¾â„“â‹¯subscriptğ›¾1subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ›¾â„“â‹¯subscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ‘2â€¦subscriptğ›¾â„“subscriptğ‘â„“\mathcal{S}(\alpha)=(\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{0}p_{0},\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{1}p_{1},\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{2}p_{2},\dots,\gamma_{\ell}p_{\ell})

and similarly for ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta). Now since Î·j=Î³jsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—\eta_{j}=\gamma_{j} whenever |jâˆ’k|>1ğ‘—ğ‘˜1|j-k|>1, we see that ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) and ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta) agree for the last â„“âˆ’(k+1)â„“ğ‘˜1\ell-(k+1) terms. Further we have Î³k+1â€‹Î³kâ€‹Î³kâˆ’1=Î·k+1â€‹Î·kâ€‹Î·kâˆ’1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1\gamma_{k+1}\gamma_{k}\gamma_{k-1}=\eta_{k+1}\eta_{k}\eta_{k-1} (see Equation (3.1)), so ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) and ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta) also agree for the first kğ‘˜k terms. To finish the proof, we will show

dMâ€‹(Î³â„“â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³k+2â€‹Î³k+1â€‹pk+1,Î³â„“â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³k+2â€‹Î·k+1â€‹qk+1)<2â€‹rtsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾â„“â‹¯subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ›¾â„“â‹¯subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜12ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{k+2}\gamma_{k+1}p_{k+1}\,,\,\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{k+2}\eta_{k+1}q_{k+1})<\frac{2r}{t}

and

dMâ€‹(Î³â„“â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³k+2â€‹Î³k+1â€‹Î³kâ€‹pk,Î³â„“â€‹â‹¯â€‹Î³k+2â€‹Î·k+1â€‹Î·kâ€‹qk)<4â€‹rt.subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾â„“â‹¯subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¾â„“â‹¯subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜4ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{k+2}\gamma_{k+1}\gamma_{k}p_{k}\,,\,\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{k+2}\eta_{k+1}\eta_{k}q_{k})<\frac{4r}{t}.

The first inequality is equivalent to proving

dMâ€‹(Î³k+1â€‹pk+1,Î·k+1â€‹qk+1)<2â€‹rt,subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜12ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(\gamma_{k+1}p_{k+1}\,,\,\eta_{k+1}q_{k+1})<\frac{2r}{t},

which is true because both are distance at most rtğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\frac{r}{t} from pk+2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜2p_{k+2}. The second is equivalent to proving

dMâ€‹(Î³k+1â€‹Î³kâ€‹pk,Î·k+1â€‹Î·kâ€‹qk)<4â€‹rt,subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜4ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(\gamma_{k+1}\gamma_{k}p_{k}\,,\,\eta_{k+1}\eta_{k}q_{k})<\frac{4r}{t},

which is true because both are distance at most 2â€‹rt2ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\frac{2r}{t} from pk+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1p_{k+1}.

By connecting the points in ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) (resp. ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta)) by minimizing geodesic segments, we obtain a continuous loop cÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼c_{\alpha} (resp. cÎ²subscriptğ‘ğ›½c_{\beta}) in Mğ‘€M. Since cÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼c_{\alpha} and cÎ²subscriptğ‘ğ›½c_{\beta} are uniformly close, we see that for tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, they are homotopic rel p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}.

It follows that for any coarse loop Î±ğ›¼\alpha in the nullhomotopy of Î¸ğœƒ\theta, we have that ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) is in the image under È·Msubscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€\jmath_{M} of the original loop [c]delimited-[]ğ‘[c]. In particular, the length of ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) is uniformly bounded below. This contradicts the fact that we have a coarse nullhomotopy of Î¸ğœƒ\theta.âˆ

3.5. Relationship between the two contributions

Let us now return to the computation of the coarse fundamental group.

Lemma 3.15.

È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) and È·Î“â€‹(Î“)subscriptitalic-È·Î“Î“\jmath_{\Gamma}(\Gamma) generate Ï€1â€‹(Mt,p0;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r) and have trivial intersection.

Proof.

Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be an rğ‘Ÿrâ€“loop based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}. By Lemma 3.11, Î±ğ›¼\alpha is rğ‘Ÿr-homotopic rel endpoints to its canonical form ğ’â€‹(Î±)=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±)âˆ—ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’ğ›¼âˆ—ğ’ªğ›¼ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{C}(\alpha)=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\,\mathcal{S}(\alpha). Consider È·~Î“â€‹(Qâ€‹(Î±)âˆ’1)âˆ—ğ’â€‹(Î±)âˆ—subscript~italic-È·Î“ğ‘„superscriptğ›¼1ğ’ğ›¼\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)^{-1})\ast\mathcal{C}(\alpha). Note that È·~Î“â€‹(Qâ€‹(Î±)âˆ’1)subscript~italic-È·Î“ğ‘„superscriptğ›¼1\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)^{-1}) ends in a sequence of orbital jumps ğ’ªâ€‹(È·~Î“â€‹(Qâ€‹(Î±)âˆ’1))ğ’ªsubscript~italic-È·Î“ğ‘„superscriptğ›¼1\mathcal{O}(\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)^{-1})) whose product in Î“Î“\Gamma is Qâ€‹(Î±)âˆ’1ğ‘„superscriptğ›¼1Q(\alpha)^{-1} and hence

ğ’ªâ€‹(È·~Î“â€‹(Qâ€‹(Î±)))âˆ—ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±)âˆ—ğ’ªsubscript~italic-È·Î“ğ‘„ğ›¼ğ’ªğ›¼\mathcal{O}(\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)))\ast\mathcal{O}(\alpha)

is a sequence of orbital jumps by products of conjugates of relators. Since rğ‘Ÿr is larger than the length of any relator, we can cancel these out and hence È·~Î“â€‹(Qâ€‹(Î±)âˆ’1)âˆ—ğ’â€‹(Î±)âˆ—subscript~italic-È·Î“ğ‘„superscriptğ›¼1ğ’ğ›¼\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)^{-1})\ast\mathcal{C}(\alpha) is rğ‘Ÿr-homotopic to a spatial loop, i.e. is in the image of È·Msubscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€\jmath_{M}.

Finally, we show È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) and È·Î“â€‹(Î“)subscriptitalic-È·Î“Î“\jmath_{\Gamma}(\Gamma) intersect trivially. Indeed, we clearly have Qâˆ˜È·M=1ğ‘„subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€1Q\circ\jmath_{M}=1. On the other hand, if Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma is nontrivial, then Qâ€‹(È·Î“â€‹(Î³))=Î³ğ‘„subscriptitalic-È·Î“ğ›¾ğ›¾Q(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma))=\gamma, so È·Î“â€‹(Î³)âˆ‰È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))subscriptitalic-È·Î“ğ›¾subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma)\notin\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)). âˆ

Lemma 3.16.

È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) is normal in Ï€1â€‹(M,p0;r)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r).

Proof.

We claim that È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))=kerâ¡(Q)subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€kernelğ‘„\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M))=\ker(Q), which will suffice to show È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) is normal. Indeed, it is clear that È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))âŠ†kerâ¡(Q)subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€kernelğ‘„\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M))\subseteq\ker(Q). To show the other direction, suppose Î±ğ›¼\alpha is an rğ‘Ÿr-loop based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} with [Î±]âˆˆkerâ¡(Q)delimited-[]ğ›¼kernelğ‘„[\alpha]\in\ker(Q). Let Î±~~ğ›¼\widetilde{\alpha} be the canonical representative, where the initial sequence of jumps is

Î³0,Î³1,â€¦,Î³â„“subscriptğ›¾0subscriptğ›¾1â€¦subscriptğ›¾â„“\gamma_{0},\gamma_{1},\dots,\gamma_{\ell}

and Î³iâˆˆSsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘†\gamma_{i}\in S, the generators for Î“Î“\Gamma, and after that Î±~â€‹(i)=pi~ğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\widetilde{\alpha}(i)=p_{i}, so dMâ€‹(pi,pi+1)<rtsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡d_{M}(p_{i},p_{i+1})<\frac{r}{t}. We know that Qâ€‹(Î±)=âˆiÎ³iğ‘„ğ›¼subscriptproductğ‘–subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–Q(\alpha)=\prod_{i}\gamma_{i} is trivial, so as a word in Fâ€‹(S)ğ¹ğ‘†F(S), we have that âˆiÎ³isubscriptproductğ‘–subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\prod_{i}\gamma_{i} is a product of conjugates of relators. Since rğ‘Ÿr is larger than the maximal size of a relator, and r>2ğ‘Ÿ2r>2 (so that for any generator sğ‘ s, a jump sequence of the form sâ€‹sâˆ’1ğ‘ superscriptğ‘ 1ss^{-1} can be canceled), we see that Î±~~ğ›¼\widetilde{\alpha} is rğ‘Ÿr-homotopic to the loop that omits the initial sequence of jumps and then performs the rest of Î±~~ğ›¼\widetilde{\alpha}, i.e. ğ’®â€‹(Î±~)ğ’®~ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\widetilde{\alpha}). This loop is in È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)), as desired. âˆ

3.6. End of the proof

At this point we know that for tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, the group Ï€1â€‹(Mt,p0;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r) is an extension

1â†’Ï€1â€‹(M,p0)â€‹âŸ¶È·Mâ€‹Ï€1â€‹(Mt,p0;r)â€‹âŸ¶ğ‘„â€‹Î“â†’1.â†’1subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€âŸ¶subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿğ‘„âŸ¶Î“â†’11\to\pi_{1}(M,p_{0})\overset{\jmath_{M}}{\longrightarrow}\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r)\overset{Q}{\longrightarrow}\Gamma\to 1. (3.2)

Further the action of Î“Î“\Gamma by conjugation on Ï€1â€‹(M,p0)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0\pi_{1}(M,p_{0}) is induced from Î“â†·Mâ†·Î“ğ‘€\Gamma\curvearrowright M. We want to show Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) is given by the group of lifts Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} of Î“Î“\Gamma to the universal cover M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M} of Mğ‘€M. Note that Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} is also an extension

1â†’Ï€1â€‹(M)â€‹âŸ¶ğœ„â€‹Î“~â€‹âŸ¶ğœ‹â€‹Î“â†’1,â†’1subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€ğœ„âŸ¶~Î“ğœ‹âŸ¶Î“â†’11\to\pi_{1}(M)\overset{\iota}{\longrightarrow}\widetilde{\Gamma}\overset{\pi}{\longrightarrow}\Gamma\to 1, (3.3)

with the action of Î“Î“\Gamma on Ï€1â€‹(M)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\pi_{1}(M) by conjugation induced from Î“Î“\Gamma acting on Mğ‘€M. We will need the following straightforward fact:

Lemma 3.17.

The action of Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} on M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M} is free.

Proof.
