This is immediate from the fact that Î“Î“\Gamma acts freely on Mğ‘€M, and Ï€1â€‹(M)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\pi_{1}(M) acts freely on M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M}. Indeed, suppose Î³~âˆˆÎ“~~ğ›¾~Î“\widetilde{\gamma}\in\widetilde{\Gamma} fixes p~âˆˆM~~ğ‘~ğ‘€\widetilde{p}\in\widetilde{M}. Let Î³=Ï€â€‹(Î³~)ğ›¾ğœ‹~ğ›¾\gamma=\pi(\widetilde{\gamma}) be the image of Î³~~ğ›¾\widetilde{\gamma} in Î“Î“\Gamma and let pğ‘p be the image of p~~ğ‘\widetilde{p} in Mğ‘€M. Then Î³ğ›¾\gamma fixes pğ‘p. Since Î“Î“\Gamma acts freely, it follows Î³=eğ›¾ğ‘’\gamma=e, and hence Î³~âˆˆÏ€1â€‹(M)~ğ›¾subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\widetilde{\gamma}\in\pi_{1}(M). But Ï€1â€‹(M)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\pi_{1}(M) acts freely on M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M}, so Î³~=e~ğ›¾ğ‘’\widetilde{\gamma}=e.âˆ

Construction 3.18.

Fix a basepoint p~0âˆˆM~subscript~ğ‘0~ğ‘€\widetilde{p}_{0}\in\widetilde{M} that maps to p0âˆˆMsubscriptğ‘0ğ‘€p_{0}\in M. We define a map

Î˜:Ï€1â€‹(M,p0;r)â†’Î“~:Î˜â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ~Î“\Theta:\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r)\to\widetilde{\Gamma}

as follows. Let Î±âˆˆÏ€1â€‹(M,p0;r)ğ›¼subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\alpha\in\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r). We assume Î±=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±)âˆ—ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ›¼âˆ—ğ’ªğ›¼ğ’®ğ›¼\alpha=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\mathcal{S}(\alpha) is in canonical form and write Î³:=Qâ€‹(Î±)assignğ›¾ğ‘„ğ›¼\gamma:=Q(\alpha). Write cğ‘c for the piecewise geodesic path in Mğ‘€M from p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to Î³â€‹p0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\gamma p_{0} obtained by connecting the points in the spatial path ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) by minimizing geodesic segments (observe that since rt<injradâ€‹(M)ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡injradğ‘€\frac{r}{t}<\text{injrad}(M), we can do this in a unique way). Now lift cğ‘c to a path c~~ğ‘\widetilde{c} in the universal cover M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M} that starts at p~0subscript~ğ‘0\widetilde{p}_{0}. Note that c~â€‹(1)~ğ‘1\widetilde{c}(1) maps to câ€‹(1)=Î³â€‹p0âˆˆMğ‘1ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0ğ‘€c(1)=\gamma p_{0}\in M. Hence there exists an element Î³~âˆˆÎ“~~ğ›¾~Î“\widetilde{\gamma}\in\widetilde{\Gamma} with Î³~â€‹p~0=c~â€‹(1)~ğ›¾subscript~ğ‘0~ğ‘1\widetilde{\gamma}\widetilde{p}_{0}=\widetilde{c}(1). Since Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} acts freely on M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M} (by the previous claim), Î³~~ğ›¾\widetilde{\gamma} is unique. Define

Î˜â€‹(Î±):=Î³~.assignÎ˜ğ›¼~ğ›¾\Theta(\alpha):=\widetilde{\gamma}.

Recall that Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} is an extension

1â†’Ï€1â€‹(M)â€‹âŸ¶ğœ„â€‹Î“~â€‹âŸ¶ğœ‹â€‹Î“â†’1.â†’1subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€ğœ„âŸ¶~Î“ğœ‹âŸ¶Î“â†’11\to\pi_{1}(M)\overset{\iota}{\longrightarrow}\widetilde{\Gamma}\overset{\pi}{\longrightarrow}\Gamma\to 1. (3.4)
Lemma 3.19.

Ï€âˆ˜Î˜=Qğœ‹Î˜ğ‘„\pi\circ\Theta=Q and Î˜âˆ˜È·M=Î¹Î˜subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€ğœ„\Theta\circ\jmath_{M}=\iota.

Proof.

Retain the notation of Construction 3.18. For the first claim: Since Î“Î“\Gamma acts freely, it suffices to show that the image of Î˜â€‹(Î±)â€‹p~0Î˜ğ›¼subscript~ğ‘0\Theta(\alpha)\widetilde{p}_{0} in Mğ‘€M is exactly Î³â€‹p0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\gamma p_{0}. But Î˜â€‹(Î±)â€‹p~0=c~â€‹(1)Î˜ğ›¼subscript~ğ‘0~ğ‘1\Theta(\alpha)\widetilde{p}_{0}=\widetilde{c}(1) projects to câ€‹(1)=Î³â€‹p0ğ‘1ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0c(1)=\gamma p_{0} in Mğ‘€M, as desired.

The second claim is clear because a lift of câˆˆÏ€1â€‹(M,p0)ğ‘subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0c\in\pi_{1}(M,p_{0}) starting at p~0subscript~ğ‘0\widetilde{p}_{0} has endpoint given by Î¹â€‹(c)â€‹p~0ğœ„ğ‘subscript~ğ‘0\iota(c)\widetilde{p}_{0}.âˆ

Lemma 3.20.

Î˜Î˜\Theta is an antihomomorphism.

Proof.

Let Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta be rğ‘Ÿrâ€“loops based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} and assume they are in canonical form. Recall from Lemma 3.13 that ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±âˆ—Î²)=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±)âˆ—ğ’ªâ€‹(Î²)ğ’ªâˆ—ğ›¼ğ›½âˆ—ğ’ªğ›¼ğ’ªğ›½\mathcal{O}(\alpha\ast\beta)=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\mathcal{O}(\beta) and ğ’®â€‹(Î±âˆ—Î²)=(Qâ€‹(Î²)â€‹ğ’®â€‹(Î±))âˆ—ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®âˆ—ğ›¼ğ›½âˆ—ğ‘„ğ›½ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\alpha\ast\beta)=(Q(\beta)\,\mathcal{S}(\alpha))\ast\mathcal{S}(\beta). Let cÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼c_{\alpha} (resp. cÎ²subscriptğ‘ğ›½c_{\beta}) be the (continuous) path in Mğ‘€M obtained by connecting the points of ğ’®â€‹(Î±)ğ’®ğ›¼\mathcal{S}(\alpha) (resp. ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta)) by minimizing geodesic segments.

The lift of the path Î³Î²â€‹cÎ±âˆ—cÎ²âˆ—subscriptğ›¾ğ›½subscriptğ‘ğ›¼subscriptğ‘ğ›½\gamma_{\beta}\,c_{\alpha}\ast c_{\beta} to M~~ğ‘€\widetilde{M} that starts at p~0subscript~ğ‘0\widetilde{p}_{0} starts with c~Î²subscript~ğ‘ğ›½\widetilde{c}_{\beta}, and then takes the lift of Î³Î²â€‹cÎ±subscriptğ›¾ğ›½subscriptğ‘ğ›¼\gamma_{\beta}\,c_{\alpha} that starts at c~Î²â€‹(1):=Î˜â€‹(Î²)â€‹p~0assignsubscript~ğ‘ğ›½1Î˜ğ›½subscript~ğ‘0\widetilde{c}_{\beta}(1):=\Theta(\beta)\,\widetilde{p}_{0}. Therefore the lift of Î³Î²â€‹cÎ±subscriptğ›¾ğ›½subscriptğ‘ğ›¼\gamma_{\beta}\,c_{\alpha} that is taken is Î˜â€‹(Î²)â€‹c~Î±Î˜ğ›½subscript~ğ‘ğ›¼\Theta(\beta)\,\widetilde{c}_{\alpha}. The endpoint is therefore Î˜â€‹(Î²)â€‹c~Î±â€‹(1)=Î˜â€‹(Î²)â€‹Î˜â€‹(Î±)â€‹p~0Î˜ğ›½subscript~ğ‘ğ›¼1Î˜ğ›½Î˜ğ›¼subscript~ğ‘0\Theta(\beta)\,\widetilde{c}_{\alpha}(1)=\Theta(\beta)\,\Theta(\alpha)\widetilde{p}_{0}. Hence we see Î˜â€‹(Î±â€‹Î²)=Î˜â€‹(Î²)â€‹Î˜â€‹(Î±)Î˜ğ›¼ğ›½Î˜ğ›½Î˜ğ›¼\Theta(\alpha\beta)=\Theta(\beta)\,\Theta(\alpha). âˆ

Finally we are able to prove that Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)â‰…Î“~subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ~Î“\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\cong\widetilde{\Gamma}, thereby finishing the proof of Proposition 3.1.

Lemma 3.21.

Î˜Î˜\Theta is an anti-isomorphism.

Proof.

We first show Î˜Î˜\Theta is injective. Let Î±âˆˆkerâ¡(Î˜)ğ›¼kernelÎ˜\alpha\in\ker(\Theta). Since Î˜â€‹(Î±)Î˜ğ›¼\Theta(\alpha) lifts Qâ€‹(Î±)ğ‘„ğ›¼Q(\alpha) and Î˜â€‹(Î±)=eÎ˜ğ›¼ğ‘’\Theta(\alpha)=e, we see Î³=eğ›¾ğ‘’\gamma=e, so Î±âˆˆÈ·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))ğ›¼subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\alpha\in\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)). But by Claim 3.19, we have Î˜âˆ˜È·M=Î¹Î˜subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€ğœ„\Theta\circ\jmath_{M}=\iota, and Î¹ğœ„\iota is injective. It follows that kerâ¡Î˜âˆ©È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))=1kernelÎ˜subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€1\ker\Theta\cap\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M))=1. This proves Î˜Î˜\Theta is injective.

Finally we show Î˜Î˜\Theta is surjective. Let Î³~âˆˆÎ“~~ğ›¾~Î“\widetilde{\gamma}\in\widetilde{\Gamma}, and write Î³=Ï€â€‹(Î³~)ğ›¾ğœ‹~ğ›¾\gamma=\pi(\widetilde{\gamma}) for the image of Î³~~ğ›¾\widetilde{\gamma} in Î“Î“\Gamma. Note that Î˜â€‹(È·Î“â€‹(Î³))Î˜subscriptitalic-È·Î“ğ›¾\Theta(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma)) is characterized by the property that Î˜â€‹(È·Î“â€‹(Î³))â€‹p~0=c~Î³â€‹(1)Î˜subscriptitalic-È·Î“ğ›¾subscript~ğ‘0subscript~ğ‘ğ›¾1\Theta(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma))\widetilde{p}_{0}=\widetilde{c}_{\gamma}(1), where cÎ³subscriptğ‘ğ›¾c_{\gamma} is the arbitrary choice of continuous path from p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to Î³â€‹p0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\gamma p_{0} made in the definition of È·italic-È·\jmath, see Definition 3.7. Since c~Î³â€‹(1)subscript~ğ‘ğ›¾1\widetilde{c}_{\gamma}(1) and Î³~â€‹p~0~ğ›¾subscript~ğ‘0\widetilde{\gamma}\widetilde{p}_{0} both project to Î³â€‹p0âˆˆMğ›¾subscriptğ‘0ğ‘€\gamma p_{0}\in M, there is Î·âˆˆÏ€1â€‹(M,p0)ğœ‚subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0\eta\in\pi_{1}(M,p_{0}) such that Î¹â€‹(Î·)â€‹c~Î³â€‹(1)=Î³~â€‹p~0ğœ„ğœ‚subscript~ğ‘ğ›¾1~ğ›¾subscript~ğ‘0\iota(\eta)\widetilde{c}_{\gamma}(1)=\widetilde{\gamma}\widetilde{p}_{0}. Hence we have

Î·â€‹Î˜â€‹(È·Î“â€‹(Î³))=Î³~.ğœ‚Î˜subscriptitalic-È·Î“ğ›¾~ğ›¾\eta\,\Theta(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma))=\widetilde{\gamma}.

On the other hand Î¹â€‹(Î·)=Î˜â€‹(È·Mâ€‹(Î·))ğœ„ğœ‚Î˜subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€ğœ‚\iota(\eta)=\Theta(\jmath_{M}(\eta)) by Lemma 3.19. Hence we see

Î˜â€‹(È·Mâ€‹(Î·))â€‹Î˜â€‹(È·Î“â€‹(Î³))=Î³~,Î˜subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€ğœ‚Î˜subscriptitalic-È·Î“ğ›¾~ğ›¾\Theta(\jmath_{M}(\eta))\,\Theta(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma))=\widetilde{\gamma},

so Î˜Î˜\Theta is surjective.âˆ

3.7. Coarse homotopical behavior of quasi-isometries

The stabilization of Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) to Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} as rğ‘Ÿr is fixed and tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\infty immediately implies that the change-of-scale map becomes an isomorphism. More precisely, let us decorate the isomorphism Î˜Î˜\Theta defined above with the scale rğ‘Ÿr, so that Î˜r:Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)â†’Î“~:subscriptÎ˜ğ‘Ÿâ†’subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ~Î“\Theta_{r}:\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\widetilde{\Gamma} is the above isomorphism, and let Î¼r,râ€²subscriptğœ‡ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mu_{r,r^{\prime}} be change-of-scale from rğ‘Ÿr to râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime}. Then whenever tâ‰«râ€²>râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r^{\prime}>r\gg 1, we have Î˜râ€²âˆ˜Î¼r,râ€²=Î˜r.subscriptÎ˜superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²subscriptğœ‡ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²subscriptÎ˜ğ‘Ÿ\Theta_{r^{\prime}}\circ\mu_{r,r^{\prime}}=\Theta_{r}. In particular Î¼r,râ€²subscriptğœ‡ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mu_{r,r^{\prime}} is an isomorphism. This has the following interesting consequence for the behavior of quasi-isometries of level sets of warped cones.

Lemma 3.22.

Fix Lâ‰¥1ğ¿1L\geq 1 and Câ‰¥0ğ¶0C\geq 0. For s,tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1s,t\gg r\gg 1, any (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“quasi-isometry f:Mtâ†’Ns:ğ‘“â†’subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘ f:M_{t}\to N_{s} induces an isomorphism Î¦:Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)â†’Ï€1â€‹(Ns;Lâ€‹r+C):Î¦â†’subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶\Phi:\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\pi_{1}(N_{s};Lr+C) on coarse fundamental groups.

Proof.

Write g:Nsâ†’Mt:ğ‘”â†’subscriptğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡g:N_{s}\to M_{t} for the coarse inverse of fğ‘“f, so gğ‘”g is also an (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“quasi-isometry and fâˆ˜gğ‘“ğ‘”f\circ g and gâˆ˜fğ‘”ğ‘“g\circ f displace points by at most Cğ¶C. Then

gâˆ—â€‹fâˆ—=(gâˆ˜f)âˆ—:Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)â†’Ï€1â€‹(Mt;L2â€‹r+Lâ€‹C+C):subscriptğ‘”âˆ—subscriptğ‘“âˆ—subscriptğ‘”ğ‘“âˆ—â†’subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡superscriptğ¿2ğ‘Ÿğ¿ğ¶ğ¶g_{\ast}f_{\ast}=(g\circ f)_{\ast}:\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\pi_{1}(M_{t};L^{2}r+LC+C)

is given by change-of-scale (because gâˆ˜fğ‘”ğ‘“g\circ f displaces points at most Cğ¶C and the scale in the target is at least Cğ¶C), and hence gâˆ—â€‹fâˆ—subscriptğ‘”âˆ—subscriptğ‘“âˆ—g_{\ast}f_{\ast} is an isomorphism. Likewise fâˆ—â€‹gâˆ—subscriptğ‘“âˆ—subscriptğ‘”âˆ—f_{\ast}g_{\ast} is an isomorphism, so fâˆ—subscriptğ‘“âˆ—f_{\ast} is an isomorphism. âˆ

4. Coarse homotopy invariance of group contributions

4.1. Setup

For the rest of this section, let Î“Î“\Gamma (resp. Î›Î›\Lambda) be a finitely presented group acting minimally, isometrically, and freely on a closed manifold Mğ‘€M (resp. Nğ‘N), and assume that Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda are not commensurable to a group with a free abelian factor. Further f:Mtâ†’Ns:ğ‘“â†’subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘ f:M_{t}\to N_{s} will denote an (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“quasi-isometry.

4.2. Statement of result

In this section, we aim to define, for every s,tâ‰«râ‰«L+Cmuch-greater-thanğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-thanğ¿ğ¶s,t\gg r\gg L+C, an invariant of an (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)-quasi-isometry f:Mtâ†’Ns:ğ‘“â†’subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘ f:M_{t}\to N_{s} that measures the extent to which fğ‘“f (coarsely) preserves the action and manifold contributions to the coarse fundamental group, i.e. the data of the extensions

1â†’Ï€1â€‹(M)â†’Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)â†’Î“â†’1â†’1subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€â†’subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿâ†’Î“â†’11\to\pi_{1}(M)\to\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\Gamma\to 1

and the corresponding extension for Nssubscriptğ‘ğ‘ N_{s}. To start, recall that we defined for an rğ‘Ÿr-loop Î±ğ›¼\alpha in Mğ‘€M, its orbital jump Q~â€‹(Î±)~ğ‘„ğ›¼\widetilde{Q}(\alpha) (see Definition 3.5). We intend to show:

Proposition 4.1.

There are commensurations Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} of Mğ‘€M and Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime} of Nğ‘N, such that the following holds for any s,tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1s,t\gg r\gg 1: Let Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} (resp. Î›â€²superscriptÎ›â€²\Lambda^{\prime}) be the group of lifts of Î“Î“\Gamma (resp. Î›Î›\Lambda) to Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} (resp. Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime}), and let fâ€²:Mtâ€²â†’Nsâ€²:superscriptğ‘“â€²â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ â€²f^{\prime}:M_{t}^{\prime}\to N_{s}^{\prime} be an (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“quasi-isometry. Let p,qâˆˆMâ€²ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘€â€²p,q\in M^{\prime} and let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be a (continuous) path in Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} from pğ‘p to qğ‘q. Then QÎ›â€²â€‹(fâ€²âˆ˜È·Mâ€‹(Î±))subscriptğ‘„superscriptÎ›â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€ğ›¼Q_{\Lambda^{\prime}}(f^{\prime}\circ\jmath_{M}(\alpha)) only depends on pğ‘p and qğ‘q, and not on the path Î±ğ›¼\alpha chosen.

This will use in an essential way that the groups Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda are complicated (namely not commensurable to any group with a free abelian factor), and is false otherwise.

4.3. Construction of the commensurable spaces

We start by finding the right covers Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} and Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime} to prove Proposition 4.1.

Proposition 4.2.

Î“Î“\Gamma contains a maximal finite normal subgroup. The same holds for Î›Î›\Lambda.

It clearly suffices to prove the statement for Î“Î“\Gamma. We prove this in two steps. We will start by proving this for a finite-index subgroup of Î“Î“\Gamma. Namely, let G=Î“Â¯ğºÂ¯Î“G=\overline{\Gamma} denote the closure of Î“Î“\Gamma in Isomâ¡(M)Isomğ‘€\operatorname{Isom}(M), let G0superscriptğº0G^{0} be the connected component of the identity of GğºG, and set Î“0:=Î“âˆ©G0assignsubscriptÎ“0Î“superscriptğº0\Gamma_{0}:=\Gamma\cap G^{0}. Note that Î“0subscriptÎ“0\Gamma_{0} is a finite-index subgroup of Î“Î“\Gamma.

Lemma 4.3.

Î“0subscriptÎ“0\Gamma_{0} contains a maximal finite normal subgroup.

Proof.

Note that any finite normal subgroup Fğ¹F of Î“0subscriptÎ“0\Gamma_{0} is central, because G0superscriptğº0G^{0} normalizes Fğ¹F and by connectedness must centralize it. Since a pair of finite central subgroups generates a finite central subgroup, we see the union Fğ¹F of all finite normal subgroups is a central locally finite subgroup of Î“Î“\Gamma. We want to show it is finite.

Indeed, FÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¹0\overline{F}^{0} is a compact connected normal abelian subgroup of the compact connected Lie group G0superscriptğº0G^{0}, potentially trivial, and contains a dense locally finite group F0:=Sâˆ©FÂ¯0assignsubscriptğ¹0ğ‘†superscriptÂ¯ğ¹0F_{0}:=S\cap\overline{F}^{0}. Then FÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¹0\overline{F}^{0} is a local torus factor of GğºG. Consider the projection onto this factor, i.e.

G0â†’FÂ¯0/Aâ†’superscriptğº0superscriptÂ¯ğ¹0ğ´G^{0}\to\overline{F}^{0}/A

where Ağ´A is a finite group. The image of Î“Î“\Gamma is then a finitely generated abelian group in the torus FÂ¯0/AsuperscriptÂ¯ğ¹0ğ´\overline{F}^{0}/A and contains the image of F0subscriptğ¹0F_{0}, which is isomorphic to F0/(F0âˆ©A)subscriptğ¹0subscriptğ¹0ğ´F_{0}/(F_{0}\cap A). But any locally finite subgroup of a finitely generated abelian group is finite, so F0/(F0âˆ©A)subscriptğ¹0subscriptğ¹0ğ´F_{0}/(F_{0}\cap A) is finite. Since Ağ´A is also finite, it follows that F0subscriptğ¹0F_{0} is finite. Finally, FÂ¯Â¯ğ¹\overline{F} has finitely many components given by the group F/F0ğ¹subscriptğ¹0F/F_{0}, so that Fğ¹F is an extension of the finite group F/F0ğ¹subscriptğ¹0F/F_{0} by the finite group F0subscriptğ¹0F_{0}, and hence Fğ¹F is finite, as desired.âˆ

We can now show Î“Î“\Gamma contains a maximal finite normal subgroup.

Proof of Proposition 4.2.

Let F0subscriptğ¹0F_{0} be the maximal finite normal subgroup of Î“0subscriptÎ“0\Gamma_{0}, which exists by the above Lemma 4.3. Since any pair of finite normal subgroups generates a finite normal subgroup, the union Fğ¹F of all finite normal subgroups of Î“Î“\Gamma is well-defined.

We have to show Fğ¹F is finite. Clearly F0âŠ†Fsubscriptğ¹0ğ¹F_{0}\subseteq F and Fâˆ©G0ğ¹superscriptğº0F\cap G^{0} is a finite normal subgroup of Î“0subscriptÎ“0\Gamma_{0}, so we must have Fâˆ©G0=F0ğ¹superscriptğº0subscriptğ¹0F\cap G^{0}=F_{0}. Therefore projection mod G0superscriptğº0G^{0} gives an embedding

F/F0â†ªG/G0,â†ªğ¹subscriptğ¹0ğºsuperscriptğº0F/F_{0}\hookrightarrow G/G^{0},

and hence

|F|â‰¤|F0|â‹…|G/G0|<âˆ,ğ¹â‹…subscriptğ¹0ğºsuperscriptğº0|F|\leq|F_{0}|\cdot|G/G^{0}|<\infty,

as desired.âˆ

Armed with Proposition 4.2, we can construct the right homogeneous spaces for the proof of Proposition 4.1.

Construction 4.4.

Let FÎ“subscriptğ¹Î“F_{\Gamma} be the maximal finite normal subgroup of Î“Î“\Gamma. Then Î“/FÎ“Î“subscriptğ¹Î“\Gamma/F_{\Gamma} has no finite normal subgroup. Further since FÎ“subscriptğ¹Î“F_{\Gamma} is normal, the action of Î“Î“\Gamma descends to a minimal, isometric, free action of Î“â€²:=Î“/FÎ“assignsuperscriptÎ“â€²Î“subscriptğ¹Î“\Gamma^{\prime}:=\Gamma/F_{\Gamma} on Mâ€²:=M/FÎ“assignsuperscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘€subscriptğ¹Î“M^{\prime}:=M/F_{\Gamma}. Likewise we set Î›â€²:=Î›/FÎ›assignsuperscriptÎ›â€²Î›subscriptğ¹Î›\Lambda^{\prime}:=\Lambda/F_{\Lambda} and Nâ€²:=N/FÎ›assignsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘subscriptğ¹Î›N^{\prime}:=N/F_{\Lambda}. By Lemma 2.3, the warped cone over a finite quotient is uniformly quasi-isometric to the original warped cone.

4.4. Proof of Proposition 4.1

We now replace our initial actions by the commensurable quotients just constructed and so denote these quotients Î“â€²,Mâ€²,Î›â€²,Nâ€²superscriptÎ“â€²superscriptğ‘€â€²superscriptÎ›â€²superscriptğ‘â€²\Gamma^{\prime},M^{\prime},\Lambda^{\prime},N^{\prime} by Î“,M,Î›,NÎ“ğ‘€Î›ğ‘\Gamma,M,\Lambda,N. The proof proceeds in several steps. We start by reducing Proposition 4.1 to a statement on coarse fundamental groups (i.e. about loops, not paths).

Lemma 4.5.

To prove Proposition 4.1, it suffices to show that for any (continuous) loop Î±ğ›¼\alpha in Mğ‘€M, we have QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜È·~Mâ€‹(Î±))=esubscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“subscript~italic-È·ğ‘€ğ›¼ğ‘’Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\widetilde{\jmath}_{M}(\alpha))=e.

Proof.

Let p,qâˆˆMğ‘ğ‘ğ‘€p,q\in M and let Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta be two paths from pğ‘p to qğ‘q. Recall that Î²Â¯Â¯ğ›½\overline{\beta} denotes the reverse of Î²ğ›½\beta. It is immediate from the definition that QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜Î²Â¯)=QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜Î²)âˆ’1subscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“Â¯ğ›½subscriptğ‘„Î›superscriptğ‘“ğ›½1Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\overline{\beta})=Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\beta)^{-1} and

QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜Î²)âˆ’1â€‹QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜Î±)=QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜Î²Â¯)â€‹QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜Î±)=QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜(Î²Â¯âˆ—Î±)).subscriptğ‘„Î›superscriptğ‘“ğ›½1subscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“ğ›¼subscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“Â¯ğ›½subscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“ğ›¼subscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“âˆ—Â¯ğ›½ğ›¼Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\beta)^{-1}\,Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\alpha)=Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\overline{\beta})\,Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\alpha)=Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ(\overline{\beta}\ast\alpha)).

Since Î²Â¯âˆ—Î±âˆ—Â¯ğ›½ğ›¼\overline{\beta}\ast\alpha is a loop in Mğ‘€M, we have QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜(Î²Â¯âˆ—Î±))=esubscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“âˆ—Â¯ğ›½ğ›¼ğ‘’Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ(\overline{\beta}\ast\alpha))=e by assumption and hence QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜Î±)=QÎ›â€‹(fâˆ˜Î²)subscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“ğ›¼subscriptğ‘„Î›ğ‘“ğ›½Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\alpha)=Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\beta). âˆ

Let Î¦:=fâˆ—assignÎ¦subscriptğ‘“âˆ—\Phi:=f_{\ast} be the map on coarse fundamental groups induced by the quasi-isometry f:Mtâ†’Ns:ğ‘“â†’subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘ f:M_{t}\to N_{s}. Consider the composition

a:Ï€1â€‹(M,p0)â€‹â†ªÈ·Mâ€‹Ï€1â€‹(Mt,p0;r)â€‹âŸ¶Î¦â€‹Ï€1â€‹(Ns,fâ€‹(p0);Lâ€‹r+C)â€‹â† QÎ›â€‹Î›.:ğ‘subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€â†ªsubscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0ğ‘ŸÎ¦âŸ¶subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘“subscriptğ‘0ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶subscriptğ‘„Î›â† Î›a:\pi_{1}(M,p_{0})\overset{\jmath_{M}}{\hookrightarrow}\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r)\overset{\Phi}{\longrightarrow}\pi_{1}(N_{s},f(p_{0});Lr+C)\overset{Q_{\Lambda}}{\twoheadrightarrow}\Lambda.

To prove Proposition 4.1, it therefore suffices to show:

Lemma 4.6.

ağ‘a is trivial.

Before we prove this, let us just note:

Remark 4.7.

This is the key place in the proof of Theorem 1.4 where we use that Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda have no free abelian factor (up to commensuration). In a sense to be made precise below, the isomorphism on coarse fundamental group induced by ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t} preserves the manifold contribution È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) and the group contribution È·Î“â€‹(Î“)subscriptitalic-È·Î“Î“\jmath_{\Gamma}(\Gamma) to the coarse fundamental group.

This fails disastrously for actions of free abelian groups, and gives rise to the examples of Kim and Kielakâ€“Sawicki of quasi-isometric warped cones for actions of groups that are not commensurable.

Proof of Lemma 4.6.

Since È·Mâ€‹(Ï€1â€‹(M))subscriptitalic-È·ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) is normal in Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t};r), it is clear that the image of ağ‘a is normal in Î›Î›\Lambda. Since Î›Î›\Lambda does not contain any nontrivial finite normal subgroup (see Construction 4.4), it therefore suffices to show that the image of ağ‘a is also finite.

Since Mğ‘€M is a compact homogeneous space, Ï€1â€‹(M)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\pi_{1}(M) contains a finite-index central free abelian subgroup Ağ´A. We claim that there is a finite-index subgroup Î”Î”\Delta of Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) such that Ağ´A is also central in Î”Î”\Delta. To see this, recall that Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) is isomorphic to the group of lifts of Î“Î“\Gamma to Mğ‘€M and hence is given by an extension

1â†’Ï€1â€‹(M)â†’Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)â†’Î“â†’1.â†’1subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€â†’subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿâ†’Î“â†’11\to\pi_{1}(M)\to\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\Gamma\to 1.

Since Î“Î“\Gamma acts isometrically on Mğ‘€M, the conjugation action Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)â†’Î“â†’Outâ¡(Ï€1â€‹(M))â†’subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘ŸÎ“â†’Outsubscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\Gamma\to\operatorname{Out}(\pi_{1}(M)) has finite image. Let Î”Î”\Delta be the kernel, so Î”Î”\Delta is of finite index in Ï€1â€‹(Mt;r)subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) and centralizes Ağ´A. Let Î›â€²:=QÎ›â€‹(Î¦â€‹(Î”))assignsuperscriptÎ›â€²subscriptğ‘„Î›Î¦Î”\Lambda^{\prime}:=Q_{\Lambda}(\Phi(\Delta)) be the image of Î”Î”\Delta in Î›Î›\Lambda and write B:=aâ€‹(A)assignğµğ‘ğ´B:=a(A). So Î›â€²superscriptÎ›â€²\Lambda^{\prime} is a finite-index subgroup of Î›Î›\Lambda that centralizes BğµB.

In order to show ağ‘a has finite image, it suffices to show BğµB is finite (since Ağ´A is of finite index in Ï€1â€‹(M)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€\pi_{1}(M)). To see this, we claim that a finite-index subgroup of BğµB is a (necessarily abelian) factor of a finite-index subgroup of Î›â€²superscriptÎ›â€²\Lambda^{\prime}. Since no finite-index subgroup of Î›Î›\Lambda has an abelian factor, it follows that BğµB must have been finite. To produce this factor of Î›â€²superscriptÎ›â€²\Lambda^{\prime}, it suffices to find a projection of a finite-index subgroup of Î›â€²superscriptÎ›â€²\Lambda^{\prime} onto a finite-index subgroup of BğµB.

To find this projection, consider the closure BÂ¯Â¯ğµ\overline{B} of BğµB in Isom(N)ğ‘(N). If BğµB is infinite, then BÂ¯Â¯ğµ\overline{B} has nontrivial connected component BÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğµ0\overline{B}^{0}. Further BÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğµ0\overline{B}^{0} is central in the compact Lie group Î›â€²Â¯0superscriptÂ¯superscriptÎ›â€²0\overline{\Lambda^{\prime}}^{0}. Hence BÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğµ0\overline{B}^{0} is a local torus factor of Î›â€²Â¯0superscriptÂ¯superscriptÎ›â€²0\overline{\Lambda^{\prime}}^{0}. Write Ï€:Î›â€²Â¯0â†’BÂ¯0/F:ğœ‹â†’superscriptÂ¯superscriptÎ›â€²0superscriptÂ¯ğµ0ğ¹\pi:\overline{\Lambda^{\prime}}^{0}\to\overline{B}^{0}/F (where Fğ¹F is a finite group) for the projection to this torus factor, and write T:=BÂ¯0/Fassignğ‘‡superscriptÂ¯ğµ0ğ¹T:=\overline{B}^{0}/F for the quotient.

Then Ï€â€‹(Î›â€²)ğœ‹superscriptÎ›â€²\pi(\Lambda^{\prime}) is a finitely generated abelian subgroup of Tğ‘‡T containing the image B/(Bâˆ©F)ğµğµğ¹B/(B\cap F) of BğµB, which is also finitely generated and abelian. There is a finite-index subgroup Bâ€²superscriptğµâ€²B^{\prime} of BğµB that intersects Fğ¹F trivially and hence projects isomorphically to B/(Bâˆ©F)ğµğµğ¹B/(B\cap F). Therefore the following fact finishes the proof:

Fact. Let A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} be a finitely generated abelian group with a subgroup A2subscriptğ´2A_{2}. Then some finite-index subgroup of A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} is a factor of some finite-index subgroup of A1subscriptğ´1A_{1}. âˆ

Vanishing of ağ‘a has the following immediate consequence:

Construction 4.8.

The map Î¦:Î“~â†’Î›~:Î¦â†’~Î“~Î›\Phi:\widetilde{\Gamma}\to\widetilde{\Lambda} induced by fğ‘“f on coarse fundamental groups restricts to an isomorphism Î¦|Ï€1â€‹(M):Ï€1â€‹(M)â†’Ï€1â€‹(N):evaluated-atÎ¦subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘\Phi|_{\pi_{1}(M)}:\pi_{1}(M)\to\pi_{1}(N) and hence descends to an isomorphism Ï†:Î“â†’Î›:ğœ‘â†’Î“Î›\varphi:\Gamma\to\Lambda.

5. Stabilization of maps on coarse fundamental groups

At this point we are able to state the full version of Theorem 1.5, which requires some technical assumptions.

Theorem 5.1.

Let Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda be finitely presented groups acting isometrically, freely and minimally on compact manifolds Mğ‘€M and Nğ‘N (respectively). Assume

  1. (i)

    neither of Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda is commensurable to a group with a nontrivial free abelian factor,

  2. (ii)

    there exist uniform quasi-isometries fn:Mtnâ†’Nsn:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›â†’subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›f_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}} for two sequences tn,snâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›t_{n},s_{n}\to\infty , and

  3. (iii)

    letting Ï†n:Î“â†’Î›:subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›â†’Î“Î›\varphi_{n}:\Gamma\to\Lambda be the isomorphisms defined in Construction 4.8, assume these stabilize up to conjugacy along a subsequence.

Then there is an affine commensuration of the action of Î“Î“\Gamma on Mğ‘€M and the action of Î›Î›\Lambda on Nğ‘N.

In general, the sequences {tn}nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘›\{t_{n}\}_{n} and {sn}nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘›\{s_{n}\}_{n} could be extremely sparse, and hence without the coarse homotopical stabilization hypothesis (iii), there is no relationship between the maps fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n}. Of course, if the maps fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} are all induced by a single quasi-isometry f:ğ’¢â€‹(Î“â†·M)â†’ğ’¢â€‹(Î›â†·N):ğ‘“â†’ğ’¢â†·Î“Mğ’¢â†·Î›Nf:\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\to\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)} of the geometric cones, then there is an extremely close connection between the different fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} (although they are only uniformly coarsely Lipschitz, see Lemma 2.4), and we will show this indeed implies that the maps Ï†nsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›\varphi_{n} stabilize in this case (see Section 5.6 below). After establishing this stabilization phenomenon, the proofs of Theorem 1.4, which shows affine commensurability of actions with quasi-isometric geometric cones, and Theorem 5.1, which shows affine commensurability only assuming quasi-isometric sequences of level sets but under the additional coarse stabilization hypothesis 5.1(iii), will proceed completely parallel to each other (see Sections 7 and 8).

In the next subsection, we will show that if Î“Î“\Gamma has Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}, then a sequence of uniform quasi-isometries satisfies the coarse stabilization hypothesis 5.1(iii). Therefore Theorem 1.5, obtaining affine commensurability for assuming quasi-isometric sequences of level sets under the additional assumption of Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}, is a direct consequence of Theorem 5.1 and the results of the next subsection.

Theorem 1.4, which assumes quasi-isometric geometric cones, does not follow from Theorem 5.1, because quasi-isometries of geometric cones do not yield uniform quasi-isometries of level sets, but only uniformly coarsely Lipschitz maps as described in Lemma 2.4. It turns out that condition suffices to construct the conjugacy in both Theorem 1.4 and 5.1 and we carry this out in Section 7 and 8.

On the other hand, for the study of the geometry of expanders, and in particular for the proof of Theorems 1.7 and 1.8, we need to control the behavior of subsequences of level sets of warped cones, which could be very sparse. Hence for these results Theorem 1.4 does not suffice, and one needs Theorem 1.5 and therefore Theorem 5.1 and the results of the next few sections.

In this section, we will prove that in many cases, the stabilization hypothesis (iii) is satisfied. In addition to the setting of the geometric cone discussed above, we will consider several easily checked group-theoretic assumptions on Î“Î“\Gamma and Î›Î›\Lambda that imply stabilization. We introduce an abstract property of a finitely generated group which we call FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} which implies stabilization and provide many examples of groups satisfying FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}. We make no attempt to be exhaustive and simply prove FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} in several cases related to applications. The following groups have FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}:

  1. (1)

    Any Î“Î“\Gamma with Outâ¡(Î“)OutÎ“\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) finite.

  2. (2)

    Surface groups.

  3. (3)

    Free groups.

  4. (4)

    Certain free products.

  5. (5)

    Certain direct products.

We will use the first or third, and fifth criterion in the proof of Theorem 1.7 and the first and fifth in the proof of Theorem 1.8. We believe one can give slightly different proofs of those theorems using the fourth condition in place of the fifith, but as the proof using the fifth is shorter, we only include it here. Since we are willing to pass to subsequences, stabilization is trivial in the first case and we will not comment on it further. Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} is really only needed to check (â€‹2â€‹)âˆ’(â€‹5â€‹)italic-(2italic-)italic-(5italic-)\eqref{item:surface}-\eqref{item:direct_prod}.

5.1. Uniform bounds on stable norms

Recall the definition of stable norm in a group:

Definition 5.2.

Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a finitely generated group, equipped with a word metric with respect to a finite symmetric generating set Sğ‘†S. Then for any Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma, the stable norm of Î³ğ›¾\gamma is

â€–Î³â€–âˆ:=limnâ†’âˆâ€–Î³nâ€–n.assignsubscriptnormğ›¾subscriptâ†’ğ‘›normsuperscriptğ›¾ğ‘›ğ‘›\|\gamma\|_{\infty}:=\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{\|\gamma^{n}\|}{n}.
Remark 5.3.

Because of submultiplicativity, the stable norm is well-defined and finite (in fact bounded by â€–Î³â€–normğ›¾\|\gamma\|).

Remark 5.4.

Stable norm is conjugation invariant.

The remarks leads us to consider the following sets of automorphisms of Î“Î“\Gamma. For any D>0ğ·0D>0 define the set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} of automorphisms Ïˆğœ“\psi of Î“Î“\Gamma which satisfy

â€–Ïˆâ€‹(Î³)â€–âˆâ‰¤Dâ€‹â€–Î³â€–âˆsubscriptnormğœ“ğ›¾ğ·subscriptnormğ›¾\|\psi(\gamma)\|_{\infty}\leq D\|\gamma\|_{\infty}

for every Î³ğ›¾\gamma in Î“Î“\Gamma. Since conjugation preserves stable norm, ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is a union of fibers of the map Autâ¡(Î“)â†’Outâ¡(Î“)â†’AutÎ“OutÎ“\operatorname{Aut}(\Gamma)\rightarrow\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) and it is more natural to consider the projection of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} to Outâ¡(Î“)OutÎ“\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma). We refer to ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} as the set of automorphisms which are Dğ·Dâ€“Lipschitz for the stable norm.

Definition 5.5.

We say Î“Î“\Gamma has FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} if the projection of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} to Outâ¡(Î“)OutÎ“\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) is finite for all D>1ğ·1D>1.

We assume the setting of Theorem 5.1. The following proposition relates FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} to the problem of stabilization.

Proposition 5.6.

For any Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma, we have

â€–Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€–âˆâ‰¤(L+2)â€‹â€–Î³â€–âˆ.subscriptnormsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾ğ¿2subscriptnormğ›¾\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\|_{\infty}\leq(L+2)\|\gamma\|_{\infty}.
Proof.

Let Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma. The shortest loop in Mtnsubscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›M_{t_{n}} representing Î³âˆˆÏ€1â€‹(Mtn,p0;r)ğ›¾subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\gamma\in\pi_{1}(M_{t_{n}},p_{0};r) has length â€–Î³â€–+tnâ€‹dMâ€‹(p0,Î³â€‹p0)normğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\|\gamma\|+t_{n}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0}) for tnsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t_{n} large enough. Consider the image under fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} of any such loop. Of course, it represents Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)âˆˆÏ€1â€‹(Nsn,fnâ€‹(p0);Lâ€‹r+C)subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\in\pi_{1}(N_{s_{n}},f_{n}(p_{0});Lr+C) and hence has length at least â€–Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€–+snâ€‹dNâ€‹(fnâ€‹(p0),Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0))normsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\|+s_{n}d_{N}(f_{n}(p_{0}),\varphi_{n}(\gamma)f_{n}(p_{0})). On the other hand by the quasi-isometry property, and the fact that the original loop could be represented by roughly â€–Î³â€–r+tnrâ€‹dMâ€‹(p0,Î³â€‹p0)normğ›¾ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\frac{\|\gamma\|}{r}+\frac{t_{n}}{r}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0}) points where under application by fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n}, each segment (of length roughly rğ‘Ÿr) gets stretched to a segment of length at most Lâ€‹r+Cğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶Lr+C, the image has length at most

(Lâ€‹r+C)â€‹(â€–Î³â€–r+tnrâ€‹dMâ€‹(p0,Î³â€‹p0)).ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶normğ›¾ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0(Lr+C)\left(\frac{\|\gamma\|}{r}+\frac{t_{n}}{r}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0})\right).

Hence we conclude (for râ‰¥Cğ‘Ÿğ¶r\geq C, which we can assume), that

â€–Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€–+snâ€‹dNâ€‹(fnâ€‹(p0),Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0))â‰¤(L+1)â€‹(â€–Î³â€–+tnâ€‹dMâ€‹(p0,Î³â€‹p0)).normsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0ğ¿1normğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\|+s_{n}d_{N}(f_{n}(p_{0}),\varphi_{n}(\gamma)f_{n}(p_{0}))\leq(L+1)\left(\|\gamma\|+t_{n}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0})\right).

Now consider the above identity for Î³msuperscriptğ›¾ğ‘š\gamma^{m} as mâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘šm\to\infty. If Î³ğ›¾\gamma has infinite order, then for mâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘š1m\gg 1 we have â€–Î³mâ€–â‰¥tnâ€‹diamâ¡(M)normsuperscriptğ›¾ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›diamğ‘€\|\gamma^{m}\|\geq t_{n}\operatorname{diam}(M), so

â€–Ï†nâ€‹(Î³m)â€–normsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ›¾ğ‘š\displaystyle\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma^{m})\| â‰¤â€–Ï†nâ€‹(Î³m)â€–+snâ€‹dNâ€‹(fnâ€‹(p0),Ï†nâ€‹(Î³m)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0))absentnormsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ›¾ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ›¾ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\displaystyle\leq\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma^{m})\|+s_{n}d_{N}(f_{n}(p_{0}),\varphi_{n}(\gamma^{m})f_{n}(p_{0}))
â‰¤(L+1)â€‹(â€–Î³mâ€–+tnâ€‹dMâ€‹(p0,Î³mâ€‹p0))absentğ¿1normsuperscriptğ›¾ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0superscriptğ›¾ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘0\displaystyle\leq(L+1)\left(\|\gamma^{m}\|+t_{n}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma^{m}p_{0})\right)
â‰¤(L+2)â€‹â€–Î³mâ€–.absentğ¿2normsuperscriptğ›¾ğ‘š\displaystyle\leq(L+2)\|\gamma^{m}\|.

Now divide by mğ‘šm on both sides and take the limit to get â€–Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€–âˆâ‰¤(L+2)â€‹â€–Î³â€–âˆsubscriptnormsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾ğ¿2subscriptnormğ›¾\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\|_{\infty}\leq(L+2)\|\gamma\|_{\infty}, as desired.

The above applied for Î³ğ›¾\gamma of infinite order. If Î³ğ›¾\gamma has torsion, then so does Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾\varphi_{n}(\gamma). Further the stable norm of torsion elements vanishes, so the desired bound is immediate. âˆ

Retaining the terminology of Theorem 5.1, the following is now obvious.

Corollary 5.7.

If Î“Î“\Gamma has FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} then the maps Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n} stabilize up to conjugacy on a subsequence.

5.2. Hyperbolic groups

In this subsection we prove:

Proposition 5.8.

Hyperbolic groups have Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

If stable norm is replaced with conjugacy length (i.e. the minimal word length of a conjugate), then this result is established for torsion-free hyperbolic groups in [Can, Proposition 2.3 ]. Throughout this subsection, we let Î“Î“\Gamma be a hyperbolic group, generated by a finite set Sğ‘†S. We denote the Cayley graph of Î“Î“\Gamma with respect to Sğ‘†S by Cay(Î“)Î“(\Gamma), and let Î´ğ›¿\delta be the hyperbolicity constant of Cay(Î“)Î“(\Gamma). We recall that in hyperbolic groups, stable norm essentially detects conjugacy classes:

Lemma 5.9 (see e.g. [BH, Proposition III.F.3.15]).

For every R>0ğ‘…0R>0, there are only finitely many conjugacy classes with stable norm bounded by Rğ‘…R. In fact, there is a constant C,D>0ğ¶ğ·0C,D>0 depending only on Î´ğ›¿\delta such that if â€–Î³â€–âˆ<Rsubscriptnormğ›¾ğ‘…\|\gamma\|_{\infty}<R then there is wâˆˆÎ“ğ‘¤Î“w\in\Gamma in the conjugacy class of Î³ğ›¾\gamma with |w|<Câ€‹R+Dğ‘¤ğ¶ğ‘…ğ·|w|<CR+D.

We now establish a basic fact about isometries of hyperbolic spaces: displacement of a point zğ‘§z under an isometry is relatively comparable to distance from zğ‘§z to a point with small displacement. This will be helpful in showing existence of fixed points for limit actions on trees.

Lemma 5.10.

Let sâˆˆÎ“ğ‘ Î“s\in\Gamma and x,yâˆˆCayâ€‹(Î“)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦CayÎ“x,y\in\text{Cay}(\Gamma) such that dâ€‹(x,sâ€‹x)<Cğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ¶d(x,sx)<C and dâ€‹(y,sâ€‹y)<dğ‘‘ğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘‘d(y,sy)<d for some constants d,C>Î´ğ‘‘ğ¶ğ›¿d,C>\delta. Then there is a point zğ‘§z on a geodesic segment [x,y]ğ‘¥ğ‘¦[x,y] which satisfies dâ€‹(z,sâ€‹z)<10â€‹Cğ‘‘ğ‘§ğ‘ ğ‘§10ğ¶d(z,sz)<10C and dâ€‹(y,z)<10â€‹dğ‘‘ğ‘¦ğ‘§10ğ‘‘d(y,z)<10d.

Proof.

If dâ€‹(x,y)â‰¤4â€‹minâ¡{d,C}ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦4ğ‘‘ğ¶d(x,y)\leq 4\min\{d,C\} we can choose z:=xassignğ‘§ğ‘¥z:=x. Hence we assume that dâ€‹(x,y)>4â€‹dğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦4ğ‘‘d(x,y)>4d and dâ€‹(x,y)>4â€‹Cğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦4ğ¶d(x,y)>4C. Pick zâˆˆ[x,y]ğ‘§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦z\in[x,y] such that dâ€‹(z,y)=2â€‹dğ‘‘ğ‘§ğ‘¦2ğ‘‘d(z,y)=2d. Let wâˆˆ[x,sâ€‹y]ğ‘¤ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦w\in[x,sy] such that dâ€‹(x,w)=dâ€‹(x,z)=dâ€‹(x,y)âˆ’2â€‹dğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¤ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘§ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦2ğ‘‘d(x,w)=d(x,z)=d(x,y)-2d. By Î´ğ›¿\delta-hyperbolicity, dâ€‹(z,w)<2â€‹Î´ğ‘‘ğ‘§ğ‘¤2ğ›¿d(z,w)<2\delta. Let tâˆˆ[sâ€‹x,sâ€‹y]ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦t\in[sx,sy] such that

dâ€‹(sâ€‹y,t)=dâ€‹(sâ€‹y,w)ğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘¤\displaystyle d(sy,t)=d(sy,w) =dâ€‹(x,sâ€‹y)âˆ’(dâ€‹(x,y)âˆ’2â€‹d)absentğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦2ğ‘‘\displaystyle=d(x,sy)-(d(x,y)-2d)
=dâ€‹(x,sâ€‹y)âˆ’dâ€‹(sâ€‹x,sâ€‹y)+2â€‹d.absentğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦2ğ‘‘\displaystyle=d(x,sy)-d(sx,sy)+2d.

By Î´ğ›¿\delta-hyperbolicity, dâ€‹(t,w)<2â€‹Î´ğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¤2ğ›¿d(t,w)<2\delta. On the other hand, since sâ€‹zâˆˆ[sâ€‹x,sâ€‹y]ğ‘ ğ‘§ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦sz\in[sx,sy] and dâ€‹(sâ€‹z,sâ€‹y)=2â€‹dğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘§ğ‘ ğ‘¦2ğ‘‘d(sz,sy)=2d, we get dâ€‹(sâ€‹z,t)<|dâ€‹(x,sâ€‹y)âˆ’dâ€‹(sâ€‹x,sâ€‹y)|â‰¤Cğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘§ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ¶d(sz,t)<|d(x,sy)-d(sx,sy)|\leq C. By the triangle inequality, we see dâ€‹(z,sâ€‹z)<4â€‹Î´+C<10â€‹Cğ‘‘ğ‘§ğ‘ ğ‘§4ğ›¿ğ¶10ğ¶d(z,sz)<4\delta+C<10C. âˆ

We also need the following lemma about isometric actions on trees. The proof can be found in Serreâ€™s [Ser]. We note that Serre considers simplicial trees but the proof is valid for general â„â„\mathbb{R}-trees as well.

Lemma 5.11.

[Ser, Proposition 26, section I.6] Let Î›Î›\Lambda be a group acting on a tree Tğ‘‡T by isometries and let s1,s2âˆˆÎ›subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2Î›s_{1},s_{2}\in\Lambda be elements with fixed points. Let Fâ€‹iâ€‹xâ€‹(s1)ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ 1Fix(s_{1}) and Fâ€‹iâ€‹xâ€‹(s2)ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ 2Fix(s_{2}) be the fixed point sets of s1subscriptğ‘ 1s_{1} and s2subscriptğ‘ 2s_{2}. If Fâ€‹iâ€‹xâ€‹(s1)âˆ©Fâ€‹iâ€‹xâ€‹(s2)=âˆ…ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ 1ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ 2Fix(s_{1})\cap Fix(s_{2})=\varnothing then s1â€‹s2subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2s_{1}s_{2} does not have fixed point on Tğ‘‡T.

We will now prove that hyperbolic groups have Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Proof of Proposition 5.8.

Let Ïn:Î“â†’Î“:subscriptğœŒğ‘›â†’Î“Î“\rho_{n}:\Gamma\to\Gamma be automorphisms that are Lipschitz with respect to stable norm. Consider the sequence of action of Î“Î“\Gamma on Cayâ€‹(Î“)CayÎ“\text{Cay}(\Gamma) obtained by precomposing the action with ÏnsubscriptğœŒğ‘›\rho_{n}. Define displacement functions dnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›d_{n} by dnâ€‹(x)=maxsâˆˆSâ¡dâ€‹(Ïnâ€‹(s)â€‹x,x)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘†ğ‘‘subscriptğœŒğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘¥d_{n}(x)=\max_{s\in S}d(\rho_{n}(s)x,x). Choose xnâˆˆCayâ€‹(Î“)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›CayÎ“x_{n}\in\text{Cay}(\Gamma) that minimize dnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›d_{n}.

We prove that dnâ€‹(xn)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›d_{n}(x_{n}) is uniformly bounded. Suppose for the sake of contradiction that dnâ€‹(xn)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›d_{n}(x_{n}) diverges. Consider the asymptotic cone of Cayâ€‹(Î“)CayÎ“\text{Cay}(\Gamma) with respect to the basepoints (xn)nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘›(x_{n})_{n} and rescaling sequence (dnâ€‹(xn))nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘›(d_{n}(x_{n}))_{n}. The limit is an â„â„\mathbb{R}-tree Tğ‘‡T and the action of Î“Î“\Gamma on Tğ‘‡T does not have a global fixed point by our choice of scaling sequence and basepoints. On the other hand, by Lemma 5.9, for every sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in S, and nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}, there exists wnâˆˆCayâ€‹(Î“)subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›CayÎ“w_{n}\in\text{Cay}(\Gamma) such that dâ€‹(Ïnâ€‹(s)â€‹wn,wn)<Cğ‘‘subscriptğœŒğ‘›ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›ğ¶d(\rho_{n}(s)w_{n},w_{n})<C for some universal constant Cğ¶C because ÏnsubscriptğœŒğ‘›\rho_{n} is Lipschitz with respect to stable norm. By Lemma 5.10, there exists wnâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›â€²w_{n}^{\prime} on the geodesic segment [wn,xn]subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›[w_{n},x_{n}] such that dâ€‹(xn,wnâ€²)<10â€‹dnâ€‹(xn)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›â€²10subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›d(x_{n},w_{n}^{\prime})<10d_{n}(x_{n}) and dâ€‹(wnâ€²,Ïnâ€‹(s)â€‹wnâ€²)<10â€‹Cğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›â€²subscriptğœŒğ‘›ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›â€²10ğ¶d(w_{n}^{\prime},\rho_{n}(s)w_{n}^{\prime})<10C. The sequence (wnâ€²)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›â€²(w_{n}^{\prime}) converges to a fixed point of sğ‘ s on Tğ‘‡T. Thus every element of Sğ‘†S acts with fixed point on Tğ‘‡T. Moreover, this argument also produces fixed points for the product of any pair of generators.

On the other hand, since Î“Î“\Gamma acts on Tğ‘‡T without global fixed point, there exist s1,s2âˆˆSsubscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2ğ‘†s_{1},s_{2}\in S whose fixed point sets are disjoint. It follows from Lemma 5.11 that s1â€‹s2subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2s_{1}s_{2} does not have a fixed point on Tğ‘‡T, which is a contradiction. Therefore, there exist xnâˆˆCayâ€‹(Î“)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›CayÎ“x_{n}\in\text{Cay}(\Gamma) such that dnâ€‹(xn)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›d_{n}(x_{n}) is uniformly bounded.

Now pick such a sequence (xn)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›(x_{n}). Then dâ€‹(xnâˆ’1â€‹Ïnâ€‹(s)â€‹xn,1)ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›1subscriptğœŒğ‘›ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›1d(x_{n}^{-1}\rho_{n}(s)x_{n},1) is uniformly bounded for all sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in S and nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}. Therefore the ÏnsubscriptğœŒğ‘›\rho_{n} are all conjugate to a finite collection of homomorphisms and so stabilize on a subsequence. âˆ

5.3. Free groups

In this subsection we prove:

Proposition 5.12.

The free group Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} on kğ‘˜k generators has Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

We note that free groups are hyperbolic so have property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} from the results of the last subsection. We present here a more explicit proof, both because free groups are more essential for applications, and since the basic idea is applied to free products in the next subsection.

We start by recalling that in a free group, word length and stable word length are closely related via cyclically reduced words. Recall that a reduced word w=si1â€‹â‹¯â€‹sikğ‘¤subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘–1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜w=s_{i_{1}}\cdots s_{i_{k}} is cyclically reduced if sikâ‰ si1âˆ’1subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘–11s_{i_{k}}\neq s_{i_{1}}^{-1}. This is to say that in w2superscriptğ‘¤2w^{2} there is no cancellation between the last letter of the first copy of wğ‘¤w and the first letter of the second copy of wğ‘¤w.

Lemma 5.13.

Let wğ‘¤w be a cyclically reduced word. Then â€–wâ€–âˆ=â€–wâ€–subscriptnormğ‘¤normğ‘¤\|w\|_{\infty}=\|w\|.

Proof.

It is obvious that â€–wnâ€–=nâ€‹â€–wâ€–normsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›ğ‘›normğ‘¤\|w^{n}\|=n\|w\| if wğ‘¤w is cyclically reduced. This immediately implies the claim.âˆ

Now we obtain stabilization for free groups:

Proof of Proposition 5.12.

Given an automorphism Ï†ğœ‘\varphi, change it by conjugation if necessary to ensure that â€–Ï†â€‹(si)â€–normğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–\|\varphi(s_{i})\| are minimal (in lexicographical ordering). We are not claiming such a representative is unique, merely take one. We assume Ï†ğœ‘\varphi is Dğ·Dâ€“Lipschitz for the stable norm and give a uniform bound on â€–Ï†â€‹(si)â€–normğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–\|\varphi(s_{i})\|. This clearly shows ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} projects to a finite set in Outâ¡(Fk)Outsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜\operatorname{Out}(F_{k}).

So let sğ‘ s be any generator. If Ï†â€‹(s)ğœ‘ğ‘ \varphi(s) is cyclically reduced, we have

â€–Ï†â€‹(s)â€–=â€–Ï†â€‹(s)â€–âˆâ‰¤D.normğœ‘ğ‘ subscriptnormğœ‘ğ‘ ğ·\|\varphi(s)\|=\|\varphi(s)\|_{\infty}\leq D.

If Ï†â€‹(s)ğœ‘ğ‘ \varphi(s) is not cyclically reduced, we can write (in reduced form)

Ï†â€‹(s)=siâ€‹wâ€‹siâˆ’1ğœ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–1\varphi(s)=s_{i}ws_{i}^{-1}

for some iğ‘–i and word wğ‘¤w that does not start with siâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–1s_{i}^{-1} and does not end with sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i}. Now there is some jğ‘—j such that Ï†â€‹(sj)ğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—\varphi(s_{j}) does not start with sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} and does not end with siâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–1s_{i}^{-1}.

Indeed, if for every jğ‘—j, we would have that Ï†â€‹(sj)ğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—\varphi(s_{j}) either started with sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} or ended with siâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–1s_{i}^{-1}, then consider Ïˆ:=siâˆ’1â€‹Ï†â€‹siassignğœ“superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–1ğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–\psi:=s_{i}^{-1}\varphi s_{i}. We have, for every jğ‘—j:

â€–Ïˆâ€‹(sj)â€–â‰¤â€–Ï†â€‹(sj)â€–normğœ“subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—normğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—\|\psi(s_{j})\|\leq\|\varphi(s_{j})\|

and further â€–Ïˆâ€‹(s)â€–<â€–Ï†â€‹(s)â€–normğœ“ğ‘ normğœ‘ğ‘ \|\psi(s)\|<\|\varphi(s)\|. This contradicts minimality of Ï†ğœ‘\varphi.

Hence we can choose jğ‘—j such that Ï†â€‹(sj)ğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—\varphi(s_{j}) does not start with sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} and does not end with siâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–1s_{i}^{-1}. Then Ï†â€‹(s)â€‹Ï†â€‹(sj)ğœ‘ğ‘ ğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—\varphi(s)\varphi(s_{j}) is cyclically reduced and hence

â€–Ï†â€‹(s)â€–â‰¤â€–Ï†â€‹(s)â€‹Ï†â€‹(sj)â€–normğœ‘ğ‘ normğœ‘ğ‘ ğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—\displaystyle\|\varphi(s)\|\leq\|\varphi(s)\varphi(s_{j})\| =â€–Ï†â€‹(s)â€‹Ï†â€‹(sj)â€–âˆabsentsubscriptnormğœ‘ğ‘ ğœ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—\displaystyle=\|\varphi(s)\varphi(s_{j})\|_{\infty}
â‰¤Dâ€‹â€–sâ€‹sjâ€–âˆabsentğ·subscriptnormğ‘ subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—\displaystyle\leq D\|ss_{j}\|_{\infty}
â‰¤2â€‹D.absent2ğ·\displaystyle\leq 2D.

âˆ

5.4. Free products

In this subsection we show that taking free products with â„¤â„¤\mathbb{Z} preserves FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} for co-Hopfian groups Î”Î”\Delta. It is most likely the case that other hypotheses on Î”Î”\Delta suffice as well. Our motivation for considering co-Hopfian groups is that higher rank lattices, and particularly all groups known to have strong property (T)ğ‘‡(T), are co-Hopfian.

Proposition 5.14.

Let Î”Î”\Delta be a finitely generated co-Hopfian group without a free cyclic factor. Set Î“=Î”âˆ—â„¤Î“âˆ—Î”â„¤\Gamma=\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}. Then Î“Î“\Gamma has FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Recall that a group GğºG is co-Hopfian if whenever HâŠ†Gğ»ğºH\subseteq G is a subgroup with Hâ‰…Gğ»ğºH\cong G, then H=Gğ»ğºH=G.

Proof.

Again fix an automorphism Ï†ğœ‘\varphi of Î“Î“\Gamma and assume Ï†ğœ‘\varphi is Dğ·Dâ€“Lipschitz for the stable norm. Again we will, after correcting by Ï†ğœ‘\varphi by conjugation, bound the word length of images of generators under Ï†ğœ‘\varphi. This suffices to see the projection of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} to Outâ¡(Î“)OutÎ“\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) is finite. Let tğ‘¡t be the generator of the free cyclic factor and consider a generating set S=SÎ”âˆª{t,tâˆ’1}ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡1S=S_{\Delta}\cup\{t,t^{-1}\} where SÎ”subscriptğ‘†Î”S_{\Delta} is a symmetric generating set for Î”Î”\Delta. First note that because Î”Î”\Delta has no free cyclic factor, by the Kurosh subgroup theorem, we can conjugate Ï†ğœ‘\varphi so that Ï†â€‹(Î”)âŠ†Î”ğœ‘Î”Î”\varphi(\Delta)\subseteq\Delta. Since Î”Î”\Delta is co-Hopfian, it follows that Ï†â€‹(Î”)=Î”ğœ‘Î”Î”\varphi(\Delta)=\Delta.

Claim 5.15.

If Ï†:Î”âˆ—â„¤â†’Î”âˆ—â„¤:ğœ‘â†’âˆ—Î”â„¤âˆ—Î”â„¤\varphi:\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}\to\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z} is an automorphism such that Ï†â€‹(Î”)=Î”ğœ‘Î”Î”\varphi(\Delta)=\Delta then there are Î´1,Î´2âˆˆÎ”subscriptğ›¿1subscriptğ›¿2Î”\delta_{1},\delta_{2}\in\Delta such that Ï†â€‹(t)=Î´1â€‹tÂ±1â€‹Î´2ğœ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¿1superscriptğ‘¡plus-or-minus1subscriptğ›¿2\varphi(t)=\delta_{1}t^{\pm 1}\delta_{2}.

Proof.

We note that for an automorphism Ï†ğœ‘\varphi satisfying Ï†â€‹(Î”)=Î”ğœ‘Î”Î”\varphi(\Delta)=\Delta and Î´1âˆˆÎ”subscriptğ›¿1Î”\delta_{1}\in\Delta, then Ï†1:Î”âˆ—â„¤â†’Î”âˆ—â„¤:subscriptğœ‘1â†’âˆ—Î”â„¤âˆ—Î”â„¤\varphi_{1}:\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}\to\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z} defined by Ï†1â€‹(Î´)=Ï†â€‹(Î´)subscriptğœ‘1ğ›¿ğœ‘ğ›¿\varphi_{1}(\delta)=\varphi(\delta) for all Î´âˆˆÎ”ğ›¿Î”\delta\in\Delta, and Ï†1â€‹(t)=Î´1â€‹Ï†â€‹(t)subscriptğœ‘1ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¿1ğœ‘ğ‘¡\varphi_{1}(t)=\delta_{1}\varphi(t) is also an automorphism of Î”âˆ—â„¤âˆ—Î”â„¤\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z} satisfying Ï†1â€‹(Î”)=Î”subscriptğœ‘1Î”Î”\varphi_{1}(\Delta)=\Delta. Similarly for Ï†2subscriptğœ‘2\varphi_{2} defined by Ï†2|Î”=Ï†|Î”evaluated-atsubscriptğœ‘2Î”evaluated-atğœ‘Î”\varphi_{2}|_{\Delta}=\varphi|_{\Delta} and Ï†2â€‹(t)=Ï†â€‹(t)â€‹Î´2subscriptğœ‘2ğ‘¡ğœ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¿2\varphi_{2}(t)=\varphi(t)\delta_{2} for some Î´2âˆˆÎ”subscriptğ›¿2Î”\delta_{2}\in\Delta. Therefore, we can assume that Ï†â€‹(t)ğœ‘ğ‘¡\varphi(t) is of the form tkâ€‹wâ€‹tlsuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘¤superscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™t^{k}wt^{l} where wğ‘¤w is an element in Î”âˆ—â„¤âˆ—Î”â„¤\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z} which does not start and end by nonzero powers of tğ‘¡t. If k+l=0ğ‘˜ğ‘™0k+l=0, then the image of any word containing tÂ±1superscriptğ‘¡plus-or-minus1t^{\pm 1} contains both tksuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜t^{k} and tâˆ’ksuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜t^{-k} in its reduced word representation. In particular, tğ‘¡t cannot be generated from Ï†â€‹(Î”âˆ—â„¤)ğœ‘âˆ—Î”â„¤\varphi(\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}). Thus, k+lâ‰ 0ğ‘˜ğ‘™0k+l\neq 0.

We show that w=1ğ‘¤1w=1 and k+l=Â±1ğ‘˜ğ‘™plus-or-minus1k+l=\pm 1. Indeed, since k+lâ‰ 0ğ‘˜ğ‘™0k+l\neq 0, wğ‘¤w cannot be canceled out in image of any reduced word containing tğ‘¡t in Î”âˆ—â„¤âˆ—Î”â„¤\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}. In particular, tğ‘¡t cannot be generated from image of Ï†â€‹(Î”âˆ—â„¤)ğœ‘âˆ—Î”â„¤\varphi(\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}), a contradiction. Thus, w=1ğ‘¤1w=1, and it follows that k+l=Â±1ğ‘˜ğ‘™plus-or-minus1k+l=\pm 1.âˆ

By Claim 5.15, we now conjugate Ï†ğœ‘\varphi by elements of Î”Î”\Delta and assume that Ï†â€‹(Î”)=Î”ğœ‘Î”Î”\varphi(\Delta)=\Delta and Ï†â€‹(t)=tÂ±1â€‹Î´ğœ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡plus-or-minus1ğ›¿\varphi(t)=t^{\pm 1}\delta, for some Î´âˆˆÎ”ğ›¿Î”\delta\in\Delta. Since â€–Ï†â€‹(t)â€–âˆ=1+â€–Î´â€–subscriptnormğœ‘ğ‘¡1normğ›¿\|\varphi(t)\|_{\infty}=1+\|\delta\|, we get â€–Î´â€–<Dnormğ›¿ğ·\|\delta\|<D. On the other hand, for sâˆˆSÎ”ğ‘ subscriptğ‘†Î”s\in S_{\Delta}, â€–Ï†â€‹(tâ€‹s)â€–âˆ=1+â€–Î´â€‹Ï†â€‹(s)â€–subscriptnormğœ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ 1normğ›¿ğœ‘ğ‘ \|\varphi(ts)\|_{\infty}=1+\|\delta\varphi(s)\|. It follows that â€–Î´â€‹Ï†â€‹(s)â€–normğ›¿ğœ‘ğ‘ \|\delta\varphi(s)\| is uniformly bounded, hence so is â€–Ï†â€‹(s)â€–normğœ‘ğ‘ \|\varphi(s)\|.âˆ

5.5. Direct products

Finally we record the case of products such that automorphisms preserve or interchange the factors, and each factor is of the above type. Mild conditions are required, which motivates:

Definition 5.16.

A group GğºG is called highly non-commutative if for any nontrivial proper subgroup Hğ»H, the group Hâ€‹Zâ€‹(H)ğ»ğ‘ğ»HZ(H) is also proper where Zâ€‹(H)ğ‘ğ»Z(H) is the centralizer of Hğ»H in GğºG.

Free groups, hyperbolic groups and irreducible higher rank lattices are all easily to be highly non-commutative. The following is now quite easy

Proposition 5.17.

Let Î”1,â€¦,Î”ksubscriptÎ”1â€¦subscriptÎ”ğ‘˜\Delta_{1},\dots,\Delta_{k} be highly non-commutative groups with FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}. Then Î“=âˆiÎ”iÎ“subscriptproductğ‘–subscriptÎ”ğ‘–\Gamma=\prod_{i}\Delta_{i} has Fâ€‹Sâ€‹Lğ¹ğ‘†ğ¿FSL.

The proof of the proposition is the following easy exercise: use that the Î”isubscriptÎ”ğ‘–\Delta_{i} are highly non-commutative to show that any automorphism of Î“Î“\Gamma permutes the factors. We will only use the following special case.

Corollary 5.18.

Let G=âˆIğ”¾iâ€‹(ki)ğºsubscriptproductğ¼subscriptğ”¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–G=\prod_{I}\mathbb{G}_{i}(k_{i}) where |I|<âˆğ¼|I|<\infty, each kisubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–k_{i} is a local field and each ğ”¾â€‹(ki)ğ”¾subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–\mathbb{G}(k_{i}) is a simple algebraic group defined over kisubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–k_{i}. Let Î“<GÎ“ğº\Gamma<G be a lattice. Then Î“Î“\Gamma has Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Remark 5.19.

We will actually only need Corollary 5.18 in the special case where |I|=2ğ¼2|I|=2, the lattice Î“=Î“1Ã—Î“2Î“subscriptÎ“1subscriptÎ“2\Gamma=\Gamma_{1}\times\Gamma_{2} is reducible and one factor Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} is a free group, viewed, for example, as a lattice in Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(2,â„)ğ‘†ğ¿2â„SL(2,\mathbb{R}) or Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(2,â„šp)ğ‘†ğ¿2subscriptâ„šğ‘SL(2,\mathbb{Q}_{p}). To construct superexpanders, the other factor Î“2subscriptÎ“2\Gamma_{2} will be a lattice in a higher rank simple pğ‘p-adic Lie group. To construct expanders, the choice of the second factor will be almost arbitrary.

5.6. Geometric cone

Finally, we prove stabilization up to conjugacy in the setting of a quasi-isometry of geometric cones, i.e. in the setting of Theorem 1.4. This proof is unrelated to the last few sections and to property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Recall that for t>0ğ‘¡0t>0, we have defined the maps

ft:Mtâ†’Nt:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡â†’subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡f_{t}:M_{t}\to N_{t}

and found there is t0>0subscriptğ‘¡00t_{0}>0 such that for any tâ‰¥t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t\geq t_{0}, the maps ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t} are uniformly coarsely Lipschitz (see Lemma 2.4). We obtain the following description for the induced maps Î¦t:=ftâ£âˆ—assignsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡âˆ—\Phi_{t}:=f_{t\ast} on coarse fundamental groups. Recall that the coarse fundamental group of a truncated cone is given by the group of lifts of the acting group (see Corollary 3.3). Therefore we can view Î¦Î¦\Phi and Î¦tsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡\Phi_{t} as maps Î“~â†’Î›~â†’~Î“~Î›\widetilde{\Gamma}\to\widetilde{\Lambda}.

Proposition 5.20.

For tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, we have Î¦t=Î¦subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡Î¦\Phi_{t}=\Phi. In particular {Ï†t}tsubscriptsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡\{\varphi_{t}\}_{t} stabilize.

Proof.

Recall that for t0>0subscriptğ‘¡00t_{0}>0, we have the truncated geometric cone ğ’¢t0â€‹(Î“â†·M):=(MÃ—[t0,âˆ)Ã—Î“)/Î“assignsubscriptğ’¢subscriptt0â†·Î“Mğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡0Î“Î“\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}:=(M\times[t_{0},\infty)\times\Gamma)/\Gamma. By Corollary 3.3, for any t>t0â‰«râ‰«1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0much-greater-thanğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t>t_{0}\gg r\gg 1, the inclusion map it:Mtâ†ªğ’¢t0â€‹(Î“â†·M):subscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â†ªsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptğ’¢subscriptt0â†·Î“Mi_{t}:M_{t}\hookrightarrow\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} induces an isomorphism on coarse fundamental group. It follows immediately that Ï†t:Î“â†’Î›:subscriptğœ‘ğ‘¡â†’Î“Î›\varphi_{t}:\Gamma\to\Lambda is given by the map Ï†:Î“â†’Î›:ğœ‘â†’Î“Î›\varphi:\Gamma\to\Lambda induced by fğ‘“f, and hence is independent of t>t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t>t_{0}. âˆ

6. Identification of growth rate by quasi-isometry

We will now start the proof of the Main Theorem 5.1. Therefore we assume we have (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“quasi-isometries fn:Mtnâ†’Nsn:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›â†’subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›f_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}} such that the induced maps Ï†n:Î“â†’Î›:subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›â†’Î“Î›\varphi_{n}:\Gamma\to\Lambda stabilize up to conjugation. In this section, we aim to prove tnsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t_{n} and snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›s_{n} grow at the same rate:

Proposition 6.1.

Assume the setting of Theorem 5.1. Then there exists Kâ‰¥1ğ¾1K\geq 1 such that

1Kâ‰¤sntnâ‰¤K.1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ¾\frac{1}{K}\leq\frac{s_{n}}{t_{n}}\leq K.
Proof.

It suffices to find an upper bound for sntnsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{s_{n}}{t_{n}}, since then a lower bound can be obtained by interchanging Mğ‘€M and Nğ‘N. Fix basepoints p0âˆˆMsubscriptğ‘0ğ‘€p_{0}\in M and q0âˆˆNsubscriptğ‘0ğ‘q_{0}\in N. By assumption, there are Î»nâˆˆÎ›subscriptğœ†ğ‘›Î›\lambda_{n}\in\Lambda such that the morphisms

Î»nâ€‹Ï†nâ€‹Î»nâˆ’1:Î“â†’Î›:subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›1â†’Î“Î›\lambda_{n}\varphi_{n}\lambda_{n}^{-1}:\Gamma\to\Lambda

lie in a finite set. Let Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi} be one of these morphisms and pass to the subsequence such that Î»nâ€‹Ï†nâ€‹Î»nâˆ’1=Ï†^subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›1^ğœ‘\lambda_{n}\varphi_{n}\lambda_{n}^{-1}=\widehat{\varphi}. Now let Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma be a generator and consider the rğ‘Ÿrâ€“loop

È·~Î“â€‹(Î³)=(p0,Î³â€‹p0,p1,â€¦,pâ„“,p0)subscript~italic-È·Î“ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘0\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(\gamma)=(p_{0},\gamma p_{0},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell},p_{0})

where p1:=Î³â€‹p0assignsubscriptğ‘1ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0p_{1}:=\gamma p_{0} and (p1,â€¦,pâ„“,p0)subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘0(p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell},p_{0}) is a discretization on the scale rtnğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{r}{t_{n}} of a minimizing geodesic from Î³â€‹p0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\gamma p_{0} to p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} in Mğ‘€M, and such that dMâ€‹(pi,pi+1)=rtnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›d_{M}(p_{i},p_{i+1})=\frac{r}{t_{n}} for every 1â‰¤i<â„“1ğ‘–â„“1\leq i<\ell. In particular, we have

dMâ€‹(p0,Î³â€‹p0)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\displaystyle d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0}) =dMâ€‹(pâ„“,p0)+âˆ‘1â‰¤i<â„“dMâ€‹(pi,pi+1)absentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘0subscript1ğ‘–â„“subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1\displaystyle=d_{M}(p_{\ell},p_{0})+\sum_{1\leq i<\ell}d_{M}(p_{i},p_{i+1})
â‰¥(â„“âˆ’1)â€‹rtn.absentâ„“1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\displaystyle\geq(\ell-1)\frac{r}{t_{n}}.

Let Dğ·D be the maximal displacement of a point under Î³ğ›¾\gamma. Rewriting the above inequality, we obtain

â„“â‰¤1+tnâ€‹Dr.â„“1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ·ğ‘Ÿ\ell\leq 1+t_{n}\frac{D}{r}. (6.1)

Applying fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} to È·Î“subscriptitalic-È·Î“\jmath_{\Gamma} , we obtain a loop Î²âˆˆÏ€1â€‹(Nsn,fnâ€‹(p0);Lâ€‹r+C)ğ›½subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶\beta\in\pi_{1}(N_{s_{n}},f_{n}(p_{0});Lr+C) with QÎ›â€‹(Î²)=Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)subscriptğ‘„Î›ğ›½subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾Q_{\Lambda}(\beta)=\varphi_{n}(\gamma). Consider its canonical form (see Definition 3.10)

ğ’â€‹(Î²)=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î²)âˆ—ğ’®â€‹(Î²).ğ’ğ›½âˆ—ğ’ªğ›½ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{C}(\beta)=\mathcal{O}(\beta)\ast\mathcal{S}(\beta).

Since the spatial component ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta) is a path from Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0)subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\varphi_{n}(\gamma)f_{n}(p_{0}) to p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}, its length is at least snâ€‹Î´subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ›¿s_{n}\delta, where Î´ğ›¿\delta is the minimal displacement of Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾\varphi_{n}(\gamma). Note that Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾\varphi_{n}(\gamma) is conjugate to Ï†^â€‹(Î³)^ğœ‘ğ›¾\widehat{\varphi}(\gamma), so Î´ğ›¿\delta does not depend on nğ‘›n. Hence the (Lâ€‹r+C)ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶(Lr+C)-path ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta) consists of at least snâ€‹Î´Lâ€‹r+Csubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ›¿ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶\frac{s_{n}\delta}{Lr+C} points.

On the other hand, È·Î“â€‹(Î³)subscriptitalic-È·Î“ğ›¾\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma) consists of â„“+3â„“3\ell+3 points, so ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta) consists of at most â„“+3â„“3\ell+3 points. Combining these two bounds on the number of points of ğ’®â€‹(Î²)ğ’®ğ›½\mathcal{S}(\beta), and also using the bound on â„“â„“\ell from Equation (6.1), we obtain

snâ€‹Î´Lâ€‹r+Câ‰¤â„“+3â‰¤4+tnâ€‹Drsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ›¿ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶â„“34subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ·ğ‘Ÿ\frac{s_{n}\delta}{Lr+C}\leq\ell+3\leq 4+t_{n}\frac{D}{r}

and hence

sntnâ‰¤4â€‹(Lâ€‹r+C)tn+DÎ´â€‹(L+Cr)â‰¤1+DÎ´â€‹(L+Cr),subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›4ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ·ğ›¿ğ¿ğ¶ğ‘Ÿ1ğ·ğ›¿ğ¿ğ¶ğ‘Ÿ\frac{s_{n}}{t_{n}}\leq\frac{4(Lr+C)}{t_{n}}+\frac{D}{\delta}\left(L+\frac{C}{r}\right)\leq 1+\frac{D}{\delta}\left(L+\frac{C}{r}\right),

(if tnâ‰¥4â€‹(Lâ€‹r+C)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›4ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¶t_{n}\geq 4(Lr+C)). Note that there are only finitely many possibilities for Î´ğ›¿\delta, because there are only finitely many options for Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi}. Taking the maximum of 1+DÎ´â€‹(L+Cr)1ğ·ğ›¿ğ¿ğ¶ğ‘Ÿ1+\frac{D}{\delta}\left(L+\frac{C}{r}\right) over all these choices of Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi} yields the desired upper bound. âˆ

7. Construction of a semiconjugacy

The goal of this section is to construct, under the assumptions of either Theorem 1.4 or Theorem 5.1, a semiconjugacy between the actions of Î“Î“\Gamma on Mğ‘€M and Î›Î›\Lambda on Nğ‘N. Recall that for tâ‰«râ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿmuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, we know that the coarse fundamental group of the level sets Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t} (resp. Ntsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡N_{t}) is given by the group of lifts Î“~~Î“\widetilde{\Gamma} (resp. Î›~~Î›\widetilde{\Lambda}). By assumption, we have maps fn:Mtnâ†’Nsn:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›â†’subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›f_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}} that are uniformly coarsely Lipschitz (in the setting of Theorem 1.4) or even uniform quasi-isometries (in the setting of Theorem 5.1). In this section, we will only need the uniformly coarsely Lipschitz property.

Further fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} induce morphisms on coarse fundamental group that descend to maps Ï†n:Î“â†’Î›:subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›â†’Î“Î›\varphi_{n}:\Gamma\to\Lambda that stabilize up to conjugation to a map Ï†^:Î“â†’Î›:^ğœ‘â†’Î“Î›\widehat{\varphi}:\Gamma\to\Lambda. In case of the setting of Theorem 5.1, we know by the results of the previous section that tnâ‰snasymptotically-equalssubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›t_{n}\asymp s_{n}. By modifying the quasi-isometry constants of fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} a bounded amount, we can assume that tn=snsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›t_{n}=s_{n}, which we will do for the rest of this section. We will refer to the coarse inverse of fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} as gnsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘›g_{n} and note that we all statements true of fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} are true of gnsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘›g_{n}. In this section we will prove:

Proposition 7.1.

Assume the setup of Theorem 1.4 or Theorem 5.1. Then there exists a Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant Lipschitz map f^:Mâ†’N:^ğ‘“â†’ğ‘€ğ‘\widehat{f}:M\to N. Moreover there is a Lipschitz map g^:Nâ†’M:^ğ‘”â†’ğ‘ğ‘€\widehat{g}:N\rightarrow M that we can construct to be Ï†^âˆ’1\widehat{\varphi}{{}^{-1}}-equivariant so that the composition g^âˆ˜f^:Mâ†’M:^ğ‘”^ğ‘“â†’ğ‘€ğ‘€\widehat{g}\circ\widehat{f}:M\rightarrow M is Î“Î“\Gamma equivariant.

Note that we do not claim that f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} is bi-Lipschitz. However, as noted by interchanging Mğ‘€M and Nğ‘N, we also obtain an equivariant Lipschitz map Nâ†’Mâ†’ğ‘ğ‘€N\to M. The real content of the last two sentences is that we can arrange for g^âˆ˜f^^ğ‘”^ğ‘“\widehat{g}\circ\widehat{f} to be equivariant for the fixed Î“Î“\Gamma action and not equivariant up to some automorphism of Î“Î“\Gamma. In the next section we will use this to show f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} is not only invertible and bi-Lipschitz but also affine.

We provide a brief outline of the proof of Proposition 7.1. In Section 4 we showed that for nâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘›1n\gg 1, the maps fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} respect the data of the extension

1â†’Ï€1â€‹(M)â†’Ï€1â€‹(Mtn;r)â†’Î“.â†’1subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€â†’subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿâ†’Î“1\to\pi_{1}(M)\to\pi_{1}(M_{t_{n}};r)\to\Gamma.

We use this to modify fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} to maps f~nsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widetilde{f}_{n} that are approximately continuous on the scale rtnğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{r}{t_{n}} (see Definition 7.2). More precisely, images under f~nsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widetilde{f}_{n} of points that are rtnğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{r}{t_{n}} close in Mğ‘€M, are distance at most âˆ¼rtnsimilar-toabsentğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\sim\frac{r}{t_{n}} apart (see Lemma 7.3). We modify these further to account for any inner automorphisms that are needed to obtain stabilization for Ï†nsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›\varphi_{n} (which are only assumed to stabilize up to conjugacy), which yields maps f^nsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›\widehat{f}_{n} that are still approximately continuous. The ArzelÃ -Ascoli theorem allows us to take a limit of the maps f^nsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›\widehat{f}_{n} to obtain a continuous map f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f}. Finally we show this map is equivariant with respect to the stabilization Ï†^:Î“â†’Î›:^ğœ‘â†’Î“Î›\widehat{\varphi}:\Gamma\to\Lambda of the maps Ï†nsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›\varphi_{n}.

We will now start by adjusting the coarsely Lipschitz maps fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} so that they are approximately continuous. Recall that for an rğ‘Ÿr-path Î±ğ›¼\alpha in Mğ‘€M, we have defined QÎ“â€‹(Î±)subscriptğ‘„Î“ğ›¼Q_{\Gamma}(\alpha) to be the product of the group elements that record local jumps along Î±ğ›¼\alpha (see Definition 3.5).

Definition 7.2.

Let nâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘›1n\gg 1 such that QÎ›subscriptğ‘„Î›Q_{\Lambda} is well-defined and let p0âˆˆMsubscriptğ‘0ğ‘€p_{0}\in M. Define the global adjustment f~nsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widetilde{f}_{n} of fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} as follows: Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be a discretization at the scale rtnğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{r}{t_{n}} of a path in Mğ‘€M from p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to pğ‘p. Then set

f~nâ€‹(p):=QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±)âˆ’1â€‹fnâ€‹(p).assignsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘„Î›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¼1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘\widetilde{f}_{n}(p):=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}f_{n}(p).

Now we can obtain the promised approximate continuity property of the global adjustment relative to the scale used. We start by showing that if two points in Mğ‘€M are nearby, their images under f~nsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widetilde{f}_{n} are close:

Lemma 7.3.

Assume that tn>2â€‹(C+1)Î´Î›â€‹(2â€‹C)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›2ğ¶1subscriptğ›¿Î›2ğ¶t_{n}>\frac{2(C+1)}{\delta_{\Lambda}(2C)}. Then for any x,yâˆˆMğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘€x,y\in M such that dMâ€‹(x,y)<1Lâ€‹tnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ‘¥ğ‘¦1ğ¿subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›d_{M}(x,y)<\frac{1}{Lt_{n}}, we have

dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(x),f~nâ€‹(y))â‰¤C+1tn.subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¥subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¦ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x),\widetilde{f}_{n}(y))\leq\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}.
Proof.

Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be a discretization on the scale rtnğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{r}{t_{n}} of a path in Mğ‘€M from p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to xğ‘¥x. Note that Î±âˆ—(y)âˆ—ğ›¼ğ‘¦\alpha\ast(y) is an rğ‘Ÿr-path from p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to yğ‘¦y, where we view (y)ğ‘¦(y) as a constant rğ‘Ÿr-path. Write Î³â€‹(x,y):=QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜(x,y))assignğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\gamma(x,y):=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ(x,y)), where again (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y) denotes an rğ‘Ÿr-path. Then we have

dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(x),f~nâ€‹(y))subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¥subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¦\displaystyle d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x),\widetilde{f}_{n}(y)) =dNâ€‹(QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±)âˆ’1â€‹fnâ€‹(x),QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜([Î±],y))âˆ’1â€‹fnâ€‹(y))absentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘„Î›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¼1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘„Î›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ›¼ğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¦\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}f_{n}(x),Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ([\alpha],y))^{-1}f_{n}(y)\right)
=dNâ€‹(QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±)âˆ’1â€‹fnâ€‹(x),QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±)âˆ’1â€‹Î³â€‹(x,y)âˆ’1â€‹fnâ€‹(y))absentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘„Î›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¼1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘„Î›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¼1ğ›¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¦\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}f_{n}(x),Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}\gamma(x,y)^{-1}f_{n}(y)\right)
=dNâ€‹(fnâ€‹(x),Î³â€‹(x,y)âˆ’1â€‹fnâ€‹(y))absentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¥ğ›¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¦\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(f_{n}(x),\gamma(x,y)^{-1}f_{n}(y)\right)
=dNâ€‹(Î³â€‹(x,y)â€‹fnâ€‹(x),fnâ€‹(y))absentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¦\displaystyle=d_{N}(\gamma(x,y)f_{n}(x),f_{n}(y))
â‰¤C+1tn.absentğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\displaystyle\leq\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}.

This proves the lemma.âˆ

We globalize the local approximate continuity property of the previous lemma:

Lemma 7.4.

f~nsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widetilde{f}_{n} is (Lâ€‹(C+1),C+1tn)ğ¿ğ¶1ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›(L(C+1),\frac{C+1}{t_{n}})-coarsely Lipschitz as a map between the manifolds (with metrics dM,dNsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘d_{M},d_{N}).

Proof.

Let p,qâˆˆMğ‘ğ‘ğ‘€p,q\in M. Let c:[0,D]â†’M:ğ‘â†’0ğ·ğ‘€c:[0,D]\to M be a distance-minimizing unit speed geodesic from pğ‘p to qğ‘q. We divide [0,D]0ğ·[0,D] into segments of length 1Lâ€‹tn1ğ¿subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{1}{Lt_{n}}, i.e. set tj:=jLâ€‹tnassignsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ¿subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t_{j}:=\frac{j}{Lt_{n}} with 0â‰¤jâ‰¤â„“0ğ‘—â„“0\leq j\leq\ell where â„“=âŒŠLâ€‹Dâ€‹tnâŒ‹â„“ğ¿ğ·subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\ell=\lfloor LDt_{n}\rfloor. Set xj:=câ€‹(tj)assignsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—x_{j}:=c(t_{j}). Then

dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(p),f~nâ€‹(q))â‰¤âˆ‘0â‰¤j<â„“(dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(xj),f~nâ€‹(xj+1)))+dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(xâ„“),f~nâ€‹(q)).subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘subscript0ğ‘—â„“subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥â„“subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(p),\widetilde{f}_{n}(q))\leq\sum_{0\leq j<\ell}\left(d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{j}),\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{j+1}))\right)+d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{\ell}),\widetilde{f}_{n}(q)). (7.1)

Since xj+1âˆˆBMâ€‹(xj;1Lâ€‹tn)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—1subscriptğµğ‘€subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—1ğ¿subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›x_{j+1}\in B_{M}(x_{j};\frac{1}{Lt_{n}}), by Lemma 7.3 we have

dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(xj),f~nâ€‹(xj+1))â‰¤C+1tn.subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—1ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{j}),\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{j+1}))\leq\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}.

Similarly we have

dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(xâ„“),f~nâ€‹(q))â‰¤C+1tn.subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥â„“subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{\ell}),\widetilde{f}_{n}(q))\leq\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}.

Using these estimates for every term on the right-hand side of Equation (7.1), and also using â„“â‰¤Dâ€‹Lâ€‹tnâ„“ğ·ğ¿subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\ell\leq DLt_{n}, we obtain

dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(p),f~nâ€‹(q))subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘\displaystyle d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(p),\widetilde{f}_{n}(q)) â‰¤â„“â€‹C+1tn+C+1tnabsentâ„“ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\displaystyle\leq\ell\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}+\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}
â‰¤Lâ€‹(C+1)â€‹D+C+1tn,absentğ¿ğ¶1ğ·ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\displaystyle\leq L(C+1)D+\frac{C+1}{t_{n}},

as desired. âˆ

The maps f~nsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widetilde{f}_{n} are not very nicely related yet, because the maps Ï†n:Î“â†’Î›:subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›â†’Î“Î›\varphi_{n}:\Gamma\to\Lambda do not coincide. However, by assumption Ï†nsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›\varphi_{n} stabilize up to conjugation, and we will use this to construct a better sequence of adjustments:

Construction 7.5.

Because Ï†nsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘›\varphi_{n} stabilize up to conjugation, there exist Î»nâˆˆÎ›subscriptğœ†ğ‘›Î›\lambda_{n}\in\Lambda such that {cÎ»nâˆ˜Ï†n}subscriptğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›\{c_{\lambda_{n}}\circ\varphi_{n}\} constitute a finite set of morphisms. Here cÎ»nsubscriptğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘›c_{\lambda_{n}} denotes conjugation by Î»nsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›\lambda_{n}. After passing to a subsequence we can assume that Ï†^:=cÎ»nâˆ˜Ï†nassign^ğœ‘subscriptğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›\widehat{\varphi}:=c_{\lambda_{n}}\circ\varphi_{n} is independent of nğ‘›n. Also define f^n:Mâ†’N:subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›â†’ğ‘€ğ‘\widehat{f}_{n}:M\to N by f^nâ€‹(p):=Î»nâ€‹f~nâ€‹(p)assignsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘\widehat{f}_{n}(p):=\lambda_{n}\widetilde{f}_{n}(p).

Since Î»nsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›\lambda_{n} acts isometrically on Nğ‘N and f~nsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widetilde{f}_{n} are (Lâ€‹(C+1),C+1tn)ğ¿ğ¶1ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›(L(C+1),\frac{C+1}{t_{n}})-coarsely Lipschitz by Lemma 7.4, the new adjustments f^n:=Î»nâ€‹f~nassignsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widehat{f}_{n}:=\lambda_{n}\widetilde{f}_{n} are also (Lâ€‹(C+1),C+1tn)ğ¿ğ¶1ğ¶1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›(L(C+1),\frac{C+1}{t_{n}})-coarsely Lipschitz. Note in particular that the multiplicative constants are uniformly bounded. Therefore if the additive constants all vanished, we could use the ArzelÃ -Ascoli theorem to obtain a limit map (along a subsequence). Unfortunately the additive constants are in general nonzero â€“ however, they still tend to 0 as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty. This is enough to push through the proof of the ArzelÃ -Ascoli theorem, and hence there is a subsequence such that

f^nâ†’f^â†’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›^ğ‘“\widehat{f}_{n}\to\widehat{f}

uniformly. Further f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} is Lâ€‹(C+1)ğ¿ğ¶1L(C+1)-Lipschitz. The rest of the section is devoted to proving that f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} is Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant, which completes the proof that f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} is a semiconjugacy between Î“â†·Mâ†·Î“ğ‘€\Gamma\curvearrowright M and Î›â†·Nâ†·Î›ğ‘\Lambda\curvearrowright N. We start by showing that f~nsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›\widetilde{f}_{n} and f^nsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›\widehat{f}_{n} satisfy approximate equivariance properties on the orbit of the basepoint p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}:

Lemma 7.6.

Let Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma. Then for any nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1, we have

(i)ğ‘–\displaystyle(i)\qquad dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€‹f~nâ€‹(p0))â‰¤(L+C)â€‹â€–Î³â€–tn,subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0ğ¿ğ¶normğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\displaystyle d_{N}\left(\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0}),\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right)\leq\frac{(L+C)\|\gamma\|}{t_{n}},
(iâ€‹i)ğ‘–ğ‘–\displaystyle(ii)\qquad dNâ€‹(f^nâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),Ï†^â€‹(Î³)â€‹f^nâ€‹(p0))â‰¤(L+C)â€‹â€–Î³â€–tn.subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0^ğœ‘ğ›¾subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0ğ¿ğ¶normğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\displaystyle d_{N}\left(\widehat{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0}),\widehat{\varphi}(\gamma)\widehat{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right)\enspace\leq\frac{(L+C)\|\gamma\|}{t_{n}}.
Proof.

We prove (i). We obtain two rğ‘Ÿr-paths Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta in Mtnsubscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›M_{t_{n}} from p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to Î³â€‹p0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\gamma p_{0} as follows. Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be the discretization at the scale rtnğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{r}{t_{n}} of a continuous path in Mğ‘€M from p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} to Î³â€‹p0ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\gamma p_{0}, and let Î²ğ›½\beta be the shortest path in the Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“orbit of p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} obtained by writing Î³ğ›¾\gamma as a word in the generators. As usual, Î±Â¯Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\alpha} denotes the reverse of Î±ğ›¼\alpha. The concatenation Î²âˆ—Î±Â¯âˆ—ğ›½Â¯ğ›¼\beta\ast\overline{\alpha} is a loop based at p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} representing È·Î“â€‹(Î³)subscriptitalic-È·Î“ğ›¾\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma) in Ï€1â€‹(M,p0;r)subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘0ğ‘Ÿ\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r). Hence we have

f~nâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0)=QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±)âˆ’1â€‹fnâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0)=QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±Â¯)â€‹fnâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘„Î›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¼1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›Â¯ğ›¼subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}\,f_{n}(\gamma p_{0})=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\overline{\alpha})\,f_{n}(\gamma p_{0}),

and

Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€‹f~nâ€‹(p0)=QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜(Î²âˆ—Î±Â¯))â€‹ftâ€‹(p0)=QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±Â¯)â€‹QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0).subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½Â¯ğ›¼subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›Â¯ğ›¼subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\,\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ(\beta*\overline{\alpha}))\,f_{t}(p_{0})=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\overline{\alpha})\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)f_{n}(p_{0}).

Hence we have

dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€‹f~nâ€‹(p0))subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\displaystyle d_{N}\left(\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right) =\displaystyle=
dNâ€‹(QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±Â¯)â€‹fnâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î±Â¯)â€‹QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0))subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›Â¯ğ›¼subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›Â¯ğ›¼subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\displaystyle d_{N}(Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\overline{\alpha})\,f_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\overline{\alpha})\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0}))
=dNâ€‹(fnâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0)).absentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\displaystyle=d_{N}(f_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0})).

We will now bound the latter quantity by exhibiting a path in Nğ‘N from QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0)subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0}) to fnâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0f_{n}(\gamma p_{0}) whose length we can bound. Indeed, consider the canonical form

ğ’â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)=ğ’ªâ€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)âˆ—ğ’®â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)ğ’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½âˆ—ğ’ªsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½ğ’®subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½\mathcal{C}(f_{n}\circ\beta)=\mathcal{O}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\ast\mathcal{S}(f_{n}\circ\beta)

of fnâˆ˜Î²subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½f_{n}\circ\beta (see Definition 3.10). Recall that ğ’®â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)ğ’®subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½\mathcal{S}(f_{n}\circ\beta) starts at QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0)subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0}), ends at fnâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0f_{n}(\gamma p_{0}), and by Lemma 3.12 has length at most

â„“â€‹(ğ’®â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²))â„“ğ’®subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½\displaystyle\ell(\mathcal{S}(f_{n}\circ\beta)) â‰¤â„“â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)absentâ„“subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½\displaystyle\leq\ell(f_{n}\circ\beta)
â‰¤â„“â€‹(Î²)â€‹(L+C)=(L+C)â€‹â€–Î³â€–.absentâ„“ğ›½ğ¿ğ¶ğ¿ğ¶normğ›¾\displaystyle\leq\ell(\beta)(L+C)=(L+C)\|\gamma\|.

Therefore

dNâ€‹(fnâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),QÎ›â€‹(fnâˆ˜Î²)â€‹fnâ€‹(p0))â‰¤(L+C)â€‹â€–Î³â€–tn,subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘„Î›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›½subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0ğ¿ğ¶normğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›d_{N}(f_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0}))\leq\frac{(L+C)\|\gamma\|}{t_{n}},

which completes the proof of (i). The bound in (ii) follows easily:

dNâ€‹(f^nâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),Ï†^â€‹(Î³)â€‹f^nâ€‹(p0))subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0^ğœ‘ğ›¾subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\displaystyle d_{N}\left(\widehat{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,\widehat{\varphi}(\gamma)\,\widehat{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right) =dNâ€‹(Î»nâ€‹f~nâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),(Î»nâ€‹Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€‹Î»nâˆ’1)â€‹Î»nâ€‹f~nâ€‹(p0))absentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›1subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(\lambda_{n}\,\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,(\lambda_{n}\,\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\,\lambda_{n}^{-1})\,\lambda_{n}\,\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right)
=dNâ€‹(f~nâ€‹(Î³â€‹p0),Ï†nâ€‹(Î³)â€‹f~nâ€‹(p0))absentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ›¾subscriptğ‘0subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ›¾subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\,\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right)
â‰¤(L+C)â€‹â€–Î³â€–tn.absentğ¿ğ¶normğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\displaystyle\leq\frac{(L+C)\|\gamma\|}{t_{n}}.

âˆ

We complete the proof that f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} is a semiconjugacy between the actions by showing it is Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant.

Proof of Proposition 7.1.

By taking the limit as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty in Lemma 7.6.(ii), we see that f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} is Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant on the orbit of p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}. Since Î“â€‹p0Î“subscriptğ‘0\Gamma p_{0} is dense in Mğ‘€M, it follows immediately that f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} is Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant.
