We can construct a map g^â€²superscript^ğ‘”â€²\widehat{g}^{\prime} simply by applying the same process to the gnsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘›g_{n} as we did to fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n}. We can do this for the same subsequence as used in Construction 7.5. We will use Ïˆğœ“\psi to denote the resulting map from Î›â†’Î“â†’Î›Î“\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma since at this point it is unclear that Ïˆğœ“\psi is Ï†^âˆ’1\widehat{\varphi}{{}^{-1}}. By choosing the same subsequence as in Construction 7.5, we guarantee that Ï†^âˆ˜Ï•^^ğœ‘^italic-Ï•\widehat{\varphi}\circ\widehat{\phi} is an inner automorphism given by cÎ³subscriptğ‘ğ›¾c_{\gamma} for some element Î³âˆˆÎ“ğ›¾Î“\gamma\in\Gamma. Letting g^=Î³âˆ˜g^â€²^ğ‘”ğ›¾superscript^ğ‘”â€²\widehat{g}=\gamma\circ\widehat{g}^{\prime}, we obtain the desired conclusion. âˆ

8. Promotion of the semiconjugacy

In this section, we will complete the proofs of the Main Theorems 1.4 and 5.1. At this point we have an isomorphism Ï†^:Î“â†’Î›:^ğœ‘â†’Î“Î›\widehat{\varphi}:\Gamma\to\Lambda and a Ï†^^ğœ‘\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant Lipschitz map f^:Mâ†’N:^ğ‘“â†’ğ‘€ğ‘\widehat{f}:M\to N. We will use algebraic methods to promote the map f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} to an affine conjugacy. Here we say a map is affine if it respects the structure of the homogeneous spaces. More precisely:

Definition 8.1.

Given homogeneous spaces G/Hğºğ»G/H and K/Cğ¾ğ¶K/C, a map f:G/Hâ†’K/C:ğ‘“â†’ğºğ»ğ¾ğ¶f:G/H\rightarrow K/C is affine if there exists a homomorphism Ï€:Gâ†’K:ğœ‹â†’ğºğ¾\pi:G\rightarrow K and an element kâˆˆKğ‘˜ğ¾k\in K such that fâ€‹(xâ€‹H)=kâ‹…Ï€â€‹(x)â€‹Hğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ»â‹…ğ‘˜ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ»f(xH)=k\cdot\pi(x)H. If fğ‘“f is surjective, we call the map an affine submersion, and if fğ‘“f is a diffeomorphism we call fğ‘“f an affine isomorphism.

The following result shows that in the setting of homogeneous dynamics, semiconjugacies are affine submersions.

Lemma 8.2.

Let GğºG and Kğ¾K be compact groups, and let H<Gğ»ğºH<G (resp. C<Kğ¶ğ¾C<K) be a closed subgroup that contains no nontrivial closed normal subgroup of GğºG (resp. Kğ¾K). Further let Î“Î“\Gamma (resp. Î›Î›\Lambda) be a dense subgroup of GğºG (resp. Kğ¾K) and assume f:G/Hâ†’K/C:ğ‘“â†’ğºğ»ğ¾ğ¶f:G/H\rightarrow K/C is a continuous map that is equivariant with respect to an isomorphism Ï:Î“â†’Î›:ğœŒâ†’Î“Î›\rho:\Gamma\rightarrow\Lambda. Then fğ‘“f is an affine submersion.

Proof.

Since Î›Î›\Lambda is dense in Kğ¾K and ÏğœŒ\rho is an isomorphism, fğ‘“f is onto. The map Ï:Î“â†’K:ğœŒâ†’Î“ğ¾\rho:\Gamma\rightarrow K defines a map graphâ¡(Ï):Î“â†’GÃ—K:graphğœŒâ†’Î“ğºğ¾\operatorname{graph}(\rho):\Gamma\rightarrow G\times K. Let Lğ¿L be the closure of graphâ¡(Ï)â€‹(Î“)graphğœŒÎ“\operatorname{graph}(\rho)(\Gamma). Then Lğ¿L projects onto both GğºG and Kğ¾K as Î“Î“\Gamma is dense in GğºG and Î›Î›\Lambda is dense in Kğ¾K. We will see that Lğ¿L is the graph of a homomorphism from GğºG to Kğ¾K. Note that we can also define graphâ¡(f)graphğ‘“\operatorname{graph}(f) as the subset of G/HÃ—K/Cğºğ»ğ¾ğ¶G/H\times K/C of the form (x,fâ€‹(x))ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥(x,f(x)). As fğ‘“f is continuous and ÏğœŒ\rhoâ€“equivariant, graphâ¡(f)graphğ‘“\operatorname{graph}(f) is closed and graphâ¡(Ï)graphğœŒ\operatorname{graph}(\rho)â€“invariant, and therefore also Lğ¿Lâ€“invariant. Consider the projections Ï€1:GÃ—Kâ†’G:subscriptğœ‹1â†’ğºğ¾ğº\pi_{1}:G\times K\rightarrow G and Ï€2:GÃ—Kâ†’K:subscriptğœ‹2â†’ğºğ¾ğ¾\pi_{2}:G\times K\rightarrow K and denote their restrictions to Lğ¿L by Ï€iLsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘–ğ¿\pi_{i}^{L}, i=1,2ğ‘–12i=1,2. Also consider the projections p1:G/HÃ—K/Câ†’G/H:subscriptğ‘1â†’ğºğ»ğ¾ğ¶ğºğ»p_{1}:G/H\times K/C\rightarrow G/H and p2:G/HÃ—K/Câ†’K/C:subscriptğ‘2â†’ğºğ»ğ¾ğ¶ğ¾ğ¶p_{2}:G/H\times K/C\rightarrow K/C and notice that p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1} is one-to-one when restricted to graphâ¡(f)graphğ‘“\operatorname{graph}(f). This immediately implies that kerâ¡(Ï€1L)kernelsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹1ğ¿\ker(\pi_{1}^{L}) is trivial since Lğ¿L acts effectively on graphâ¡(f)graphğ‘“\operatorname{graph}(f) by the assumption on the absence of normal subgroups in Hğ»H and Cğ¶C. Now we can define a map Ï^:Ï€2âˆ˜(Ï€1L):âˆ’1Gâ†’K\widehat{\rho}:\pi_{2}\circ(\pi^{L}_{1}){{}^{-1}}:G\rightarrow K which is a homomorphism extending ÏğœŒ\rho and whose graph is Lğ¿L. The graphâ¡(Ï^)graph^ğœŒ\operatorname{graph}(\widehat{\rho})â€“invariance of graphâ¡(f)graphğ‘“\operatorname{graph}(f) then exactly means that fğ‘“f is Ï^^ğœŒ\widehat{\rho}â€“equivariant. âˆ

The difficulty with Lemma 8.2 for applications is that it might be the case that G=G1Ã—G2ğºsubscriptğº1subscriptğº2G=G_{1}\times G_{2} and K=G1ğ¾subscriptğº1K=G_{1} and the semiconjugacy is given by projection onto the first factor. In the setting of our theorems, the fact that the quasi-isometry has a coarse inverse allows us to rule out this kind of behavior because we also have a semiconjugacy in the other direction. In conjunction with the last statement in Proposition 7.1 the following result, which gives a criterion for promoting a semiconjugacy to an affine conjugacy, finishes the proofs of the Main Theorems 1.4 and 5.1.

Corollary 8.3.

Let GğºG and Kğ¾K be compact groups, and let H<Gğ»ğºH<G (resp. C<Kğ¶ğ¾C<K) be a closed subgroup that contains no nontrivial closed normal subgroup of GğºG (resp. Kğ¾K). Further let Î“Î“\Gamma (resp. Î›Î›\Lambda) be a dense subgroup of GğºG (resp. Kğ¾K) and assume there is a isomorphism Ï:Î“â†’Î›:ğœŒâ†’Î“Î›\rho:\Gamma\rightarrow\Lambda and a continuous ÏğœŒ\rho-equivariant map f:G/Hâ†’K/C:ğ‘“â†’ğºğ»ğ¾ğ¶f:G/H\rightarrow K/C and also a continuous Ïâˆ’1\rho{{}^{-1}}-equivariant map h:K/Câ†’G/H:â„â†’ğ¾ğ¶ğºğ»h:K/C\rightarrow G/H. Then fğ‘“f and hâ„h are affine isomorphisms.

Proof.

We consider the map fâˆ˜h:G/Hâ†’G/H:ğ‘“â„â†’ğºğ»ğºğ»f\circ h:G/H\rightarrow G/H and follow the proof of Lemma 8.2. In this context, the map ÏğœŒ\rho is the identity map from Î“Î“\Gamma to itself and so graphâ¡(Ï)graphğœŒ\operatorname{graph}(\rho) is the diagonal embedding of Î“Î“\Gamma in GÃ—GğºğºG\times G and the closure Lğ¿L of graphâ¡(Ï)graphğœŒ\operatorname{graph}(\rho) is GğºG embedded diagonally in GÃ—GğºğºG\times G. Therefore the map Ï^^ğœŒ\widehat{\rho} is the identity map on GğºG and this immediately implies fâˆ˜hğ‘“â„f\circ h is an affine isomorphism. By Lemma 8.2, both fğ‘“f and hâ„h are affine submersions. If the composition of two affine submersions is an affine isomorphism, both maps are affine isomorphisms. âˆ

9. Construction of families of expanders

In this section we show how to apply Theorem 5.1 to construct expanders with a wide variety of distinct geometries. The main point is to construct large families of group actions that are not conjugate for groups where we can show quasi-isometry of warped cones implies algebraic conjugacy of actions.

9.1. Outline

To construct a continuum of non-isomorphic actions with various spectral properties, we will use the following construction. Let Kğ¾K be a simple compact group and Î”<KÎ”ğ¾\Delta<K a fixed subgroup. We will consider a free group Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} and recall that a generic homomorphism of Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} to Kğ¾K is faithful with dense image. We then consider left-right actions Î”Ã—FnÎ”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Delta\times F_{n} on Kğ¾K where Î”Î”\Delta acts on the left and Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} acts on the right. We observe that this action can also be written as a left action of Î”Ã—FnÎ”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Delta\times F_{n} on (KÃ—K)/diagâ¡(K)ğ¾ğ¾diagğ¾(K\times K)/\operatorname{diag}(K), making it clear that the action fits into our setting of minimal isometric actions on homogeneous spaces. We will show that a generic choice of Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} in Kğ¾K gives rise to a free action. Theorem 5.1 shows that any pair of such actions with quasi-isometric warped cones are conjugate by an affine map. By making judicious choices of Î”Î”\Delta, we can guarantee sufficient spectral properties so that results of Sawicki and Vigolo allow us to show that the level sets of the cones are expanders or superexpanders [Saw1, Vig1].

9.2. Spectral gaps, (super)expanders, reductions to algebraic constructions

In this subsection we recall some definitions concerning spectral gaps, expanders and superexpanders and the connections between them and warped cones. At the end of the subsection we reduce the proofs of Theorems 1.7 and 1.8 to the existence of continuous families of non-conjugate actions of well-chosen groups. The more expert reader may choose to skip to Proposition 9.4 and read only reductions which follow easily from known results.

Definition 9.1.

Given a class of Banach spaces â„°â„°\mathcal{E} of Banach spaces we say that a sequence of graphs Gn=(Vn,En)subscriptğºğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›subscriptğ¸ğ‘›G_{n}=(V_{n},E_{n}) is an expander family for â„°â„°\mathcal{E} if

  1. (1)

    |Vn|â†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›|V_{n}|\rightarrow\infty, and there exists k>1ğ‘˜1k>1 such that each Gnsubscriptğºğ‘›G_{n} is has degree bounded by kğ‘˜k, and

  2. (2)

    given any Eğ¸E in â„°â„°\mathcal{E} there are p,Î·>0ğ‘ğœ‚0p,\eta>0 such that for any family of maps fn:Vnâ†’E:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›â†’subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ¸f_{n}:V_{n}\rightarrow E we have

    1|Vn|2â€‹âˆ‘(u,v)âˆˆVnÃ—Vnâ€–(fnâ€‹(u),fnâ€‹(v))â€–Epâ‰¤Î·kâ€‹|Vn|â€‹âˆ‘(u,v)âˆˆEnâ€–(fnâ€‹(u),fnâ€‹(v))â€–Ep.1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘£subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘£ğ¸ğ‘ğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘£subscriptğ¸ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘£ğ¸ğ‘\frac{1}{|V_{n}|^{2}}\sum_{(u,v)\in V_{n}\times V_{n}}\|(f_{n}(u),f_{n}(v))\|_{E}^{p}\leq\frac{\eta}{k|V_{n}|}\sum_{(u,v)\in E_{n}}\|(f_{n}(u),f_{n}(v))\|_{E}^{p}.

The standard definition of an expander or expander sequence is a family of graphs that is an expander for a separable Hilbert space. It is standard to call a family of graphs a superexpander if it is expander for the class Eğ¸E of uniformly convex Banach spaces. Our results here work equally well if a superexpander is defined to be an expander of the class Eğ¸E of all Banach spaces of nontrivial type.

Given an action of a group Î“Î“\Gamma on a measure space (X,Î¼)ğ‘‹ğœ‡(X,\mu), one has a natural unitary representation ÏğœŒ\rho on L2â€‹(X,Î¼)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡L^{2}(X,\mu). Furthermore, given any Banach space Eğ¸E, one can form the space of square-integrable Eğ¸E-valued functions L2â€‹(X,Î¼,E)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡ğ¸L^{2}(X,\mu,E) and Î“Î“\Gamma has a natural isometric representation ÏğœŒ\rho on L2â€‹(X,Î¼,E)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡ğ¸L^{2}(X,\mu,E) by pre-composition. The first representation is in fact the case of E=â„ğ¸â„E=\mathbb{R} or â„‚â„‚\mathbb{C}. For Î“Î“\Gamma finitely generated by a set Sğ‘†S, we say that the Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“action on L2â€‹(X,Î¼,E)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡ğ¸L^{2}(X,\mu,E) has a spectral gap if

supÎ³âˆˆSâ€–Ïâ€‹(Î³)â€‹vâˆ’vâ€–â‰¥Ïµâ€‹â€–vâ€–.subscriptsupremumğ›¾ğ‘†normğœŒğ›¾ğ‘£ğ‘£italic-Ïµnormğ‘£\sup_{\gamma\in S}\|\rho(\gamma)v-v\|\geq\epsilon\|v\|.
Proposition 9.2.

If Î”<Î”â€²Î”superscriptÎ”â€²\Delta<\Delta^{\prime} are finitely generated groups and we have an action of Î”â€²superscriptÎ”â€²\Delta^{\prime} on a space (X,Î¼)ğ‘‹ğœ‡(X,\mu) where the restriction of the action to Î”Î”\Delta has a spectral gap on L2â€‹(X,Î¼,E)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡ğ¸L^{2}(X,\mu,E), then the Î”â€²superscriptÎ”â€²\Delta^{\prime}â€“action does as well.

In [Vig1], Vigolo gives a systematic treatment of how to discretize level sets of warped cones to produce expander graphs. We call these discretizations the geometric graphs corresponding to the Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“action on Xğ‘‹X. We use the following result which combines results of Sawicki and Vigolo, see also papers of Nowakâ€“Sawicki and De Laatâ€“Vigolo [NS, Vig1, Saw1, dLV] for related developments. Special cases of the following proposition were certainly known before these works and the basic ideas seem to go back to the earliest days of the subject.

Proposition 9.3.

Let a finitely generated group Î“Î“\Gamma act on a compact metric space Mğ‘€M preserving a Radon measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu and with a spectral gap on L2â€‹(X,Î¼)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡L^{2}(X,\mu). Then there exist constants L>1ğ¿1L>1 and C>0ğ¶0C>0 and graphs Gnsubscriptğºğ‘›G_{n} such that Gnsubscriptğºğ‘›G_{n} is (L,C)ğ¿ğ¶(L,C)â€“quasi-isometric to the level set Xnsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X_{n} in the warped cone ğ’â€‹(Î“â†·X)ğ’â†·Î“ğ‘‹\mathcal{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright X) and such that the family of graphs {Gn}subscriptğºğ‘›\{G_{n}\} is an expander sequence. We call these graphs the geometric graphs for the action of Î“Î“\Gamma on Mğ‘€M.

The Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“action on L2â€‹(X,Î¼,E)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡ğ¸L^{2}(X,\mu,E) has a spectral gap if and only if the geometric graphs for the Î“Î“\Gamma action on Mğ‘€M are expanders with respect to Eğ¸E.

Finally we remark that if Eğ¸E is a Hilbert space, then it is easy to see that a spectral gap on L2â€‹(X,Î¼)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡L^{2}(X,\mu) is equivalent to one on L2â€‹(X,Î¼,E)superscriptğ¿2ğ‘‹ğœ‡ğ¸L^{2}(X,\mu,E).

To state our key reductions, we need two more definitions. Given two groups Î“Î“\Gamma and Î”Î”\Delta where Î“,Î”<KÎ“Î”ğ¾\Gamma,\Delta<K we define the left-right action of Î“Ã—Î”Î“Î”\Gamma\times\Delta on Kğ¾K by acting on the left by Î“Î“\Gamma and on the right by Î”Î”\Delta. Given two actions Ï1subscriptğœŒ1\rho_{1} and Ï2subscriptğœŒ2\rho_{2} of a single group Î”Î”\Delta on a space Xğ‘‹X we say the actions are conjugate up to automorphism if there exists an automorphism Ïˆ:Î”â†’Î”:ğœ“â†’Î”Î”\psi:\Delta\rightarrow\Delta such that Ï1â€‹(Î´)=Ï2â€‹(Ïˆâ€‹(Î´))subscriptğœŒ1ğ›¿subscriptğœŒ2ğœ“ğ›¿\rho_{1}(\delta)=\rho_{2}(\psi(\delta)) for any Î´ğ›¿\delta in Î”Î”\Delta. This corrects a small discrepancy in standard terminology where a conjugacy between actions of a priori different groups involves a homomorphism identifying the groups but a conjugacy between two actions of the same group implicitly assumes the identification Ïˆğœ“\psi is the identity.

Proposition 9.4.

To prove Theorem 1.7 it suffices to produce a finitely presented dense subgroup Î“Î“\Gamma of a compact group Kğ¾K with a spectral gap on L2â€‹(K)superscriptğ¿2ğ¾L^{2}(K) such that Î“Î“\Gamma has property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} and there is a continuum of free left-right actions of Î“Ã—FnÎ“subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Gamma\times F_{n} on Kğ¾K which are not conjugate up to automorphism for some k>1ğ‘˜1k>1.

Proposition 9.5.

To prove Theorem 1.8 it suffices to produce a finitely presented dense subgroup Î“Î“\Gamma of a compact group Kğ¾K where Î“Î“\Gamma has strong property (T)ğ‘‡(T) and property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} such that there is a continuum of left-right actions of Î“Ã—FnÎ“subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Gamma\times F_{n} on Kğ¾K which are not conjugate up to automorphism for some k>1ğ‘˜1k>1.

Both propositions follow immediately from Propositions 9.3, Proposition 9.2, Theorem 1.5 and Corollary 5.18.

9.3. Genericity of freely acting, dense subgroups

Note that Kğ¾K as a compact group is also a real algebraic group. We will write Homâ¡(Fn,K)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) for the representation variety of homomorphisms of Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} into Kğ¾K and Homâ¡(Fn,K)/â£/KHomsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K for the character variety. Note that we take the geometric invariant theory quotient here, but that for compact groups this is the same as the set theoretic one. Also observe that Homâ¡(Fn,K)â‰…KnHomsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾superscriptğ¾ğ‘›\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\cong K^{n} as varieties and so one can think of Homâ¡(Fn,K)/â£/KHomsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K as Kn/â£/Ksuperscriptğ¾ğ‘›ğ¾K^{n}\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K where Kğ¾K action on Knsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘›K^{n} is by simultaneous conjugation in all coordinates. Elements of Kn/Ksuperscriptğ¾ğ‘›ğ¾K^{n}/K are often called multidimensional conjugacy classes and the action of Kğ¾K on Knsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘›K^{n} by simultaneous conjugation will be referred to as simply conjugation below.

Lemma 9.6.

  1. (1)

    The subset of Homâ¡(Fn,K)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) consisting of dense, faithful representations is the complement of a countable union of proper subvarieties.

  2. (2)

    Fix a countable subgroup Î”âŠ†KÎ”ğ¾\Delta\subseteq K. The subset of Homâ¡(Fn,K)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) such that the left-right action of Î”Ã—FnÎ”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Delta\times F_{n} on Kğ¾K is free is the complement of a countable union of proper subvarieties.

  3. (3)

    Let K=Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(n)ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘ˆğ‘›K=SU(n) and fix a countable dense subgroup Î”âŠ†KÎ”ğ¾\Delta\subseteq K. Then there exists VâŠ‚Kğ‘‰ğ¾V\subset K that is a countable union of subvarieties such that if xâˆ‰Vğ‘¥ğ‘‰x\notin V, we have âŸ¨Î”,xâŸ©â‰…Î”âˆ—â„¤Î”ğ‘¥Î”â„¤\langle\Delta,x\rangle\cong\Delta*\mathbb{Z}.

Proof.

We note that (1)1(1) is standard and provide a proof for completeness and also to motivate the proof of (2)2(2). We note that up to conjugacy, Kğ¾K has only countably many closed subgroups Cğ¶C and any of these is an algebraic subgroup, so that Homâ¡(Fn,C)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¶\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},C) is a proper subvariety of Homâ¡(Fn,K)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K). Furthermore the set of representations of Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} into any conjugate of Cğ¶C in Kğ¾K can be identified with the Kğ¾Kâ€“conjugates of Homâ¡(Fn,C)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¶\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},C) in Homâ¡(Fn,K)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K), so the set of homomorphisms of Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} into any conjugate of Cğ¶C is a proper subvariety of Homâ¡(Fn,K)/â£/KHomsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K. This shows that the set representations whose image is not dense, is a countable union of closed subvarieties. We now check that the set of representations that are not faithful is also contained in a (different) countable union of closed subvarieties, which suffices to prove the first claim. For any word wâˆˆFnğ‘¤subscriptğ¹ğ‘›w\in F_{n}, denote by Vâ€‹(w)âŠ†Homâ¡(Fn,K)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾V(w)\subseteq\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) the set of representations that vanish on wğ‘¤w. The word map evw:Homâ¡(Fn,K)â†’K:subscriptevğ‘¤â†’Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾ğ¾\text{ev}_{w}:\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\rightarrow K that evaluates a representation on the word wğ‘¤w is clearly a rational map. It follows that Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w) is a closed subvariety of Homâ¡(Fn,K)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K). Further note there are only countably many words in Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n}, so it remains to show that Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w) is a proper subvariety for every wğ‘¤w.

To do so, it suffices to exhibit a single faithful Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} in Kğ¾K, i.e. a single point not in Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w). To motivate the proof of (2)2(2) we proceed differently. We recall a theorem of Borel that says that the map evw:Homâ¡(Fn,K)â†’K:subscriptevğ‘¤â†’Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾ğ¾\text{ev}_{w}:\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\rightarrow K is not only rational but dominant [Bor]. This implies the image is Zariskiâ€“dense and in particular that not every point maps to the identity, proving that Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w) is proper. Since Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w) and its complement are both conjugation invariant, this proves that the image of Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w) in the character variety is also a proper subvariety.

We now analyze stabilizers of the left-right action of Î”Ã—FnÎ”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Delta\times F_{n} on Kğ¾K in order to be able to apply Borelâ€™s theorem again. Computing, we see that Î´cÎ³=âˆ’1c\delta c\gamma{{}^{-1}}=c if and only if Î´=câ€‹Î³âˆ’1â€‹cğ›¿ğ‘superscriptğ›¾1ğ‘\delta=c{{}^{-1}}\gamma c. I.e. fixing an element Î´âˆˆÎ”ğ›¿Î”\delta\in\Delta, the set of elements Î³ğ›¾\gamma in Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} where the left-right action of (Î´,Î³)ğ›¿ğ›¾(\delta,\gamma) has a fixed point is the set of elements Î³ğ›¾\gamma whose image is a conjugate of Î´ğ›¿\delta. We fix an enumeration {Î´i}iâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘–â„•\{\delta_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}} of Î”Î”\Delta. For any word wâˆˆFnğ‘¤subscriptğ¹ğ‘›w\in F_{n}, the set of representations of Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n} into Kğ¾K where the image of wğ‘¤w is conjugate to Î´isubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\delta_{i} is the subset Wâ€‹(w,i)ğ‘Šğ‘¤ğ‘–W(w,i) of Homâ¡(Fn,K)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) where evwâ€‹(k1,â€¦,kn)subscriptevğ‘¤subscriptğ‘˜1â€¦subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘›\text{ev}_{w}(k_{1},\ldots,k_{n}) is conjugate to Î´isubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\delta_{i}. Recall that conjugacy classes of semisimple elements in algebraic groups are Zariskiâ€“closed and that every element of a compact algebraic group is semisimple. This immediately implies Wâ€‹(w,i)ğ‘Šğ‘¤ğ‘–W(w,i) is a closed subvariety since it is the pre-image of a closed subvariety under a rational map. Since evwsubscriptevğ‘¤\text{ev}_{w} is a dominant map to Kğ¾K, we also see that Wâ€‹(w,i)ğ‘Šğ‘¤ğ‘–W(w,i) is a proper subvariety of Homâ¡(Fn,K)Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K). Since it is clearly conjugationâ€“invariant we are done as above.

We now prove the third point which is quite similar to the first. We consider a word wâˆˆÎ”âˆ—â„¤ğ‘¤Î”â„¤w\in\Delta*\mathbb{Z} as a map from Kâ†’Kâ†’ğ¾ğ¾K\rightarrow K by inserting xâˆˆKğ‘¥ğ¾x\in K into wğ‘¤w anytime the generator for â„¤â„¤\mathbb{Z} appears. We let Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w) be the set of xâˆˆKğ‘¥ğ¾x\in K such that wâ€‹(x)=Idğ‘¤ğ‘¥Idw(x)=\operatorname{Id}. This set is clearly a subvariety of Kğ¾K and to prove the result it suffices to see that Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w) is proper for each wğ‘¤w. To see this, it suffices to find one faithful representation of Î”âˆ—â„¤Î”â„¤\Delta*\mathbb{Z} into Kğ¾K. This follows easily from the existence of one such representation into G=Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(n,â„‚)ğºğ‘†ğ¿ğ‘›â„‚G=SL(n,\mathbb{C}) and the fact that Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(n)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆğ‘›SU(n) is Zariski dense in Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(n,â„‚)ğ‘†ğ¿ğ‘›â„‚SL(n,\mathbb{C}). To clarify, we can define a map w~:Gâ†’G:~ğ‘¤â†’ğºğº\tilde{w}:G\rightarrow G exactly as we define wğ‘¤w and let V~â€‹(w)~ğ‘‰ğ‘¤\tilde{V}(w) be the subset of GğºG where w~â€‹(x)=Id~ğ‘¤ğ‘¥Id\tilde{w}(x)=\operatorname{Id}. Since Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(n)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆğ‘›SU(n) is Zariski dense in Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(n,C)ğ‘†ğ¿ğ‘›ğ¶SL(n,C) as a complex subvariety and V~â€‹(w)~ğ‘‰ğ‘¤\tilde{V}(w) is a complex subvariety, if V~â€‹(w)~ğ‘‰ğ‘¤\tilde{V}(w) is a proper subset of GğºG then Vâ€‹(w)ğ‘‰ğ‘¤V(w) is a proper subset of Kğ¾K. The existence of a faithful embedding of Î”âˆ—â„¤Î”â„¤\Delta*\mathbb{Z} in Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(n,â„‚)ğ‘†ğ¿ğ‘›â„‚SL(n,\mathbb{C}) where Î”Î”\Delta embeds in Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(n,â„‚)ğ‘†ğ¿ğ‘›â„‚SL(n,\mathbb{C}) is originally due to Nisnevich and was rediscovered later by Shalen [Nis, Sha]. âˆ

Remark: Borelâ€™s proof that word maps are dominant uses that there are dense free subgroups of at least SUâ¡(n)SUğ‘›\operatorname{SU}(n), so our proof of (1)1(1) using dominance really depends on the fact that (1)1(1) was already known. However, the proof of (1)1(1) given above serves well to motivate the proof of (2)2(2).

9.4. Proofs

Before beginning the proof of Theorem 1.7, we make a few historical remarks. We will need a dense subgroup Î”<KÎ”ğ¾\Delta<K with a spectral gap on L2â€‹(K)superscriptğ¿2ğ¾L^{2}(K). For particular choices of Kğ¾K, many of these are constructed as lattices in a Lie group GğºG which have dense embeddings in a compact form Kğ¾K of GğºG by Margulis, Sullivan and Drinâ€™feld [Mar2, Sul, Dri]. More recently, examples were found by more elementary methods by Gamburd, Jakobson and Sarnak in [GJS] where the authors conjecture that a generic dense free subgroup of a compact simple group Kğ¾K will have a spectral gap. In recent work towards that conjecture, Bourgainâ€“Gamburd and Benoistâ€“De Saxce show that any dense free subgroup of Kğ¾K with algebraic entries has a spectral gap [BG2, BG1, BdS]. If the Gamburdâ€“Jakobsonâ€“Sarnak conjecture is correct, one can prove Theorem 1.7 using only left actions of a free group and not left-right actions.

Proof of Theorem 1.7 (families of expanders).

Fix K=SUâ¡(n)ğ¾SUğ‘›K=\operatorname{SU}(n) and a free group Î”âŠ†KÎ”ğ¾\Delta\subseteq K with a spectral gap on L2â€‹(K)superscriptğ¿2ğ¾L^{2}(K). For any kâˆˆKğ‘˜ğ¾k\in K, the group âŸ¨Î”,kâŸ©Î”ğ‘˜\langle\Delta,k\rangle has spectral gap. Further, by Lemma 9.6.(3), for a generic choice of kğ‘˜k, we have âŸ¨Î”,kâŸ©â‰…Î”âˆ—â„¤â‰…FnÎ”ğ‘˜âˆ—Î”â„¤subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\langle\Delta,k\rangle\cong\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}\cong F_{n}. This produces a continuous of free group actions on Kğ¾K which are conjugate if and only if the have representatives in the character variety that are related by an automorphism of the free group. Since Outâ¡(Fn)Outsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›\operatorname{Out}(F_{n}) orbits in the character variety are countable, this produces continuous families that are not conjugate, so which have warped cones giving rise to quasi-isometrically disjoint families of expanders by Theorem 1.5.

âˆ

A different construction is to choose a simple compact Lie group Kğ¾K and a dense subgroup Î”âŠ†KÎ”ğ¾\Delta\subseteq K with a spectral gap on L2â€‹(K)superscriptğ¿2ğ¾L^{2}(K). As discussed above, we consider Î“=Î”Ã—FnÎ“Î”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Gamma=\Delta\times F_{n} and left-right Î“Î“\Gammaâ€“actions on Kğ¾K as defined by an element Î±âˆˆHomâ¡(Fn,K)ğ›¼Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\alpha\in\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K). Using Lemma 9.6 we see that off of a countably union of subvarieties in Homâ¡(Fn,K)/â£/KHomsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K the resulting left-right action of Î”Ã—FnÎ”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Delta\times F_{n} is free. This produces a continuumm of non-conjugate Î”Ã—FnÎ”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Delta\times F_{n} actions. Since the orbit of any action under Autâ¡(Î”Ã—Fn)AutÎ”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\operatorname{Aut}(\Delta\times F_{n}) in Homâ¡(Fn,K)/â£/KHomsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾ğ¾\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K is countable, this suffices to verify the hypotheses of Proposition 9.4.

Proof of Theorem 1.8 (families of superexpanders).

The proof is exactly as the above proof of Theorem 1.7, though the choices of Î”Î”\Delta and Kğ¾K are more limited. We can choose Î”Î”\Delta as in the paper of De Laatâ€“Vigolo to be a cocompact lattice in SLâ¡(d,â„šp)SLğ‘‘subscriptâ„šğ‘\operatorname{SL}(d,\mathbb{Q}_{p}) that has a dense embedding in K=SOâ¡(d)ğ¾SOğ‘‘K=\operatorname{SO}(d) [dLV]. As in that paper it follows from Lafforgueâ€™s work on strong property (T)ğ‘‡(T) [Laf] that the action on L2â€‹(K,Î¼,E)superscriptğ¿2ğ¾ğœ‡ğ¸L^{2}(K,\mu,E) has a spectral gap for any Eğ¸E with nontrivial type and so in particular for any uniformly convex Eğ¸E. More general choices are also possible by work of Liao [Lia]. The rest of the proof follows exactly as in the previous case, where we again choose generic homomorphisms Î±âˆˆHomâ¡(Fn,K)ğ›¼Homsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ¾\alpha\in\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) to define a left-right action of Î“=Î”Ã—FnÎ“Î”subscriptğ¹ğ‘›\Gamma=\Delta\times F_{n} on Kğ¾K. âˆ
